q1.quetsion_text: Name this politician who resigned as Secretary of State after making objections to foreign policy following the Lusitania sinking. He was the principal opponent of the Bourbon Democrats.

q2.quetsion_text: Near the end of his life, Bryan served as the prosecutor in this Tennessee trial, where a teacher was put on trial for teaching the theory of evolution. It was also known as the "monkey trial."

q3.quetsion_text: For much of the early 1900s, Bryan was a popular speaker on this circuit. Named after a New York lake, it promoted adult education and featured numerous cultural and religious speakers traveling throughout rural America

lead_in: This man's linguistic works include A Theory of Semiotics and The Role of the Reader. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Italian semiotician who authored the essay collection Misreadings, as well as Six Walks in the Fictional Woods. He also wrote the novels The Prague Cemetery and The Island of the Day Before.

q2.quetsion_text: In this Eco novel, William of Baskerville and his apprentice Adso of Melk investigate a series of murders at a monastery where a copy of Aristotle's lost treatise on comedy is kept.
q2.raw_answer: The Name of the Rose [or Il nome della rosa]

q3.quetsion_text: Eco's novel The Mysterious Flame of Queen Loana concerns Yambo, a man who forgets everything except what he has acquired while doing this activity. A prefatory poem by a different author addressed to a man doing this activity ends by calling him a hypocrite, a likeness and a brother.

lead_in: This is a bonus on American doggerel and food. To begin, let's listen to some beautiful poetry: "Come, dear bowl, Glide o'er my palate, and inspire my soul." For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: That bullshit appears in what three-canto poem by Joel Barlow that celebrates the title dish of cornmeal mush by mock-heroically tracing the history of corn?

q2.quetsion_text: "Wives in the avocadoes, babies in the tomatoes" and you, "Garcia Lorca...down by the watermelons" are just some of the enumerations of food found in this Allen Ginsberg poem.

q3.quetsion_text: Robert Hass writes "if you think I am going to make a sexual joke in this poem you are mistaken" in "Poem with a Cucumber in it," an entry in this collection of his. Another poem in this collection is a meditation on the pose of Vermeer's Milkmaid.

lead_in: This man took his pen name from the banana tree that his followers planted outside his rustic hut. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this poet who added his own commentary to the results of a poetry contest in The Seashell Game and wrote the poetic travelogue Narrow Road to the Deep North.
q1.raw_answer: Matsuo Basho [or Matsuo Kinsaku; or Matsuo Chuemon Munefusa]

q2.quetsion_text: Basho wrote that he loathed to see a miscanthus budding next to his banana plant in this Japanese poetic form that is comprised of three lines of five, seven, and five morae.

q3.quetsion_text: This contemporary female Japanese writer of Kitchen and Asleep, whose real first name is Mahoko, probably did not consider Basho when choosing her new fruit-related English first name.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Paramecium is one of the many organisms that belong to a class of protists that have many of these cellular structures, which they use to move and feed. They are generally shorter than flagella.

q2.quetsion_text: These protists have frustules made out of silica, which leads to beautiful patterns when viewed under a microscope.

q3.quetsion_text: This genus of green algae forms spherical colonies, with each cell containing two flagella. This genus is used as a model organism because it can reproduce both sexually and asexually.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Portuguese explorer who stayed in Calicut during his voyages to India.

q2.quetsion_text: da Gama paved the way for Portugal to obtain this small state in western India, which remained under Portuguese control until the 1960s.
q2.raw_answer: Goa [or Old Goa; or Velha Goa]

q3.quetsion_text: da Gama acquired these goods from the Malabar coast in an attempt to break Venetian monopolies on their trade. Holdings in Kerala produced these goods, and a search for them inspired Afonso de Albuquerque to find the Maluku Islands near Indonesia.
q3.raw_answer: spices [or peppers; or black pepper grains; or cloves; or nutmeg; or mace]

lead_in: Ancient Egyptian art made use of the "sunken" form of this technique, in which the carved figures are below the surface plane. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this type of sculpture in which the backs of figures are attached to the background.
q1.raw_answer: relief sculpture [or relievo or rilievo; or bas-relief; or high-relief; or sunk-relief]

q2.quetsion_text: This artist employed relief sculpture in his "Back" series. This head of the Fauvists also painted Harmony in Red and The Dance.

q3.quetsion_text: Some of the finest examples of Roman relief sculpture can be found on this shrine, which was originally located in the Field of Mars outside of Rome. Richard Meier built a museum around this structure, which was commissioned by the Senate in 13 BCE to honor Augustus.
q3.raw_answer: Ara Pacis [or Ara Pacis Augustae; or Altar of the Augustan Peace]

lead_in: Polynomials used for this purpose include Lagrange polynomials, Newton polynomials, and Hermite polynomials. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this task in numerical analysis that involves using a polynomial to approximate some other function.

q2.quetsion_text: A problem in numerical interpolation is Runge's phenomenon, in which error oscillation occurs over the edges of an interpolating interval. Runge's phenomenon occurs due to the fact that the interpolating points have this property.
q2.raw_answer: the points are equi-spaced [or the points are equally spaced from each other; accept equivalents]

q3.quetsion_text: This man's approximation theorem states that, over a closed interval, one can use a polynomial to model a continuous function with as much precision as desired.
q3.raw_answer: Karl [Theodor Wilhelm] Weierstrass [or Marshall Harvey Stone; accept Stone-Weierstrass theorem]

lead_in: An artist with this surname surprisingly took into account the accurate reflections cast by a sleeping cat and a dog eating scraps from a plate in his depiction of the Last Supper. F

q1.quetsion_text: Give this surname of Pietro and his brother, who depicted the prosperous Tuscan countryside and a tyrant with horns resting his feet upon a goat in two paintings from his series The Allegory of Good and Bad Government.
q1.raw_answer: Lorenzetti [or Ambrogio Lorenzetti; or Pietro Lorenzetti]

q2.quetsion_text: The Allegory of Good and Bad Government was located, as a solemn reminder, in the town hall of this Italian city, which rivaled Florence in its heyday in the 14th and 15th centuries.

q3.quetsion_text: Siena set the Italian Renaissance in motion by commissioning the artist Duccio to produce the Maesta, a massive altarpiece with these two enthroned religious figures in the middle. One of them cradles another in Pieta scenes.
q3.raw_answer: Jesus Christ and the Virgin Mary [accept in either order; or obvious equivalents mentioning Jesus Christ of Nazareth and the Virgin Mary; or Madonna and Child]

lead_in: He described how “people with monocles still complain, and sting, politely, like snakes in the grass” in the title poem of his collection “My Sister -- Life” and lamented that “this life is not a stroll across the meadow” in another poem. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this poet of “Hamlet”, which he attributed to the title character of a novel that was smuggled to Milan and published in 1957.

q2.quetsion_text: Pasternak won the Nobel Prize shortly after the aforementioned publication of this novel. Its title character, a physician and poet, dies of a heart attack shortly before his great love Lara dies in the gulag.

q3.quetsion_text: This poet walked out of the 1958 show trial in which Pasternak was expelled from the Union of Soviet Writers. He lamented the fact that “no monument stands over” the title location in his poem “Babi Yar”.

lead_in: A whole lot of people get killed in Norse mythology. Answer the following about some of them, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This god’s continuous conflict with Jörmungandr, the Midgard Serpent, leads to their mutual destruction at Ragnarök. This god of thunder carries the hammer Mjölnir.
q1.raw_answer: Thor [or Donar; or Thunor; or Thunraz]

q2.quetsion_text: Loki tricks this hapless blind god into killing his brother Baldur with a dart made of mistletoe. Vali was then conceived, born, and raised to adulthood in a single day to revenge-kill this poor guy.

q3.quetsion_text: After Fenrir eats Odin at Ragnarök, this son of Odin uses his incredibly thick shoe to help tear Fenrir’s jaws apart, killing the wolf.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name these membrane proteins, which are named for their similarity to a protein in Drosophila that aids in its immune response.

q2.quetsion_text: Toll-like receptors play a role in this part of the immune system, which is the first to respond to an infection. It includes the complement system and neutrophils, and is faster than the adaptive immune system.
q2.raw_answer: innate immune system [or innate immunity; or non-specific immunity]

q3.quetsion_text: The innate immune system often responds to an infection by causing this symptom characterized by swelling and redness.

lead_in: This person built a large citadel in Cairo and started a project to build a wall around Cairo and the historical city of Fustat.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this ruler who established the Ayyubid dynasty in the Middle East around the twelfth century AD.
q1.raw_answer: Saladin [or Salah ad-Din Yusuf ibn Ayyub; or al-Malik al-Nasir Salah al-Din Yusuf I]

q2.quetsion_text: At this 1187 battle, Saladin's forces defeated the armies of Guy of Lusignan, which allowed Saladin to gain control of Jerusalem. This battle is sometimes named for a geographical feature of the place where it was fought.
q2.raw_answer: Battle of Hattin [or Battle of Horns of Hattin]

q3.quetsion_text: Saladin conquered Aleppo and this other city, in modern Iraq, from the Zengids in the 1180s. Sovereignty over a vilayet centered in this city was the subject of a dispute between Turkey and the UK in the early 20th century.

lead_in: An adviser of this man was the former librarian Emile Banning. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this ruler who hired Henry Stanley to establish what would become this man’s personal fiefdom, the Congo Free State. Many countries were appalled by this man’s brutal control of that colony.
q1.raw_answer: Leopold II [or Léopold Louis Philippe Marie Victor; or Leopold Lodewijk Filips Maria Victor]

q2.quetsion_text: Leopold II was king of this European country, which controlled what would become the Democratic Republic of the Congo.
q2.raw_answer: Belgium [or Belgique; or Belgie; or Belgius]

q3.quetsion_text: This Irish diplomat wrote a namesake 1904 report chronicling the Congo Free State abuses. He would later be executed after being arrested shortly before the Easter Rising.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this pair of glands located immediately above the kidneys, which are responsible for secreting cortisol and epinephrine.

q2.quetsion_text: Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome occurs when the adrenal glands hemorrhage and die. Such a syndrome would naturally mimic this disease, in which the adrenal glands are chronically insufficient.

q3.quetsion_text: Pheochromocytoma, which are tumors of the adrenal glands, are bilateral and extra-adrenal about this percentage of the time. When energy moves from one trophic level to another, this is the percent stored as biomass.

lead_in: This outburst was caught on microphone after its speaker hit a fadeaway two-pointer over Patrick Patterson to put his team up 7 with a minute to go.

q1.quetsion_text: Give the enthusiastic six-word sentence that Paul Pierce shouted at the end of Game 7 in the 2014 Nets-Raptors series.
q1.raw_answer: "That's why they got me here!" [or "That's why they brought me here!"]

q2.quetsion_text: During the offseason, Ernie Grunfeld got Paul Pierce here by signing the veteran to this team as a cheaper replacement for Trevor Ariza. John Wall and Bradley Beal got this team a surprise first-round win over the Bulls.

q3.quetsion_text: During the Nets-Raptors series, this global ambassador for the Toronto Raptors was caught rolling his pants for lint courtside. The NBA fined this man over the summer for tampering with Kevin Durant.

lead_in: One creature who was pretty much identical to this other creature was named Empusa. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Libyan queen who became a devourer of children after she was transformed into a hideous serpent-demoness.

q2.quetsion_text: Lamia was transformed into a hideous demon and cursed to eat children by this goddess, because Lamia was having an affair with her husband Zeus.

q3.quetsion_text: Zeus gave Lamia the power to detach these body parts and reattach them. The Graeae were a group of sisters who shared one of these body parts and one tooth as well.

lead_in: Gallus Anonymus was among the first historians of this country, which was ruled by kings such as Mieszko I and Casimir the Restorer. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this European country. The Union of Krewo, in which its queen Jadwiga married into the Jagiello family, united it with Lithuania.

q2.quetsion_text: This first ruling Polish dynasty included Mieszko and Casimir. Its final king, Casimir III, was succeeded by Louis of Hungary, giving way to Angevin rule.

q3.quetsion_text: The third Holy Roman Emperor with this name was a close ally of the Piast king Boleslaw I. The first Holy Roman Emperor of this name, nicknamed "the Great," beat the Magyars at Lechfeld in 962.
q3.raw_answer: Otto [or Otto III; or Otto I; or Otto the Great]

lead_in: Answer the following about wine-producing regions of the world, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This country produces some of the world’s best sauvignon blanc in the vineyards in its Marlborough and Hawke’s Bay regions, though it also produces red wine from the area around its largest city, Auckland.

q2.quetsion_text: The criminally underrated Vinho Verde originated in the historical Minho province of this western European country. The fortified wine-producing archipelago of Madeira is one of its two Autonomous Regions.
q2.raw_answer: Portugal [accept the Portuguese Republic or Republica Portuguesa]

q3.quetsion_text: Egri Bikaver, or “the Bull’s Blood of Eger”, and a white dessert wine from the region of Tokaj are the most famous wines produced by this country. The 1920 Treaty of Trianon gave part of Tokaj to this country's northern neighbor.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this island, home of a Dutch enclave called Batavia. In 1891, a namesake Homo erectus fossil was found at Trinil on this Southeast Asian island.

q2.quetsion_text: After taking over from the Dutch, this British lieutenant governor of Java eased many of the colonial restrictions on the island. He also established the British colony in Singapore.

q3.quetsion_text: This Indonesian autocrat's rise to power was aided by thousands of anti-Communist killings in Java. He forced Sukarno to transfer power to him in 1965.

lead_in: A formalism in this discipline uses the linear adiabatic wave equation when higher order pulsations can be neglected. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this discipline that probes stellar interiors through energy pulsations, analogous to how geophysicists probe the Earth's interior by studying p-waves and s-waves.
q1.raw_answer: asteroseismology [accept descriptive equivalents such as stellar seismology or the study of seismology in stars; do not accept or prompt on answers including "starquakes"]

q2.quetsion_text: The rapid pulsation of AP stars and ZZ Ceti stars is driven by this phenomenon, in which opacity increases as a star's interior becomes more pressurized. The Kramer's relation describes this phenomenon.

q3.quetsion_text: By assuming the Eddington model of pulsation, one can use the equation of state for a star in hydrostatic equilibrium to derive the equation named for the pulsation period and this other quantity. That equation states that the pulsation period is inversely proportional to this state variable of a star.
q3.raw_answer: mean density [accept the period mean density relation]

lead_in: Published in the same year as its author’s books Speech and Phenomena and Writing and Difference, it opens with a section on “the end of the book and the beginning of writing”. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this 1967 book which also critiques Saussure’s conception of the relationship between speech and writing. Its author, Jacques Derrida, proposes replacing linguistics with the title science.

q2.quetsion_text: In Of Grammatology’s section on Rousseau, Derrida claims that “reading must remain intrinsic”, and thus the absence of the “transcendental signified” prompts the famous conclusion that “there is nothing” in this location.
q2.raw_answer: “there is nothing outside (of) the text” [or “il n'y a pas de hors-texte”; or translational variants of “there is no out-of-the-text”]

q3.quetsion_text: In a section on justice in Specters of Marx, Derrida quotes the line “time is out of joint” from this Shakespeare play, which also contains soliloquies beginning “What a piece of work is a man!” and “To be or not to be”.
q3.raw_answer: Hamlet [or The Tragedy of Hamlet, Prince of Denmark]

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this violin concerto in E major, whose opening movement depicts the singing of birds and a thunderstorm.
q1.raw_answer: Violin Concerto in E major, Op. 8 No. 1 RV 269, "La primavera" [or "Spring"; accept any underlined portion]

q2.quetsion_text: "Spring" is the first of the Four Seasons violin concertos, which appear in this Italian Baroque composer's The Contest Between Harmony and Invention.

q3.quetsion_text: Vivaldi also composed a setting of this Catholic hymn about the Virgin Mary's sorrows during the crucifixion. Giovanni Battista Pergolesi wrote another famous setting of this hymn in 1736.

lead_in: This book opens with a conversation between Ahern and Robartes, who argues that the 28 embodiments of nature and mankind correspond to the phases of the moon. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this book that uses astrology and "The Great Wheel" to interpret history. Its sections include "What the Caliph Partly Learned" and "What the Caliph Refused to Learn."

q2.quetsion_text: A Vision is one of the densest works of this poet and literary critic, who also wrote The Madness of King Goll and the English-language preface to Gitanjali.

q3.quetsion_text: In A Vision, Yeats begins by saying he was inspired to write A Vision after engaging in this practice. Philippe Soupault and another author wrote Les Champs Magnetiques using this technique.
q3.raw_answer: automatic writing [or pure psychic automatism; accept descriptive equivalents]

lead_in: At one point, this text repeats the word "screenplays" seven times and it notes that, "from William James to Voronoff," the title idea is a "transfiguration of taboo into totem." For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this manifesto by Oswald de Andrade, which notes that only the title idea unites us. It contains the line, "Tupi or not tupi that is the question."
q1.raw_answer: "Cannibal Manifesto" [or Manifesto Antropófago; accept but do not reveal "Brazilwood Manifesto"; accept similar translations such as "Cannibalist's Manifesto"]

q2.quetsion_text: Oswald de Andrade is a writer who was part of this country's Modernist Movement. It is the home country of Jorge Amado, who wrote Gabriela, Clove and Cinnamon.
q2.raw_answer: Federative Republic of Brazil [or República Federativa do Brasil]

q3.quetsion_text: In one work, this earlier author recalls meeting a cannibal from Brazil brought to him by Villegagnon, which leads him to conclude "each men calls barbarism whatever is not his own practice; for indeed it seems we have no other test of truth and reason than the pattern of the opinions and customs of the country we live in."

lead_in: A small degree of self-government was allowed in this system by the Minto-Morley Reforms of 1909. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this system whose last Viceroy was Lord Mountbatten. Under this system, "Pukka Sahib" British bureaucrats isolated themselves from India's population with whites-only private clubs.
q1.raw_answer: British Raj System [prompt on "British Empire" or "Indian empire"]

q2.quetsion_text: The Raj System began under this monarch, who oversaw the transfer of India from the British East India Company to the crown after the Sepoy mutiny in 1857.

q3.quetsion_text: In this city, a "pact" between the Indian National Congress and the Muslim League committed both to opposing the British Raj. Colin Campbell relieved a pre-Raj siege of this city during the Sepoy mutiny.

lead_in: The instantaneous polarity at each terminal of this device is denoted using the dot convention. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this device used to "step up" or "step down" voltages and match impedances in AC circuits. Its simplest form contains two mutually coupled inductors called the primary and secondary windings.

q2.quetsion_text: Along with eddy currents, this phenomenon is the main source of energy loss in a transformer. Schmitt triggers and noise gates implement this phenomenon to reduce contact bounce.

q3.quetsion_text: This diminutive, hunchbacked arch-badass of electrical engineering formulated an empirical law of hysteresis loss and developed an equivalent circuit model of transformers and induction motors. This "Wizard of Schenectady" created phasor notation and loved party tricks like smiting trees with artificial lightning.
q3.raw_answer: Charles Proteus Steinmetz [or Karl August Rudolph Steinmetz]

lead_in: Answer the following about some revolting peasants, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This leader of the English Peasant's Revolt was stabbed by the Lord Mayor of London after he swished water in his mouth "in a very rude and disgusting fashion."

q2.quetsion_text: Followers of this Kentish rebel put the heads of James Fiennes and William Crowmer on pikes so that they appeared to kiss before they were defeated in a dramatic battle on London Bridge.

q3.quetsion_text: This Hungarian was set to be a commander of an army of Crusaders against the Ottomans in 1514, but instead led a peasant army against the nobility. He was eventually captured and made to sit on a scalding iron throne while his followers were forced to bite off and eat chunks of his flesh.
q3.raw_answer: György Dózsa (or György Székely; or Gheorghe Doja]

lead_in: Pierre Ronsard's poem Discourse was written in the aftermath of this event. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this event in which a group of Hugenots were burned in a church, a massacre that helped spark the French Wars of Religion.
q1.raw_answer: Massacre of Vassy [or Massacre of Wassy; accept reasonable equivalents including Vassy or Wassy]

q2.quetsion_text: The Vassy Massacre was carried out by Francis, who held this title. Francis's son, who also held this title, founded the Catholic League.
q2.raw_answer: Duke of Guise [or duc de Guise; accept Prince of Joinville]

q3.quetsion_text: The latter Duke de Guise had this first name; he was one of three men with this name who contested the eighth and final conflict in the French Wars of Religion.
q3.raw_answer: Henry [accept War of the Three Henrys]

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this quantity, the energy released when the constituent atoms of a molecule come together. It is usually measured at 25 degrees Celsius and 1 bar, and is zero for elements in their standard states.
q1.raw_answer: enthalpy of formation [or standard heat of formation]

q2.quetsion_text: In order to determine the enthalpy of a state not at 25 degrees Celsius, you can add on the integral of this quantity with respect to temperature. This quantity is the amount of energy required to increase temperature by one degree.
q2.raw_answer: specific heat [or heat capacity; or Cp]

q3.quetsion_text: For liquids and solids, enthalpy is usually pressure-independent, because those phases are usually assumed to approximate this condition, which requires that volume is independent of pressure.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this event during which a group of predominantly African American workers walked off the job, much to the chagrin of Mayor Henry Loeb, a "white unity" advocate.
q1.raw_answer: 1968 Memphis Sanitation Strike (anything indicating a strike or walkout that occurred in Memphis in 1968 and/or a strike or walkout that occurred in Memphis among garbage or sanitation workers)

q2.quetsion_text: This civil rights activist gave his "I've Been to the Mountaintop" speech to support the striking workers but was shot that night at the Lorraine motel.

q3.quetsion_text: After King's death, Ralph Abernathy assumed leadership of this organization. This non-militant organization helped plan the March on Washington and also ran the Birmingham Campaign and the Poor People's Campaign.

lead_in: One of these gods gave the first humans wit, while the other gave them speech and sight. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these two sons of Borr who help their brother kill a primordial frost giant.
q1.raw_answer: Vili and Ve [prompt if only one is given; accept in either order]

q2.quetsion_text: Vili and Ve helped their brother Odin kill this frost giant from Norse mythology.

q3.quetsion_text: Loki accused this wife of Odin of carrying on an affair with Odin's brothers.

lead_in: Styx was the first to side with Zeus and the others during this 10-year long conflict. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this war which pitted Hades, Poseidon, and their brethren against another group of immortal deities, which included Hyperion.
q1.raw_answer: Titanomachy [accept the war between the titans and gods, or other such equivalents]

q2.quetsion_text: This leader of the Titans had dethroned Uranus. He swallowed up the siblings of Zeus because he wished to avoid his downfall, which was foretold in a prophecy.

q3.quetsion_text: This titaness was the wife of Oceanus. She was sometimes conflated with Thalassa, another personification of the sea.

lead_in: One member of this literary family described Ralph Waldo Emerson as “a convert to--nothing but Emerson” in A Fable For Critics, while another asked “Christ! What are patterns for?” in her most famous poem. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this Boston literary family whose members include the aforementioned James Russell and Amy, as well as Robert, who wrote “Skunk Hour” and “For the Union Dead”.

q2.quetsion_text: Amy Lowell was particularly associated with this early-20th-century poetic movement, much to the dismay of another prominent member, Ezra Pound, whose poem “In a Station of the Metro” exemplifies it.

q3.quetsion_text: Imagism was a major influence on this last editor of The Dial, who described “scale lapping scale with spruce- cone regularity” in “The Pangolin” and wrote of a desire to create “imaginary gardens with real toads in them” in “Poetry”.

lead_in: This composer included musical depictions of scenes from Rapunzel and Rumpelstiltskin in his MÃ¤rchenbilder for viola and piano.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this German composer who wrote the song cycle Dichterliebe during his "Year of Song". He wrote his only piano concerto for his wife, Clara Wieck.

q2.quetsion_text: This collection of piano pieces by Schumann includes three musical cryptograms, portraits of Schumann's alter-egos Eusebius and Florestan, and depictions of the Commedia dell'arte characters Pantalon and Colombine.

q3.quetsion_text: Carnaval ends with the march of this group against the Philistines. This society was founded by Schumann to promote contemporary music and his Opus 6 is a series of eighteen dances named for this group

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this text by Simone de Beauvoir, which contains the quote, "One is not born but becomes a woman".
q1.raw_answer: The Second Sex [or Le Deuxieme Sexe]

q2.quetsion_text: Beauvoir described her life with this French philosopher in memoirs like The Prime of Life. This man wrote Existentialism is a Humanism and Being and Nothingness.

q3.quetsion_text: The Second Sex touched on the role of the male form of this way of perceiving and interpreting art. Laura Mulvey argued that this concept often manifested as women being shown as objects of attraction and desire rather than active participants.

lead_in: This system was first used at a 1983 production by the company of Lotfi Mansouri, who placed a video screen above the proscenium. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this system used to keep operatic audiences aware of what the lyrics mean.
q1.raw_answer: surtitles [or supertitles; do not accept or prompt on "subtitles"]

q2.quetsion_text: The first use of surtitles occurred during a performance of this Richard Strauss opera, whose title character is the daughter of Klytaemnestra and the sister of Orest.

q3.quetsion_text: This music director of the Met said of surtitles, "Over my dead body will they show those things at this house," but he was mollified by Met Titles, which have individual display screens on the back of the seats. He has led more than 2,000 performances at the Met since 1971.

lead_in: On the Trobriand Islands, only chiefs can really participate in this system, while it is open to all men on the island of Dobu. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this ceremonial system in modern day Papua New Guinea in which participants exchange things such as necklaces or armshells. It was studied extensively by Bronislaw Malinowski in Argonauts of the Western Pacific.

q2.quetsion_text: The Trobriand Islanders, like many societies, have form of taboo against this practice, which consists of sexual relations between blood relatives.

q3.quetsion_text: The concept of gift exchange was analyzed in The Gift by Marcel Mauss. Mauss claimed that the gift was this two word object which had “spiritual mechanisms” affecting both giver and receiver. As this term implies, the gift represents all of a specific society.

lead_in: Tony Harrison used the rediscovery of one work in this genre as the basis of his play The Trackers at Oxyrhyncus. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this literary genre whose only fully extant example, a play depicting a comical version of a scene from the Odyssey, is Cyclops.

q2.quetsion_text: Cyclops was written by this Athenian tragedian, whose other plays include The Suppliants, Alcestis, Hippolytus, and Medea.

q3.quetsion_text: Euripides wrote two plays titled for this character, which relate how she was whisked away to the island of Tauris by Artemis, thus rescuing her from Agamemnon’s attempt to sacrifice her at Aulis.

lead_in: A Carl Milles fountain depicting two nude, sexualized figures riding fish as they prepare to be married called The Meeting of the Waters is found outside this city’s Theodore Link-designed Union Station. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Midwestern city that contains Eero Saarinen’s Gateway Arch.

q2.quetsion_text: This early skyscraper, a red-brick office building designed in the Palazzo style by Henry Sullivan, is a St. Louis architectural landmark.

q3.quetsion_text: The Wainwright Building was co-designed by Sullivan and this German-born architect, the second named partner in Sullivan’s architectural firm.

lead_in: The losing side in this battle was routed after getting caught between Marcantonio Colonna's cavalry charge and the frontal attack by Il Medeghino. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this clash during the Italian War of 1551, fought on the Scannagallo River near Arezzo. It resulted in Siena losing its independence and becoming part of the Grand Duchy of Tuscany.
q1.raw_answer: Battle of Marciano [prompt on Battle of Scannagallo]

q2.quetsion_text: The Battle of Marciano was fought between Siena and this Italian city-state, whose forces were led by Gian Giacomo Medici, a poor and far-flung Milanese relation of its ruler at the time, Cosimo.

q3.quetsion_text: The Milanese Medicis made it big in the world when this younger brother of Gian Giacomo, born Giovanni Angelo Medici, was named pope. He presided over the last session of the Council of Trent.

lead_in: This man wrote about Walter Hartright finding a woman who has escaped from an asylum in one novel. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this British author of The Woman in White. He also cowrote "A House to Let" with Charles Dickens and some female authors.

q2.quetsion_text: This Collins work, considered to be the first detective novel, features several narrators such as the prim evangelist Drusilla Clack and ends with the title gem being returned to its temple in India.

q3.quetsion_text: This character is the first to realize that no one stole the moonstone. This geriatric policeman wins the friendship of the butler Betteredge and employs a boy with notably bulging eyes, Gooseberry.

lead_in: The SHE, which consists of a piece of platinum in a solution with hydrogen gas bubbled into it, has a defined value of 0 for this quantity. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this quantity which can be determined from thermodynamics by the Nernst equation.
q1.raw_answer: reduction potential [or voltage, prompt on “V” or “E”]

q2.quetsion_text: The denominator of the term proportional to the natural log of the reaction quotient in the Nernst equation contains this constant, which is approximately 96,500 Coulombs per mol of electrons.
q2.raw_answer: Faraday constant [prompt on “F,” do NOT accept or prompt on “Farad”]

q3.quetsion_text: The difference between the actual electrode potential and the electrode potential determined by the Nernst equation is this quantity. When this quantity is low, the Butler-Volmer equation is approximately linear.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this king of Thebes who was the first husband of Jocasta. He was murdered by his son while he was travelling on the way back from the Delphic oracle.

q2.quetsion_text: This unfortunate hero was the one who murdered his father Laius and married his own mother Jocasta. His other exploits include ridding Thebes of the sphinx.

q3.quetsion_text: This son of Oedipus became one of the Seven against Thebes after he and his brother could not share the throne peacefully. Creon ordered that this man be refused burial.

lead_in: Unlike his brother Pratap, this novel’s protagonist does not stay on as an estate worker, a decision which later allows him to read Marcus Aurelius’s Meditations on his Slumberking bed. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this 1961 novel whose title polydactylic sign-painter marries into the Tulsi family, gets a job as a journalist, and becomes obsessed with building the title structure.

q2.quetsion_text: A House for Mr. Biswas was written by this Indo-Trinidadian author of A Bend in the River and In a Free State.

q3.quetsion_text: This critic discussed the “two sides” of V.S. Naipaul in his essay “Wounder and Wounded”, which was collected in his book The Fun Stuff. This New Yorker writer also wrote the book How Fiction Works.

lead_in: The first chief residents of this building are depicted in statue form as Caesar and his wife; those statues decorate the sarcophagus of a chapel later added to this mansion by William Kent.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this country house designed in Woodstock, England, by then-novice architect John Vanbrugh, for the Duke of Marlborough.

q2.quetsion_text: Blenheim Palace mostly avoided a popular style of English architecture named for this Italian, whose treatise The Four Books of Architecture was so influential that Thomas Jefferson abided by it for Monticello.

q3.quetsion_text: The popularity of the Palladian style in the British isles was further undermined by the elegant style invented by this Scottish architect of the Kenwood House and Osterley Park. He took into account furniture and other interior objects in his designs.

lead_in: A September 1994 issue of the American Economic Review carried a landmark study by David Card and Alan Krueger on this topic. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this legally mandated value, whose impact Card and Krueger analyzed by phoning hundreds of New Jersey and Pennsylvania restaurants.

q2.quetsion_text: A writer who has cited that study is this Nobel laureate with a New York Times column.

q3.quetsion_text: Republicans generally favor this program, which allows some poor workers to get a refund larger than their withholdings. Krugman argues that the amount of this benefit should be increased along with the minimum wage.
q3.raw_answer: Earned Income Tax Credit [or EITC; or EIC]

lead_in: This author and Anna Strunsky co-authored the pseudonymous novel The Kempton-Wace Letters, while his second wife Charmian described their life together in The Log of the Snark and Our Hawaii. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this socialist author of the dystopian novel The Iron Heel, who also wrote two novels set during the Klondike Gold Rush, White Fang and The Call of the Wild.
q1.raw_answer: Jack London [or John Griffith London; or John Griffith Chaney]

q2.quetsion_text: The protagonist of this London story disregards the advice of the old-timer from Sulphur Creek while traveling through the Yukon on a cold day, and eventually freezes to death after failing at the title endeavor.

q3.quetsion_text: London may have taken a phrase from H.G. Wells’s Anticipations to title this 1903 exposé about life among the poor in the workhouses of the East End of London.

lead_in: This thinker suggested that the Ego is formed at the moment when infants are able to recognize reflections as being their own image, which he termed the "mirror stage".

q1.quetsion_text: Name this French psychoanalyst who divided reality into the Imaginary, Real, and Symbolic orders.

q2.quetsion_text: Lacan's Real order roughly corresponds to this concept from Freudian terminology, referring to the part of our personalities containing all of our primal urges. It forms a triad with the ego and superego.

q3.quetsion_text: This queer theorist and author of Epistemology of the Closet suggested moving past Freudian and Lacanian notions of "sexual difference" in "Paranoid Reading and Reparative Reading".

lead_in: This member of a prominent musical family honored one of his strongest influences with the trio sonata Parnassus, or the Apotheosis of Corelli. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this French composer of such keyboard works as The Mysterious Barricades. Nicknamed "le Grand", he was memorialized in a piano suite by Maurice Ravel.

q2.quetsion_text: Couperin's music inspired a Dance Suite and a Divertimento by this German composer of the tone poems Death and Transfiguration and Ein Heldenleben. This man's operas include Salome and Der Rosenkavalier.

q3.quetsion_text: The aforementioned Arcangelo Corelli invented this Baroque musical form in which music is passed between a small group of soloists and the "ripieno", or the rest of the orchestra, unlike a similar form which uses only one soloist.
q3.raw_answer: concerto grosso [or concerti grossi; do not accept or prompt on "concerto" alone]

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this level of protein structure that describes local three-dimensional form into common motifs like alpha-helices and beta-sheets.

q2.quetsion_text: These structures are formed from sheets that wrap all the way around and are commonly found in transmembrane proteins.

q3.quetsion_text: An improvement on the ChouÂ–Fasman method, this method of predicting secondary structure also takes into account the conditional probabilities that a protein will be in a certain structure given that its neighbors are in some given structure.

lead_in: ATTENTION: MODERATORS DO NOT REVEAL THE FULL ANSWERLINE IN THE FIRST PART. This man was slain by killers probably employed by his half-brother Dingane. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this ruler and son of Nandi who used such military innovations as the “bull horns” formation. The empire he led from 1816 to 1828 would go on to fight the British at the Battle of Isandlwana decades later.

q2.quetsion_text: Shaka is considered the greatest leader of what Southern African kingdom that would fight the Voortrekkers and British in bloody 1800’s wars?

q3.quetsion_text: As ruler, Shaka’s series of wars caused a series of migrations that would help cause this chaotic, bloody period in Southern Africa known by a term meaning “crushing”. The peak of the violence in this period came when King Mzilikazi ordered mass slaying of his enemies.
q3.raw_answer: Mfecane [prompt on scattering, accept Difaqane or Lifaqane]

lead_in: This chapter, which follows "Where I lived, and what I lived for," quotes George Chapman's Caesar and Pompey to praise the livelihood of a farmer, and ends by reproducing Thomas Carew's "The Pretensions of Poverty." For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this first chapter of a larger work in which the author relates his desire to live alone in the woods. It includes a list of prices used in building a house, which sum to about $28.

q2.quetsion_text: The "Economy" chapter appears in this book, which describes how the author built a cabin and appreciated nature next to the title pond.

q3.quetsion_text: This book by Annie Dillard is structured similarly to Walden and follows the narrator's attempts at living nearby the title stream in the Blue Ridge Mountains.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name these proteins, labelled A, B, D, and E. The B one associates with CDK1 to form maturation promoting factor during the entry to mitosis.

q2.quetsion_text: Cyclins D, E, and A, on the other hand, accumulate during this "resting" phase of the cell cycle, composed of G1, S, and G2.

q3.quetsion_text: One target of MPF is this class of intermediate filaments found on the inner face of the nuclear envelope. Rb, a regulator of mitotic activity, is a transcription factor localized to these fibrous proteins.
q3.raw_answer: lamins [prompt on nuclear lamina; do not accept "laminins"]

lead_in: This philosophical thought experiment is used to determine a just social contract.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this construct, behind which people do not know their initial position in a society when determining what would be a just distribution of resources in that society.

q2.quetsion_text: This philosopher developed the veil of ignorance in A Theory of Justice. Robert Nozick attacked the ideas of this philosopher in Anarchy, State, and Utopia.

q3.quetsion_text: According to Rawls, human beings' innate sense of justice allows us to arrive at this state of balance and coherence of beliefs, through constant adjustments of all beliefs that are in mutual conflict.

lead_in: In 1968, a statewide event of this type in Florida forced governor Claude Kirk to pass new taxes. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this type of event that Albert Shanker organized in the Ocean Hill-Brownsville district of New York City in 1968.
q1.raw_answer: teachers' strikes [or strikes by a teachers' union; accept any reasonable equivalent]

q2.quetsion_text: In 2012, Karen Lewis led a week-long teachers' strike in this city in protest against overcrowded working conditions and over-reliance on standardized testing under mayor Rahm Emanuel.

q3.quetsion_text: This controversial 1983 report commissioned by the Reagan administration cited declining SAT scores, writing skills, and mathematical abilities to argue for more rigorous standards in American education.
q3.raw_answer: A Nation at Risk: The Imperative For Educational Reform

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this major boulevard in a European capital where signs reading "PAZI!" warned of constant danger during an extended siege by Serbs in the 1990s.
q1.raw_answer: Sniper's Alley [or Ulica Zmaja od Bosne; prompt on "Sarajevo"]

q2.quetsion_text: Sarajevo was home to Sniper Alley during a war named for this republic. It suffered the Srebrenica massacre after it declared independence from Yugoslavia along with its constituent Herzegovina.

q3.quetsion_text: The Bosnian War was ended by this agreement, signed at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base near its namesake U.S. city. Bosnia's copy of this agreement was embarrassingly lost in 2008.
q3.raw_answer: Dayton-Paris agreement [or Dayton Accords; or General Framework Agreement for Peace in Bosnia and Herzegovina; prompt on "Paris Protocol"]

lead_in: This polity fought against a colonial power in battles at Mbumbi and Mbwila. F

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this kingdom that was founded by a "nami" named Lukeni lua Nami. It had its capital at Mbanza.

q2.quetsion_text: The Kingdom of Kongo fought several wars against this colonial power. Missionaries from this empire converted kings of the Kongo, who then took on names like Afonso and Joao.

q3.quetsion_text: This man's explorations of the Upper Congo river, and treaties with natives on behalf of France, led to disputes between the Portuguese and French. He lends his name to the current capital of the Republic of Congo.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this device, found at the beginning of Beethoven's first piano sonata, which consists of a crescendoing arpeggio rising through several octaves. Its name comes in part from the 18th-century school founded by Stamitz.

q2.quetsion_text: A Mannheim Rocket appears at the beginning of the fourth movement of this Mozart symphony, the only one to open with an accompaniment figure.
q2.raw_answer: Symphony No. 40 in G minor (or the Great G minor Symphony; or KV. 550)

q3.quetsion_text: This Austrian composer employed a Mannheim Rocket in the opening movement of his Trout Quintet. He famously left his eighth symphony unfinished.

lead_in: Name some things about the difference between the Jewish and Christian Bibles, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: The Christian Old Testament is a rearrangement of this set of Hebrew Scriptures, whose name reflects its three sections - the Torah, the Prophets, and the Writings.

q2.quetsion_text: The Tanakh, like the Old Testament, begins with this book. This book opens with two different creation stories and contains the stories of Cain and Abel and Noah.

q3.quetsion_text: This term designates books, like the Odes of Solomon and the Gospel of Barnabas, not included in Christian canons that were purportedly written by important people. Confusingly, some Protestant scholars have conflated this term with “deuterocanonical” and “apocryphal”.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this four-novel cycle including Justine, Balthazar, Mountolive, and Clea.

q2.quetsion_text: Another Englishman who wrote a long novel cycle was this author of Framley Parsonage and Barchester Towers, which he included in his Chronicles of Barsetshire.

q3.quetsion_text: An early supporter of Trollope was this other English author of The History of Henry Esmond and a "Novel without a hero," Vanity Fair.

lead_in: Denver rarely leaves the house at this address. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this address, the location of a house that Howard and Bulgar flee because they believe it is haunted. Other residents here used to live on the Sweet Home plantation.

q2.quetsion_text: This novel opens with the observation that "124 was spiteful" and "full of a baby's venom." In this novel, Baby Suggs is the mother of Halle and mother-in-law of the protagonist.

q3.quetsion_text: This American author of Song of Solomon told the story of Sethe's infanticide in Beloved.

lead_in: A red curtain dominates the top portion of this painting, which was rejected by the church of Santa Maria della Scala because the artist used a prostitute as the model for the title figure. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this painting whose title figure lies in a red dress with her left arm splayed out to the side, while the apostles gather behind her and Mary Magdalene sits in front with her head in her hands.

q2.quetsion_text: In this painting, created for the Contarelli Chapel, a beam of light originates in the upper right, above a man pointing toward a customs-house table. The title figure may be either a seated, bearded man or the youth at which he points.

q3.quetsion_text: This Italian pioneer of tenebrism painted such chiaroscuro-heavy paintings as The Death of the Virgin and The Calling of Saint Matthew.
q3.raw_answer: Michelangelo Merisi o Amerighi da Caravaggio [accept either underlined portion]

lead_in: This bonus on Feynman diagrams has nothing to do with ghosts, penguins, or ghost penguins. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Because this equation contains an infinite number of interactions, the ladder approximation is used to convert it to a Feynman diagram. This equation describes the bound states of a two-particle system in quantum field theory.

q2.quetsion_text: Using this method to calculate the S-matrix generates expansion terms that correspond to Feynman diagrams. This theory approximates a quantum system in terms of a simpler system subject to a small corrective disturbance.

q3.quetsion_text: The standard perturbative expansion of the S-matrix is this physicist's namesake series. His namesake equation sets the self-energy operator equal to the inverse of the bare propagator minus the inverse of the dressed propagator.
q3.raw_answer: Freeman Dyson [or Dyson series; or Dyson equation]

lead_in: These cells are found in Howship's lacunae. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these multinucleated cells formed from fused monocytes. They secrete acid phosphatases like TRAP, and proteases like cathepsin K, from the ruffled border, causing the breakdown of elastin and collagen.
q1.raw_answer: osteoclasts [do not accept or prompt on "osteoblasts"]

q2.quetsion_text: Inhibitors of osteoclast activity can help prevent this condition, which causes bone density to diminish. It's most common in elderly patients.

q3.quetsion_text: The protons released by osteoclasts through the ruffled border are generated through the action of this enzyme. This catalytically perfect enzyme buffers blood by catalyzing the conversion of carbon dioxide to bicarbonate.

lead_in: This woman became addicted to pain medication following a back injury in the mid-60s. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this first lady and namesake of a center for recovery from chemical dependencies.

q2.quetsion_text: Betty Ford underwent surgery relating to this disease while in the White House. The Susan G. Komen non-profit funds research to cure this disease.

q3.quetsion_text: Betty Ford studied under this woman at Bennington College in Vermont, and, as first lady, helped secure a Presidential Medal of Freedom for her. Her Episodes uses the music of Anton von Webern, and she worked with Louis Horst on Frontier.

lead_in: This book is dedicated to “the socialists of all parties.” For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this 1940’s book which is meant to warn “of the danger of tyranny that inevitably results from government control of economic decision-making through central planning.” This libertarian text was written by one of the chief leaders of the Austrian school of economics.

q2.quetsion_text: The Road to Serfdom’s author, Friedrich von Hayek, taught during the 1950’s at this American university. Its namesake economic school rejects Keynesianism, and includes scholars like Milton Friedman and Ronald Coase.

q3.quetsion_text: Hayek and other thinkers formed this think tank in 1947 that is dedicated to free market economic policies. This society is named for a Swiss resort and was originally going to be named the “Acton-Tocqueville” Society.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: This man's book The Wretched of the Earth's first chapter discusses violence as a means of ending colonialism. He also wrote Black Skin, White Masks.

q2.quetsion_text: This man's 2008 work Violence discusses events like the 2005 Parisian riots. This Slovenian Marxist also wrote How to Read Lacan and many other works of criticism and philosophy.

q3.quetsion_text: This French anthropologist wrote The Archaeology of Violence. He's more famous for working with the Guayaki and publishing Society Against the State.

lead_in: This leader of the ominously-named “Cabal of Naples” painted that city’s patron saint, Januarius, emerging unscathed from a furnace. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this artist who painted a jolly-looking Clubfooted Boy and multiple canvases of St. Bartholomew being flayed. While working in Italy, he was given a diminutive nickname referencing his nationality.
q1.raw_answer: Jusepe de Ribera [or Jose de Ribera; or Giuseppe de Ribera; or Lo Spagnoletto; or The Little Spaniard]

q2.quetsion_text: Ribera, and the later Murillo and Zurbaran, were the foremost Spanish painters in this period of art characterized by dramatic tension and lighting effects. Caravaggio is the best-known Italian painter from this period from around 1600 to 1750.

q3.quetsion_text: This term, from the Italian for "murky", refers to an extreme version of chiaroscuro pioneered by Caravaggio. Paintings in this style contrast a predominantly dark canvas with patches of light.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this semi-historical novel, attributed to Luo Guanzhong, which casts Liu Bei as the virtuous protagonist and Cao Cao ("tsow tsow") as the power-hungry villain.
q1.raw_answer: Romance of the Three Kingdoms [or San Guo Yanyi; prompt on "ROTK"]

q2.quetsion_text: Romance of the Three Kingdoms is one of the Four Great Classical Novels of this Asian country, a group that also includes Dream of the Red Chamber and Journey to the West.
q2.raw_answer: China [or Zhongguo; or the People's Republic of China; or Zhonghua Remin Gongheguo]

q3.quetsion_text: Shortly before joining the army fighting the Yellow Turban Rebellion, Liu Bei swears an oath of brotherhood with Guan Yu and Zhang Fei in one of these specific locations.
q3.raw_answer: a peach garden [or taoyuan; or peach tree orchard; prompt on "garden" or "orchard" and accept descriptive equivalents that specify peaches]

lead_in: Carlos Chavez’s Upingos and Benjamin Britten’s Six Metamorphoses After Ovid were written for this instrument, which features prominently in the “Menuet” and “Rigaudon” sections of Ravel’s Le Tombeau de Couperin. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this woodwind instrument played by Léon Goossens, for which Mozart wrote a concerto in C major.

q2.quetsion_text: A sonata in unusual two-movement form for oboe was written in 1938 by this German composer, whose other works include a collection of fugues called Ludus Tonalis and the Symphonic Metamorphosis of Themes by Weber.

q3.quetsion_text: A cadenza-like passage for solo oboe appears during the recapitulation in the first movement of this Beethoven symphony, which opens with a famous “short-short-short-long” motif representing “Fate knocking at the door”.
q3.raw_answer: Symphony No. 5 in C minor [accept word forms and obvious equivalents like “Beethoven’s Fifth”]

lead_in: In 2005, a sizable chunk of marble from the space above the motto "Equal Justice Under Law" fell off this building

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Cass Gilbert-designed building in Washington, D.C., which is abundantly lined with Alabama marble and features, in its top level, a basketball court nicknamed "the Highest Court in the Land."

q2.quetsion_text: The Supreme Court Building is an example of this style of Neoclassical architecture that was developed at a namesake Parisian art school. It was also used for the New York Public Library and Grand Central Terminal.

q3.quetsion_text: After training at the Ecole des Beaux-Arts, William Bosworth devised a new architectural plan for this college campus, whose later landmarks include Alvar Aalto's Baker House and Eero Saarinen's Kresge Auditorium.

lead_in: This woman published a periodical called The Revolution and Lynn Sherr collected her writings in Failure is Impossible. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this pioneering suffragist who refused to pay a fine for voting in the 1872 presidential election. This close collaborator with Elizabeth Cady Stanton has since appeared on a dollar coin.

q2.quetsion_text: Anthony and Stanton campaigned unsuccessfully for women's suffrage in this state in 1867, a few years after the sack of Lawrence and the Lecompton constitution affected its prospects for statehood.

q3.quetsion_text: Two abolitionist sisters of this surname also cast illegal votes in the late 19th century. These South Carolina Quakers gave speeches about witnessing slavery firsthand on their father's plantation.
q3.raw_answer: Grimke sisters [or Sarah Moore Grimke and Angelica Grimke Weld]

lead_in: The library collected by this king included a defense of Palestrina that he wrote himself. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this king, who was raised to the throne in a revolution against Philip III. His vast empire lost Muscat and Malacca during his reign, and his daughter Catherine married Charles II of England.
q1.raw_answer: John IV [or João IV; prompt on "John" or "João"]

q2.quetsion_text: John and his daughter Catherine came from this Portuguese royal house, which ruled Portugal until 1910 and was also the only royal house of Brazil.
q2.raw_answer: [Most Serene House of] Braganza [or Sereníssima Casa de Bragança]

q3.quetsion_text: Kings of Portugal were styled monarchs of Portugal and this Portuguese coastal region south of Alentejo, whose name is derived from the Arabic for "west." It is essentially Portugal's answer to the French Riviera.

lead_in: The arrival of a German ship to this country prompted the "pajama conference" and the British decoded messages sent to this country in Room 40. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this country which Heinrich von Eckardt suggested should ally with Japan as Germany resumed unrestricted submarine warfare.

q2.quetsion_text: This 1917 message from Germany promised Mexico renewed control over Texas in exchange for entering into World War I against the United States.

q3.quetsion_text: This Mexican president, known as the Jackal, fled to Jamaica on a German cruiser, ending the fight between him and Venustiano Carranza which cost him the presidency in 1914.

lead_in: The archetype of this religious figure is often thought to be the Ugaritic hero Kothar. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Islamic religious figure, whose name is translated as "The Green One" because of a false etymology. This righteous servant of God accompanies Dhul-Qarnayn on a quest and finds the water of life.
q1.raw_answer: al-Khidr [accept Khizr or Khyzer or Qeezr or Qhizyer or Xizir or Hizir]

q2.quetsion_text: Al-Khidr is sometimes syncretized with Saint Sarkis the Warrior, an Armenian hero who held this position in the Roman army. Biblical holders of this position include the master of a servant Jesus heals at Capernaum, and Cornelius, the first gentile convert.

q3.quetsion_text: The miracle of the healing of the centurion's servant is found in both Matthew and this third and longest gospel, which, like Acts of the Apostles, is addressed to Theophilus.

lead_in: This man's fourth string quartet uses his characteristic "arch" form and his namesake kind of snap pizzicato. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Hungarian composer of six string quartets, Bluebeard's Castle, and Music for Strings, Percussion, and Celesta.

q2.quetsion_text: In Bartók's sixth string quartet, each movement begins with a slow section marked with this indication.

q3.quetsion_text: Mesto means "sadly." This other composer used the similarly depressed markings "Tenebroso" and "Largo desolato" in the last movement of his Lyric Suite for string quartet.

lead_in: News of this battle's outcome prompted more interest from the French in aiding the American Revolution, after an unexpected attack from a pre-treasonous Benedict Arnold surprised the losing side at Bemis Heights. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this battle whose first stage was fought at Freeman's Farm in upstate New York in the autumn of 1777. It stopped British plans to cut New England off from the southern states.

q2.quetsion_text: State the outcome of the battle of Saratoga in terms of the commander who won and the commander who lost.
q2.raw_answer: Horatio Gates defeated John Burgoyne [accept any answer indicating that Horatio Gates won and Burgoyne lost; prompt on answers such as "Americans defeated British"]

q3.quetsion_text: This man designed the winning fortifications at Bemis Heights during the Saratoga campaign. This engineer of the defenses at West Point left the continent after the war.

lead_in: According to this system's cosmogony, the universe originally consisted of oozy mud on the back of a trout. The god Kamui then sent a water-wagtail to create the universe from that mud. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this culture that believed that Aioina taught mankind agriculture. This culture's hirsute women may be explained by the fact that they believe themselves to be descended from a bear.
q1.raw_answer: Ainu [prompt on "indigenous (inhabitants of) Japan" or equivalents; do not accept or prompt on "Shinto"]

q2.quetsion_text: The sandals of Aioina became the first of these creatures. In Norse mythology, one of these animals named Ratatosk scampers between the branches and roots of Yggdrasil to exchange insults between a dragon and a bird.

q3.quetsion_text: In Japanese folklore, sandals can turn into monstrous bakezori, a kind of this yokai. This kind of yokai is based on inanimate objects and includes the boroboroton, a cursed futon, and the zenfusho, a haunted teapot.

lead_in: This man's alliances with the Communists forced Charles De Gaulle into a 1965 runoff and unseated Válery Giscard D'Estaing 16 years later. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this French socialist president who served two terms and left office shortly before his 1996 death.

q2.raw_answer: Observatory Affair [or L'attentat de l'Observatoire; or l'affaire de l'Observatoire]

q3.quetsion_text: Mitterrand used this numbered list of potential policies as his blueprint for a socialist France in his 1981 presidential campaign. It included a "solidarity tax on wealth" and the abolition of the death penalty.

lead_in: The Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence was founded after the perpetrator of this event paralyzed Press Secretary James Brady. For 10 points each:

q1.raw_answer: asssassination attempt on Ronald Wilson Reagan [or shooting of Ronald Wilson Reagan; accept equivalents which clearly indicate that the attempt did not succeed]

q2.quetsion_text: During a briefing with the press, this inapt phrase was used by Secretary of State Alexander Haig to describe his role in the decision-making process until Reagan returned from the hospital.
q2.raw_answer: "As of now, I am in control here, in the White House"

q3.quetsion_text: Before the shots, Reagan had just spoken to a group within this federation of organizations. It kicked out the Teamsters after George Meany and Walter Reuther negotiated to form it in the 50s.

lead_in: Name the following American short story authors, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: Horses and Men and The Triumph of the Egg are less famous collections of stories by this man, whose most enduring work is the 1919 short story cycle Winesburg, Ohio.

q2.quetsion_text: The recently-fired secretary Miss Dent threatens to kill Blake with a pistol in “The Five-Forty-Eight”, a story by this author of “The Enormous Radio” and “The Swimmer”.

q3.quetsion_text: “The Balloon” and “The Joker’s Greatest Triumph” are two of the better stories by this author of Come Back, Dr. Caligari. This co-founder of Fiction magazine collected some of his shorter “flash fiction” in Forty Stories.

lead_in: This author wrote about Monsieur Folantin, who searches for a decent meal, in his early novella With the Flow. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this writer who broke from the naturalist tradition with his novel about the decadent Jean des Essientes, À rebours, usually translated as Against Nature or Against the Grain.

q3.quetsion_text: In The Damned, Durtal is a working on a biography of this man, who supposedly conducted numerous black masses. In real life, Huysmans and Jean Benedetti wrote an actual biography of him.

lead_in: This term is defined as the heat transfer coefficient times characteristic length over thermal conductivity. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this number that characterizes a solid's heat conduction along with the Fourier number. This number is a measure of the relative importance of the resistance to heat transfer inside a body compared to at the body's surface.

q2.quetsion_text: When the Biot number is less than 0.1, thermal systems can be accurately described by a model named for this quantity's "lumped" form. Graphene has two different values of this quantity's "quantum" form, which Serge Luryi defined as fundamental charge squared times density of states in the case of a 2-D electron gas.
q2.raw_answer: capacitance [or lumped capacitance model; or quantum capacitance]

q3.quetsion_text: When the lumped capacitance model is used, Fourier's law of heat conduction simplifies to this empirical law. It states that the rate of heat loss is proportional to the temperature difference between a body and its surroundings.
q3.raw_answer: Newton's law of cooling [prompt on "Newton's law" or "law of cooling"]

lead_in: Matthew Boulton pioneered the manufacture of these devices, which were improved by James Watt. For 10 points each:

lead_in: Answer the following about geis taboos in Celtic mythology,

q1.quetsion_text: This woman, who was betrothed to Finn MacCumhaill, placed a geis upon Finn's warrior Diarmuid to force him to run away and elope with her.
