q3.quetsion_text: Finnish scholar Anti Aarne devised a classification system, later expanded by Stith Thompson, for analyzing motifs in these texts. An influential book on their “morphology” was written by Vladimir Propp.
q3.raw_answer: folktales [or fairy tales; accept obvious equivalents]

lead_in: WMAP and COBE are projects devoted to observing this entity. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this type of blackbody radiation with a temperature of approximately 2.7 Kelvin which fills the universe almost uniformly. It was created in the early universe during the era of recombination when photons became decoupled from matter as the first atoms were formed.

q2.quetsion_text: The CMBR serves as one of the main pieces of evidence for this theory popularly attributed to Fred Hoyle, which holds that the universe was formed via expansion from an infinitely dense state over 13 billion years ago.

q3.quetsion_text: The temperature of the CMBR is approximately equal to 2.725 Kelvin times one plus this parameter, symbolized z. This quantity is very high for quasars since their great distances from the Earth exacerbate the effects of the expanding universe, causing them to travel away from the Earth more quickly than less distant objects.

lead_in: The main metaphor for this condition is that of seeing oneself through the eyes of others. F

q1.quetsion_text: Name this term for an African-American person's struggle with reconciling being black with being American because the latter is defined in white cultural terms.

q2.quetsion_text: The theory of "double consciousness" appears in The Souls of Black Folk, by this African-American social thinker. His Niagara Movement opposed the conciliatory approach of Booker T. Washington.
q2.raw_answer: W.E.B. DuBois [or William Edward Burghardt DuBois]

q3.quetsion_text: DuBois's Black Reconstruction in America attacks the work of this Columbia University historian, whose namesake school characterized Reconstruction as an attempt by Radical Republicans to subjugate the South.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Gestalt psychologist best known for studying how masses adopt incorrect opinions in his namesake conformity experiment.

q2.quetsion_text: Asch also examined how perception of this type of media is affected by its credited source. This form of media is used to influence populations, often for nefarious purposes, and includes Uncle Sam posters and the Nazi film Triumph of the Will.

q3.quetsion_text: Asch's studies of how statements like "he is hot" and "she is cold" affect our perception of others led him to examine the ubiquity of this figure of speech. George Lakoff argued that cognitive forms of this figure of speech are necessary for understanding the inner workings of the mind.

lead_in: Angels with progressively darker colors and yellow banners with inscriptions accompany the title events of this altarpiece in chronological order from left to right. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this triptych, now held in Antwerp, with a middle scene depicting a large crucifixion above the Eucharist. It employs dramatic linear perspective to give the illusion of depth to its setting, the interior of a cathedral.

q2.quetsion_text: The Seven Sacraments Altarpiece is a masterwork by this early Flemish artist, who showed the body of Christ being lowered in his Descent from the Cross.
q2.raw_answer: Rogier Van Der Weyden [or Roger de la Pasture]

q3.quetsion_text: Van der Weyden created this triptych as a memorial for Jehan of Tournai. The landscape in the background is continuous across panels depicting John the Baptist, Jesus with Mary and John, and Mary Magdalene.
q3.raw_answer: The Braque Triptych [or The Braque Family Triptych]

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Naturalist English author of The Odd Women and The Nether World. Another novel by this author contrasts the lives of the writers Jasper Milvain and Edward Reardon.

q3.quetsion_text: While living in Italy, Gissing published a critical study of the works of this author of Hard Times and David Copperfield.

lead_in: This data structure contains an entry for a piece of data and a reference to another node for the next piece of data. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this data structure that is often used to implement stacks and queues.

q2.quetsion_text: The reference to another node in a linked list is typically of this data type, whose value is an address in memory. A very common Java exception named for the "null" type of them often occurs when you declare a variable, but do not create an object before dereferencing it.

q3.quetsion_text: Linked lists may have these empty nodes at their ends in order to reduce off by one errors.

lead_in: This collection was published in 1610 with a six-voice Missa in illo tempore. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this collection of sacred concertos and other pieces for the title evening service. It ends with a lengthy Magnificat for seven voices.
q1.raw_answer: 1610 Vespers, SV 206 [accept either underlined part; or Vespers of the Blessed Virgin; or Vespro della Beata Vergine da concerto, composto sopra canti fermi]

q2.quetsion_text: The 1610 Vespers were composed by this Italian, who wrote innovative madrigals like "Cruda Amarilli," as well as Il combattimento di Tancredi e Clorinda. He also wrote the operas L'incoronazione di Poppea and L'Orfeo.

q3.quetsion_text: The penultimate movement of Monteverdi's Vespers is a setting of this Marian hymn. Its title draws an appropriate parallel between Mary's name and the Latin word for "sea."
q3.raw_answer: Ave, maris stella [or Hail, star of the sea]

lead_in: This man's father is described as "A true Hidalgo, free from every stain / Of Moor or Hebrew blood" and he survives a shipwreck where he is nursed back to good health by HaidÃ©e. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this hero of an epic poem, who ruins Alfonso and Julia's marriage when he's discovered in Julia's bedroom.
q1.raw_answer: Don Juan [pronounced "joo-an" but any reasonable pronunciation is fine]

q2.quetsion_text: Don Juan was written by this British poet of Childe Harold's Pilgrimage. He described a "heart whose love is innocent" in his poem "She Walks in Beauty".
q2.raw_answer: George Gordon, Lord Byron [accept either underlined answer; or George Gordon Noel, 6th Baron Byron]

q3.quetsion_text: Don Juan is mockingly dedicated to this Lake poet, who is sarcastically dubbed an "Epic Renegade" who "turn'd out a Tory at last". This author of the anti-war poem "After Blenheim" also wrote Madoc and Thalaba the Destroyer.

lead_in: Graves states that she was the most terrible of a certain triad and personified Crone, the autumnal aspect of a triple goddess. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this goddess, who cut the thread spun out by her sister Clotho, and measured by her sister Lachesis.

q2.quetsion_text: Atropos, Clotho and Lachesis are the three women who make up this mythological triad, who ruled over destiny.

q3.quetsion_text: This other goddess of fate was a tutelary deity that Greeks used to personify luck. She was sometimes syncretized with Nemesis, and her Roman counterpart was Fortuna.

lead_in: These people were accused of being guilty of the three sins of perjury, rebellion, and blasphemy, in a text arguing that people should hunt them down for the same reasons one would hunt a mad dog. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these people whom Martin Luther accused of forming "murderous, thieving hordes" during a namesake war that culminated at the Battle of Frankenhausen.
q1.raw_answer: peasants [or bawren; accept Peasants' War or Bauernkrieg; accept no other answers]

q2.quetsion_text: Luther felt that the rebelling German peasants had erred by using his spiritual teachings to guide their drafting of the Twelve Articles against this league, which won at Frankenhausen.
q2.raw_answer: Swabian League [or Schwäbischer Bund; accept word forms of Swabia]

q3.quetsion_text: Luther's eyes were opened to the peasants' capacity for murder and thievery during a tour of this German region, whose city of Mühlhausen was the home of peasant leader Thomas Müntzer.

lead_in: This term, which was coined by Gustav Bergmann, describes the movement toward analytic philosophy in the mid-20th century. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this term often applied to the consideration of the ways that language constitutes reality.

q2.quetsion_text: The anthology The Linguistic Turn was edited by this American philosopher, who wrote Contingency, Irony, and Solidarity and Philosophy and the Mirror of Nature.

q3.quetsion_text: Rorty's essay "The World Well Lost" critiques Donald Davidson's formulation that one must assume that other speakers hold true beliefs in order to maximize agreement, a principle given this name.
q3.raw_answer: principle of charity [or principle of rational accommodation]

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this economist who argued that long-term macroeconomic stability tends to heighten the risk of instability during crises, as part of his financial instability hypothesis.

q2.quetsion_text: Similarly to Minsky, this school of economics argues that macroeconomic booms and busts are generally produced by monetary phenomena. Proponents of this school include Ludwig von Mises and Friedrich Hayek.

q3.quetsion_text: In Austrian economic theory, this value coordinates production across time and reflects the time-preference of individuals. Varieties of this value are calculated using the Fisher equation.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this very large protein consisting of two heavy and two light chains, which forms intermolecular disulfide bonds, aggregating into pentamers. It is produced in the immediate response to an antigen.
q1.raw_answer: IgM [or Immunoglobulin M; prompt on "immunoglobulin" or "antibody"]

q2.quetsion_text: IgM is the largest isotype of these Y-shaped proteins produced by B cells, which specifically recognize and bind to antigens.

q3.quetsion_text: IgM turning up in an ELISA for this disease, which is part of the TORCH complex, indicates recent infection. Patent ductus arteriosus and "blueberry muffin" skin lesions appear in babies with the congenital form of this disease, which you don't have because you were given the MMR vaccine. . . right?
q3.raw_answer: rubella [or German measles; or three-day measles; for the love of God, do NOT accept or prompt on "measles"]

lead_in: These molecules can be purified in minipreps which often employ alkaline lysis to destroy the cells containing them followed by centrifugation and removal of the supernatant. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these pieces of circular DNA often found in bacteria. They can be transferred between cells in transformation and conjugation.

q2.quetsion_text: During conjugation, DNA replication proceeds through this mechanism in which a nick is made in one of the circular strands, then DNA polymerase pushes the nicked strand off of the unnicked strand as it synthesizes a new strand.

q3.quetsion_text: F plasmids are transferred through the “sex” form of this structure which is found on the surface of bacteria that engage in conjugation.

lead_in: Most of the text on this artifact refers to its namesake's conquest of Libya, and controversy exists regarding the interpretation of its most famous line. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this stele that has the first non-Biblical reference to Israel in the phrase "Israel is laid to waste, its seed is not." It was built to celebrate the victories of Rameses II's successor.

q2.quetsion_text: The Merneptah stele was discovered by this Egyptologist, who made early contributions on contextual seriation techniques for dating archaeological finds. He also excavated the Royal Palace and the Great Temple of Aten in the city of Amarna.

q3.quetsion_text: Flinders Petrie also excavated several encaustic portraits found at a burial site in this city that were created contemporaneously to Roman rule over Egypt. This city stands over the ancient site of Crocodilopolis.
q3.raw_answer: Fayyum [or Phiom; or Faiyum; accept Fayyum portraiture or equivalents]

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this woman who catches a "bitter allusion to the sea" and spaces out while a man is addressing her, thinking instead about enormous beds and perfumes in France.
q1.raw_answer: the Dover Bitch (prompt on the addressee of "Dover Beach," prompt on Matthew Arnold's wife, lover, girlfriend, etc.)

q2.quetsion_text: This American poet whose "The Transparent Man" is narrated by a woman dying of leukemia also wrote "The Dover Bitch."

q3.quetsion_text: Hecht's poem "More Light! More Light!", in which a Pole is forced to dig a grave for himself and two Jews, focuses on the atrocities of this event. Yevgeny Yevtushenko's "Babi Yar" also memorializes victims of this event.
q3.raw_answer: the Holocaust (or the Shoah; prompt on "World War II")

lead_in: DELLA proteins regulate the transcription of enzymes that synthesize these compounds. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this class of diterpenoid plant hormones which, like auxins, induce stem elongation. They also stimulate seed germination and cause uncharacteristically rapid growth of rice seedlings.

q2.quetsion_text: Gibberellins also stimulate the secretion of this enzyme, which hydrolyzes starch. This enzyme is present in saliva and breaks down carbohydrates into simple monosaccharides.

q3.quetsion_text: Synthesis of gibberellins requires the mevalonate pathway, which uses this metabolite as its starting material. This thioester is formed from the beta-oxidation of fatty acids, and also from the decarboxylation of pyruvate

lead_in: This ethical thought experiment was proposed by Philippa Foot in 1967. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this conundrum in which inaction leads to the death of five people by a certain type of vehicle, but action leads to the death of only one.

q2.quetsion_text: This ethical doctrine, which is first found in Aquinas, roughly states that it is sometimes permissible to bring about, as a foreseeable secondary result, an action that would be impermissible to intentionally bring about directly. Foot applied it to the abortion debate in a 1967 paper.

q3.quetsion_text: This American philosopher proposed the "fat man" version of the trolley problem and used the "unconscious violinist" thought experiment to defend abortion in "A Defense of Abortion."
q3.raw_answer: Judith Jarvis Thomson [accept either underlined name]

lead_in: Identify the following things about Mozart's operas, for 10 points each

q1.quetsion_text: This title character, a notorious rake, kills the Commendatore in a duel but is later dragged to hell by a statue of that man. His many conquests are outlined by his servant Leporello in the "Catalog Aria".

q2.quetsion_text: Emperor Joseph II supposedly claimed that there were "too many notes" in this Mozart opera, in which Belmonte rescues his beloved Konstanze from the harem of Pasha Selim.
q2.raw_answer: The Abduction from the Seraglio [or Die EntfÃ¼hrung aus dem Serail; or K.384]

q3.quetsion_text: This aria from The Magic Flute requires the soprano playing the Queen of the Night to hit a high F6. In it, the Queen orders Pamina to assassinate her rival Sarastro.
q3.raw_answer: "Der HÃ¶lle Rache kocht in meinem Herzen" [or "Hell's vengeance boils in my heart"; prompt on "the Queen of the Night's aria"]

lead_in: This house formed the royal house of Piedmont-Sardinia and then Italy after its member, Victor Emmanuel II, was crowned king.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this house, whose member Eugene served as a general for the Austro-Hungarian Empire.

q2.quetsion_text: At this 1697 battle, Eugene of Savoy led a surprise attack on an Ottoman force attempting to cross the Tisza river. The result was a rout in which the Austrians inflicted over 30,000 casualties on the Ottomans.
q2.raw_answer: Battle of Zenta [or Battle of Senta ]

q3.quetsion_text: The Ottomans signed this 1699 treaty with the Habsburg empire two years after being routed at Zenta. This treaty signed over large parts of Hungary and Serbia to Austria, and Dalmatia to Venice.

lead_in: Good news everyone! We'll be delivering a package to Chapek 9, a world where humans are killed on sight. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: To get there, we'll be making frequent use of this equation that sets the delta-v of a maneuver equal to "effective exhaust velocity times the natural log of initial mass over final mass."
q1.raw_answer: ideal rocket equation [or Tsiolkovsky rocket equation]

q2.quetsion_text: We'll also be making use of this most efficient way to transfer from a lower orbit to a higher one, or vice versa. We'll wait for the right launch window so that this elliptical transfer orbit will intersect with Chapek 9's orbit around its sun.

q3.quetsion_text: In order to haul ass out of Chapek 9, we use this kind of rocket nozzle to exhaust fuel at supersonic velocities. This type of nozzle is hourglass shaped and is usually named for its Swedish inventor.
q3.raw_answer: de Laval nozzle [or convergent-divergent nozzle; or CD nozzle]

lead_in: This building received its current nickname because local Bedouins supposedly hoped to earn riches by shooting its urns. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Give the common name of this building carved into sandstone, which is depicted towards the end of Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade as an ancient temple. Solomon's Temple in Assassin's Creed may be modeled after this building.

q2.quetsion_text: The Treasury is found in this Jordanian ruined city carved out of stone, which can be accessed through the siq to see the Monastery, the Temple of the Winged Lions and other marvels.

q3.quetsion_text: This ancient North Arabian people constructed Petra as the capital of their kingdom, which encompassed Hegra and Damascus at its height. This people's name is thought to mean "the men who dig for water."
q3.raw_answer: Nabataeans [or Nabatae; or Nabatu; or al-Anbat]

lead_in: In The Brothers Karamazov, Fyodor compares himself and his sons Dmitri and Ivan to the central family of this 1781 play.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this play in which the schemes of Franz Moor cause the banishment of his brother Karl, who becomes a leader of a group of outlaws.

q2.quetsion_text: The Robbers is a play by this German author of Intrigue and Love, the Wallenstein trilogy, and William Tell. He wrote about a "daughter of Elysium" in his poem "Ode to Joy".
q2.raw_answer: Friedrich Schiller [or Johann Christoph Friedrich von Schiller]

q3.quetsion_text: This Schiller play, whose similarities to Star Wars were described by Jeffrey L. High, is a historical drama about a character whose obsessive love for Elizabeth of Valois is complicated when his father, King Philip II, marries her.
q3.raw_answer: Don Carlos, Prince of Spain [or Don Karlos, Infant von Spanien]

lead_in: This region's variety of Spanish became the standard variety spoken throughout the later Spanish Empire, instead of Leonese or other dialects.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this medieval kingdom, which was united with neighboring Aragon into Spain through the marriage of Ferdinand and Isabella.

q2.quetsion_text: This ruler of Castile was opposed in an election for Holy Roman Emperor by Richard of Cornwall. This scientifically-minded king sponsored the creation of a number of astronomical tables.
q2.raw_answer: Alfonso X [or Alfonso the Wise; or Alfonso el Sabio; prompt on "Alfonso"]

q3.quetsion_text: This powerful association of sheep herders was granted numerous caÃ±adas by the kings of Castile. This organization's name originates from the mixing of animals at gatherings of medieval notables.

lead_in: This man’s relationship with Mamah Borthwick ended when she was killed by an axe-wielding servant from Barbados. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this man who proposed a garden city like model called “Broadacre City,” in which each family would be given one acre of land. That model was financed by his patron Edgar Kaufmann.

q2.quetsion_text: Wright designed the Imperial Hotel in this Japanese city. The structure survived the 1923 Kanto earthquake.

q3.quetsion_text: The aforementioned lunatic servant murdered Borthwick while setting fire to this Wisconsin estate of Wright, which has a mythological name. Wright would rebuild it, and also have a “western” equivalent to it built in Scottsdale, Arizona.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: One of these people authored a grain law that allowed for the sale of state grain to citizens at a subsidized rate. That member of this pair of reformers committed suicide after protesting the election of Lucius Opimius, while his brother was murdered by a mob.
q1.raw_answer: Gracchus brothers (accept Gracchi or Tiberius and Gaius Gracchus)

q2.quetsion_text: This Republic politician turned the state-run grain sale to commoners, the annona, into a free grain dole. Cicero notably defended Milo from accusations of having murdered this man on the Appian way.

q3.quetsion_text: Later, this emperor replaced the grain dole with the distribution of bread, wine, and pork. His military accomplishments include defeating the Juthungi and Alemanni at the Battle of Fano.
q3.raw_answer: Aurelian (or Lucius Domitius Aurelianus Augustus, do not accept anything involving "Aurelius")

lead_in: In a political cartoon, this man rides an elephant over such Liberals as Alexander Mackenzie. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Conservative Prime Minister of Canada, the first in that country’s history. He put down the Red River Rebellion and left his first term shortly after the Pacific scandal.

q2.quetsion_text: The Pacific scandal dealt with financing this mode of transportation in Canada. In the United States, examples of this transportation system included the Union and Central Pacific.

q3.quetsion_text: The Red River Rebellion was an uprising led by Louis Riel, the leader of this indigenous Canadian people. Under Riel, they also fought in the North West Rebellion.

lead_in: It’s time for the most beloved MUT tradition of all. If you can identify these geographical entities from Pokemon clues, you get 10 points each; if you need more academic clues, you get 5.

q1.quetsion_text: In Pokemon X and Y, the Lumiose City Gym, where the player fights Clemont and his electric Pokemon, is based on this real-world landmark.
q1.raw_answer: the Eiffel Tower [or la Tour Eiffel]

q2.quetsion_text: This real-world Japanese city served as the basis for Gold and Silver’s Ecruteak City, which is home to two temples: the silver-colored Tin Tower and a gold-colored Brass Tower, the latter of which burned down.

q3.raw_answer: Guyana [or the Cooperative Republic of Guyana]

lead_in: A crab was sent to distract Heracles during the slaying of this creature. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this multi-headed monster in Lerna. Every time one of its heads would be chopped off, two more would grow in its place.

q2.quetsion_text: This other multi-headed monster from Greek myth was a two-headed dog. that was the son of Echidna. This son of Echidna was killed by Heracles when he was stealing the cattle of the island of Erytheia.

lead_in: This Dissenter promoted religious toleration with his Remarks on Blackstone's Commentaries.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this English scientist who discovered what he called "dephlogisticated air", but refused to accept the chemical revolution and reject phlogiston theory

lead_in: The most recent edition of this book combined a series of diagnoses into "Autism Spectrum Disorder". For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this book produced by the American Psychiatric Association that is used in the US to classify mental illnesses.
q1.raw_answer: DSM-5 [or Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders, Fifth Edition]

q2.quetsion_text: The DSM-5 also eliminated the "bereavement exclusion" for this common mental disorder, characterized by sadness, despair, and lethargy. This condition often treated with drugs like Zoloft and Prozac.
q2.raw_answer: depression [or clinical depression; or unipolar depression; or major depressive disorder; or MDD]

q3.quetsion_text: Milder cases of depression are often treated with this form of talk therapy that combines the work of Aaron Beck and Albert Ellis. This form of therapy is goal-oriented and focuses on eliminating maladaptive actions and patterns.

lead_in: This play's dramatis personae include an un-jolly fellow who purchases Lives of the Great Poisoners so that he can kill his unenviable wife Mrs. Pugh. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this drama whose characters include the frightening cobbler Jack Black, and the music loving Organ Morgan. Captain Cat begins this play by dreaming of his lost men.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this caliphate that supplanted the Umayyads. Its capital at Baghdad featured a library called the House of Wisdom.

lead_in: This poem's final stanza opens by discussing how the word forlorn is "like a bell" that tolls the speakerfrom the title figure back to himself. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this poem, dedicated to a "light-winged Dryad of the trees," which opens "My heart aches, and a drowsy numbness pains / my sense, as though of hemlock I had drunk."

q3.raw_answer: "Silence and slow Time" [prompt if only one answer is given]

lead_in: Until 2002, the Al Faisaliyah Center was the tallest building in this city. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this city, which is home to the historic Masmak fort and is the most populous city in Saudi Arabia.

q2.quetsion_text: This building has been the tallest in Riyadh since it opened in 2002. At nearly one thousand feet high, this building features an upside-down parabolic hole in its upper half.

q3.quetsion_text: The under-construction Kingdom Tower in this Saudi city was originally planned to be one mile tall. Located on the Red Sea, this city's airport features the Hajj Terminal, an enormous facility that helps this city's role as the primary port of entry for Muslim pilgrims.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this lengthy poem detailing the events of 1665 to 1666, written while its author was in western Britain attempting to escape the Great Plague of London.

q2.quetsion_text: Annus Mirabilis was written by this English poet and dramatist of Absalom and Achitophel and MacFlecknoe.

q3.quetsion_text: Dryden wrote this ode for St. Cecilia's Day commemorating an event in Persepolis following the titular character's defeat of Darius. It was adapted into a choral work by Handel.
q3.raw_answer: Alexander's Feast, or the Power of Music

lead_in: Locke claimed this process should encourage physical health, sound moral character, and critical thinking skills and shy away from false tales of “goblins and sprites”. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this term for the process of learning, often directed by authority figures like parents and teachers.

q2.quetsion_text: In “Some Thoughts Concerning Education”, Locke examined how to instill proper thoughts in a mind that in this work, which distinguishes between simple and complex ideas.

q3.quetsion_text: This Persian Islamic thinker also described the learning process in a work that described the two phases of an ideal maktab education. He also wrote the philosophical encyclopedia The Book of Healing.
q3.raw_answer: Avicenna [or Ibn Sina; or Pur Sina; or Pur-e Sina; or Son of Sina; or Abū ʿAlī al-Ḥusayn ibn ʿAbd Allāh ibn Sīnā]

lead_in: A smashed tomato lies on the ground next to a wall which also displays part of a racial slur in the background of this painting. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this 1964 painting which depicts Ruby Bridges being led to school by four U.S. marshals.
q1.raw_answer: The Problem We All Live With

q2.quetsion_text: The Problem We All Live With is a work of this American painter and illustrator, who created works such as Saying Grace and the Willie Gillis series for the Saturday Evening Post.

q3.quetsion_text: An old woman places a huge turkey on a crowded dinner table in the most famous of this series of Rockwell paintings, which depict the essential human rights laid out in FDR's 1941 State of the Union address.

lead_in: In this play, a former judge serves as the butler of a woman he had sentenced to prostitution. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this drama in which a billionaire woman, the gangsters Toby and Roby, the blind eunuchs Koby and Loby, her butler Boby, and her seventh husband Moby go to the town of Güllen.
q1.raw_answer: The Visit [or Der Besuch der alten Dame]

q2.quetsion_text: This author wrote about Claire and the town of Güllen in his tragicomedy The Visit. He also wrote about a mental asylum operated by Mathilde von Zahnd in his play The Physicists.

q3.quetsion_text: Dürrenmatt wrote this "Requiem for the Detective Novel" in which The Kommandant relates the tale of the brilliant investigator Matthäi, who falls into an alcohol-fueled state of despair after he fails to find the true murderer of a little girl.

lead_in: “Conversation” Kenge, Mr. Vholes, and Mr. Tulkinghorn represent the various parties in this case, which involves a will that may benefit Lady Dedlock, Richard Carstone, or the guardian of Esther Summerson. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this fictional court case, created to mock the inefficiencies of the Chancery court, from the novel Bleak House.
q1.raw_answer: Jarndyce v Jarndyce [or Jarndyce and Jarndyce]

q2.quetsion_text: Bleak House was written by this prolific English author who serialized his own novel Hard Times in his magazine Household Words. He also wrote Oliver Twist.

q3.quetsion_text: In Bleak House, the paper-hoarding landlord Mr. Krook dies in this fashion. This fate also befalls the father of Clara and Theodore Wieland in Charles Brockden Brown’s first novel.
q3.raw_answer: spontaneous human combustion [accept word forms; prompt on “fire” or equivalents but don’t accept things like “self-immolation” that imply agency on the part of the immolated]

lead_in: This philosopher argued that evil is the ground that teaches man the difference between good and evil and is necessary for the development of perfection. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this German philosopher who distinguished between God's aspects of perfection and the ground of being in his book Philosophical Enquiries into the Nature of Human Freedom.

q2.quetsion_text: Several of Schelling's titles make reference to this German term that now refers to the German romantic idealist conceptions of the natural sciences held by Schelling and his contemporaries.

q3.quetsion_text: This contemporary thinker lambasted Schelling's definition of absolute knowledge as similar to a night "in which all cows are black" in his Phenomenology of Spirit.

lead_in: Name the following works of Edmund Spenser,

q1.quetsion_text: Britomart rescues Artegal from Radigund and Una marries the dragon-slaying Redcrosse Knight, who is revealed to be Saint George, in this incomplete epic written in praise of Queen Elizabeth I.

q2.quetsion_text: Spenser borrowed John Skelton's rustic character Colin Clout to serve as the main character of this collection of twelve eclogues, his first major poetic work.
q2.raw_answer: The Shepheardes Calender [or The Shepherd's Calendar]

q3.quetsion_text: Spenser's sonnet cycle Amoretti is usually accompanied by this "song made in lieu of many ornaments", a poem chronicling the day of his wedding to Elizabeth Boyle.

lead_in: Two men from this place carried out an attack in which the police officer Leslie Coffelt was killed. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this island whose independence was sought by Oscar Collazo and Griselio Torresola, two men who attempted to kill Harry Truman at the Blair House in 1950.
q1.raw_answer: [Commonwealth of] Puerto Rico [or Estado Libre Asociado de Puerto Rico]

q2.quetsion_text: In 1954, Puerto Rican nationalists shot 30 semi-automatic pistol rounds from the Ladies' Gallery in this building to protest U.S. occupation.

q3.quetsion_text: This Marxist Puerto Rican separatist organization, a forerunner of the Boricua Popular Army, was responsible for numerous bombings, including a January 1975 Wall Street bombing that killed four people.
q3.raw_answer: FALN [or Fuerzas Armadas de Liberación Nacional; or reasonable translations such as Armed Forces of National Liberation]

lead_in: This novel's protagonist disapproves of Barbro, a woman who joins the Salvation Army, and in an early chapter, its protagonist sells a copper mine to the local sheriff. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this novel by Knut Hamsun that focuses on Isak's and Inger's attempts to cultivate their farm Sellanrå.
q1.raw_answer: The Growth of the Soil [or Markens Grode]

q2.quetsion_text: Early on, Inger is sent to jail because she murders her own child, who has this condition.

q3.quetsion_text: In Hamsun's memoir On Overgrown Paths, he defends himself from critics who accused him of being insane after he gave a eulogy for this man. He inadvertently achieves YouTube fame as a satirist after waking up in 2011 in Timur Verme's novel He's Back Again.

lead_in: One print by this man shows women making floss silk, the title Evening Snow on the Heater. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this 18th-century Japanese creator of the Parlor Views series. He popularized the full-color nishiki-e printmaking technique and was an important predecessor of later printmakers like Hiroshige and Hokusai.

q2.quetsion_text: Harunobu's Parlor Views series contains this number of prints. A popular theme in Asian art is to create this number of scenes of a certain area, such as the Views of Xiaoxiang series.

lead_in: In this play, Mr. Organ Morgan is obsessed with his music to the annoyance of his wife, and Captain Cat dreams of his dead crew members.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this radio play by Dylan Thomas, set in the fictional Welsh village of Llareggub.

q2.quetsion_text: Edward and Flora are visited by a Matchseller in this English dramatist's radio play A Slight Ache. The hit-men Ben and Gus receive mysterious food orders from the title object in his The Dumb Waiter.

q3.quetsion_text: This English writer of dark comedies first came to prominence with the radio play The Ruffian on the Stair. Dr. Rance's inspection of Dr. Prentice's psychiatric hospital goes horribly astray in his play What the Butler Saw.

lead_in: This poem includes a hunter "in habit for the chase arrayed" among the lively dead.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this poem by Philip Freneau in which the narrator observes an exception to his usual rule that "the posture that we give the dead points out the soul's eternal sleep."

q2.quetsion_text: Margaret Fuller Slack and Jonathan Swift Somers are among the dead who narrate first-person accounts of their lives from a cemetery in the title Midwestern town of this 1915 poetry collection. Its opening poem notes that "All, all are sleeping on the hill".

q3.quetsion_text: In Spoon River Anthology, Ann Rutledge claims to be "beloved in life" of this American president, who is the subject of Walt Whitman's "O Captain! My Captain!"

lead_in: A character in this film is described to be “the kindest, bravest, warmest most wonderful human being I’ve ever known in my life.” For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this 1962 movie in which veteran Raymond Shaw is revealed to have been brainwashed by the Chinese into becoming an assassin, with his own mother as his Communist handler.

q2.quetsion_text: In the film, Shaw’s brainwashing is triggered when he sees this playing card, which the villains prompt Shaw into seeing by encouraging him to play solitaire.
q2.raw_answer: queen of diamonds [prompt on partial answer]

q3.quetsion_text: In the film, Shaw is a veteran of this war, which is also the subject of such movies as Pork Chop Hill and The Bridges at Toko-Ri, as well as Robert Altman’s film M*A*S*H.

lead_in: The Soviet government attempted to retitle this opera Hammer and Sickle, and it was originally known by the name of its protagonist, Ivan Susanin. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this earliest Russian-language opera in the repertoire, whose plot involves Susanin saving Mikhail Romanov by leading an opposing army astray.
q1.raw_answer: A Life for the Tsar [or Zhiznza tsarya]

q2.quetsion_text: A Life for the Tsar was composed by this man, who also wrote the opera Ruslan and Lyudmila.

q3.quetsion_text: The army seeking out Mikhail in A Life for the Tsar represents this country, whose native-born composers include Henryk Gorecki (gore-ET-ski) and Krzysztof Penderecki (pen-der-ET-ski).

lead_in: The creator of this theory separated it from other theories of language with its emphasis on characterizing language first from the Saussurian paradigmatic axis, rather than the syntagmatic axis. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this theory of linguistics, which asserts that language is a multidimensional, social, semiotic network, and that user participation in a language operates on the basis of choice. It was developed by Michael Halliday.
q1.raw_answer: systemic functional linguistics [or systemic functional grammar; or systemic functionalism; prompt on "SFL" or "functional(ism)"; do not accept other, more specific types of functionalism]

q2.quetsion_text: Halliday and his wife, Ruqaiya Hasan, wrote a book titled for cohesion in this language, whose "social stratification in New York" and dialects on Martha's Vineyard were the subjects of studies by William Labov.

q3.quetsion_text: The Sound Pattern of English is a phonological study by Noam Chomsky and this now-90-year-old Latvian-American linguist, who also authored a paper "On Accent and Juncture in English" with Chomsky and Fred Lukoff.
q3.raw_answer: Morris Halle [accept Morris Pinkowitz or Pinkovics]

lead_in: A man looks out a window as the rest of his family grieves the loss of a dying girl, in a really early artwork by Henry Peach Robinson that was made using this technique and is titled Fading Away.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this photographic technique pioneered by Berlin-based artists such as Hannah Hoch and Kurt Schwitters, in which positives and negatives from different sources are printed on a single piece of printing paper

q3.quetsion_text: This pseudonymous Dada/surrealist/weird artist produced a photomontage of Picasso's lover Dora Maar, and photographed Marcel Duchamp in drag as his alter-ego Rrose Selavy.

lead_in: The wasps at the top right of this painting may be a reference to the symbol of the house of Simonetta Vespucci, with whom the artist was deeply infatuated.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this painting in which satyrs play with the helmet and lance of one of the title deities, who is in a state of blissful post-coital slumber.
q1.raw_answer: Mars and Venus [or Venus and Mars]

q2.quetsion_text: This Renaissance painter of Mars and Venus signed his name and included twelve angels and other bits of unusual iconography in his Mystical Nativity. He also enthusiastically participated in the Bonfire of the Vanities.
q2.raw_answer: Sandro Botticelli [or Alessandro di Mariano di Vanni Filipepi]

q3.quetsion_text: Mercury picks fruit, Zephryus abducts Chloris, and the Three Graces dance in a circle in this spring-themed canvas by Botticelli.

lead_in: With Hilary Putnam, this philosopher names an indispensability thesis which suggests that we must be intellectually committed to the existence of mathematical entities, such as numbers.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this analytic philosopher who introduced his idea of the "indeterminacy of translation" in his book Word and Object.
q1.raw_answer: W.V.O. Quine [or Willard Van Orman Quine]

q2.quetsion_text: Both "Two Dogmas of Empiricism" and Word and Object support this philosophical position that the meaning of any proposition in a language can only be understood through its relation to the entire language.
q2.raw_answer: semantic holism [or meaning holism; or linguistic holism]

q3.quetsion_text: Quine's book Mathematical Logic condensed many of the ideas of Principia Mathemathica, which was written by Alfred North Whitehead and this English philosopher, who wrote "On Denoting".
q3.raw_answer: Bertrand Russell [or Bertrand Arthur William Russell]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this abstract expressionist who used oils to evoke watercolors in 1952's Mountains and Sea.

q3.quetsion_text: This other abstract expressionist painted pieces like Pink Landscape and Pink Angels. A bikini-clad entry in his Woman series was quietly removed from Iran following the 1979 Revolution.

lead_in: One equation describing this process assumes that only monolayers are formed, and that surfaces on which this process occurs are uniform. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this process whose extent is related to the partial pressures of the gas undergoing this process in an isotherm named for Irving Langmuir.

q2.quetsion_text: This regime, which is characterized by pressures as low as ten-to-the-negative-nine torr, significantly increases the mean-free-path of particles. Achieving this regime has been central to the Nobel-winning surface chemistry work of Gerhard Ertl.

q3.quetsion_text: In the UHV-assisted photon traps of Haroche et al., photons interact with gigantic atoms known by this name. These atoms have principal quantum number as high as 50, and high orbital quantum numbers, and their relaxation times are on the order of seconds, making them ideal systems for study.

lead_in: Helga Brandt and the Ronald Rich-portrayed bodyguard Hans both fall into a pool of piranhas in this film, whose protagonist works with Tiger Tanaka and stages a marriage with Kissy Suzuki. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this 1967 film whose title is spoken when Donald Pleasence, playing Ernst Stavro Blofeld, comments on James Bond’s having earlier faked his death in Hong Kong.

q2.quetsion_text: In You Only Live Twice and the four films preceding it, Bond was played by this Scottish actor, whose other roles include the defecting Soviet captain Ramius in The Hunt for Red October and Indiana Jones’s father.
q2.raw_answer: Sean Connery [or Thomas Sean Connery; please respond to incompetent faux-Connery accents with disdain]

q3.quetsion_text: Charles Gray, who plays Bond’s contact Henderson in You Only Live Twice, appeared as Blofeld in this campy Bond film, which features the gay assassins Wint and Kidd, a moon buggy chase, and a plot to build a huge laser.

lead_in: Frederick Powicke wrote a six-volume study of this group, which included Anne Conway, who proposed the concept of the monad in her book Principles of the Most Ancient and Modern Philosophy. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these philosophers, who believed that the laws of the natural universe were in harmony with the will of God according to the "plastic nature" of mankind.

q2.quetsion_text: The Cambridge Platonists were led by Ralph Cudworth and this man, who apparently believed that he was endowed with knowledge of God after he realized that his purple excrement resembled that of the thaumaturgist Valentine Greatrakes. He outlined the hylarchic principle in such works as On the Immortality of the Soul.

q3.quetsion_text: Henry More synthesized the thought of Plato with the thought of this French dualist, whose ideas on the soul are described in The Passions of the Soul.

lead_in: The title object of this story was created by the one-eyed Petrovich.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this story in which the clerk Akaky Akakievich saves up money for the title object, which is stolen by muggers on his way home from a party.

q2.quetsion_text: The Overcoat is by this Ukrainian writer, who wrote of Chichikhov buying up the rights to deceased serfs in his unfinished novel Dead Souls .

q3.quetsion_text: In 1996, this renowned husband-and-wife translating team produced a version of Gogol's Dead Souls . Their 2002 version of Tolstoy's Anna Karenina won the PEN Translation Prize.

lead_in: This religious term is often used as a general name for unquestioningly accepted principles.

q1.quetsion_text: Name these articles of faith revealed by God, which are binding upon faithful Catholics. No statement from the Second Vatican Council has this designation.

q2.quetsion_text: This document, also known as the Dogmatic Constitution of the Church, was approved at Vatican II by an overwhelming majority of bishops. This document declares in its second chapter that the Church is "the People of God."
q2.raw_answer: Lumen Gentium [or The Light of the Nations]

q3.quetsion_text: This figure is given the title "Mediatrix" by Lumen Gentium. Pius XII defined dogma regarding this figure ex cathedra in the apostolic constitution, Munificentissimus Deus.

lead_in: This group was a pioneer in the use of vocoders in music, and they used an Orchestron to produce choir-like sounds for their 1975 album Radioactive. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this winner of a 2014 Lifetime Achievement Grammy, a German electronic music band that was founded in the early 1970s. Their "Robot Pop" tunes include the 22-minute long "Autobahn."

q2.quetsion_text: This London museum's ticketing system went down in 2013 soon after they started selling tickets to a Kraftwerk show. This art gallery is located in what used to be the Bankside power station.

q3.quetsion_text: This large gallery of the Tate Modern annually houses notable exhibitions like Ai Weiwei's Sunflower Seeds and Rachel Whiteread's EMBANKMENT. This hall was inaugurated with Louise Bourgeois's I Do, I Undo, I Redo series and has also housed Anish Kapoor's massive Marsyas.

lead_in: A major theorist of this movement, Max Nordau, decried the physical weakness of his compatriots in an address calling for a new, "muscular" version of its adherents. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this movement that underwent a key directional shift in the Biltmore Program. Its Revisionist branch was led by Vladimir Jabotinsky, who opposed the Uganda plan.

q2.quetsion_text: This Austro-Hungarian reporter, the author of The Jewish State and Altneuland, is generally recognized as the father of Zionism.

q3.quetsion_text: This 1917 letter to Baron Rothschild from the British Foreign Secretary, which ambiguously promised a Jewish "national home" in Palestine, was a major success for Zionism.

lead_in: Answer the following about important jazz bassists, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: When he wasn’t training his cats to use the toilet, this man was busy composing albums like Black Saint and Sinner Lady and Pithecanthropus Erectus and songs like “Goodbye Pork Pie Hat”.

q2.quetsion_text: Before being beaten to death by a club bouncer, this long-haired fretless bass pioneer played on the albums Black Market and Heavy Weather after Joe Zawinul recruited him to join Weather Report.

q3.quetsion_text: A duet between pianist Bill Evans and bassist Paul Chambers opens “So What”, the first track on Kind of Blue, an album by this trumpeter’s quintet.

lead_in: Johann Zoffany painted this man’s death. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this British explorer, the most notable commander of the HMS Endeavour. He was slain in a 1779 brawl when natives hit him over the head and then stabbed him.

q2.quetsion_text: Cook is credited with leading the first European voyage to this continent, which he claimed for Britain without consulting the aboriginal population.

q3.quetsion_text: This 1828 to 1832 war took place on what is now Tasmania between aborigines and British colonists. A human chain that shares its name with this war swept across the island to corral the natives, although some contemporary historians question accounts of atrocities during it.

q3.quetsion_text: In an essay on "The Overcoat," Boris Eikhenbaum described Gogol's use of this Russian literary technique, also used regularly by Nikolai Leskov. It involves the use of a personal narrator who adopts a specific linguistic idiom.

lead_in: The Large Hadron Collider is the most powerful one of these devices in the world.

q1.quetsion_text: Name these devices, other examples of which include Stanford's SLAC and Fermilab's Tevatron. As their name suggests, they bring protons and electrons to high speeds, often to collide them.

q2.quetsion_text: The LHC is located in this laboratory on the Franco-Swiss border. The W and Z bosons were discovered here, and a sample of antimatter lasted for 15 minutes here in 2011.
q2.raw_answer: CERN [or European Organization for Nuclear Research]

q3.quetsion_text: The ongoing OPERA experiment, which reported measuring faster-than-light neutrinos in 2011, fires particles from CERN and detects them 731 kilometers away at this Italian lab.
q3.raw_answer: Laboratori Nazionali del Gran Sasso [or LNGS]

lead_in: This man's followers engaged in a dispute over various issues with the followers of Shammai. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Jewish scholar of the 1st century BC, famous for positing a version of the Golden Rule.

q2.quetsion_text: Hillel is well-known for condensing the six or several hundred orders of this redaction of the Jewish Oral Torah into six. Together with the Gemara, it makes up the Talmud.

q3.quetsion_text: "Sandwiches" named for Hillel are eaten during the seder marking the beginning of this holiday celebrating the exodus from Egypt.

lead_in: This scientist gave the first proof of the law of quadratic reciprocity, which is sometimes called his namesake “golden theorem.” For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this scientist, who also names a function whose integral is referred to as the “error function.”

q2.quetsion_text: Gauss’s golden theorem concerns the solvability of one of these statements between some square modulo some prime number. These statements are represented by a symbol that looks like an equals sign with an extra horizontal line in the middle.

q3.quetsion_text: For all prime numbers p, a raised to the p is congruent to a mod p according to this man’s “little theorem.” The equation a to the n plus b to the n equals c to the n has no integer solutions for n > 2 according to this French mathematician’s “last theorem.”

lead_in: Name these abolitionists, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This hyper-religious bearded man orchestrated the Pottawatomie Massacre in Kansas. He was hanged after his failed attack on Harpers Ferry.

q3.quetsion_text: Wendell Phillips gave a eulogy for this abolitionist at Faneuil Hall in 1837. This editor of the St. Louis Observer was killed when a mob stormed his newspaper's building in Illinois.

lead_in: This man is the subject of the book Yankee from Olympus. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this man who wrote in a famous dissent in Lochner v. New York that “the Fourteenth Amendment does not enact” the book Social Statics. This justice more famously wrote about “clear and present danger” in his majority opinion in Schenck v. United States.

q2.raw_answer: World War I [or the Great War]

q3.quetsion_text: Holmes’ later moderation of his free speech views was influenced by the writings of this New York judge, who later became an extremely prolific judge on the Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. The author of The Spirit of Liberty, he had more opinions quoted by the Supreme Court than any other lower-court judge.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this state which intermittently unified Norway, Denmark, and Sweden from 1397 to 1523.

q3.quetsion_text: After the Englebrecht Rebellion, the Swedish gained some independence before this ruler's invasion in 1520. An ally of Gustav Trolle, he perpetrated the Stockholm Bloodbath. In karmic retaliation, Frederick I imprisoned this man for 27 years.

lead_in: The Jaynes-Cummings model is used to model an atom with this many levels, which is the most important system in quantum optics.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this minimum number of levels required for a system to display the Schottky anomaly. There exist this many values of spin for a spinÂ–1/2 particle.
q1.raw_answer: two [or obvious equivalents, such as dos or someone flashing the peace sign]

q2.quetsion_text: The Schottky anomaly is observed in salts with this property, as it's due to unpaired electrons or partially filled orbitals. Orbital quenching in molecules normally obviates this property, though oxygen is an exception.

q3.quetsion_text: A ideal paramagnetic system of independent, non-interacting spinÂ–1/2 particles, like solid helium-3, can exhibit this odd property seen in lasers at population inversion. This peculiar property actually just means that higher energy levels are more occupied than lower ones, so the Boltzmann factor's sign is reversed.
q3.raw_answer: negative temperature on an absolute scale [or obvious equivalents, such as a temperature below absolute zero]

lead_in: This character has been given two weeks to live by his doctor and recounts his failed romance with Lizaveta, the daughter of Ozhogin in an "uncomfortably built" district town.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this archetypal title character who writes a diary in a novella by the author of A Sportsman's Sketches.

q1.quetsion_text: Name these structures made up of triangular units linked at nodes.

q2.quetsion_text: If the structure is completely anchored so as to prevent movement, the sum of all forces equals this, as per Newton's second law.

q3.quetsion_text: If two times the number of joints equals the number of members plus the number of reactions, a truss will have this quality. This means that static equilibrium equations alone are enough to calculate all the unknown forces on a free body diagram.

lead_in: A crucifix by this artist is now located in the Escorial Monastery, while his many now-lost works include a golden clasp for the cape of Clement VII.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this sculptor who included a boat surrounded by dolphins, as well as a gilded sea god reclining away from an earth goddess, in his most famous work, which was created for Francis I.

q3.quetsion_text: Francis I also commissioned a Cellini sculpture titled for the genius of this place, which shows a reclining nude goddess and a deer extending out towards the viewer. A school of this name included Mannerist artists like Rosso Fiorentino.
q3.raw_answer: Fontainebleau [accept the Genius of Fontainebleau or the Nymph of Fontainebleau]

lead_in: This man wrote of "a people starved and stabbed in the untilled field", a reference to the Peterloo Massacre, in a poem about a land ruled by "an old, mad, blind, despised and dying King". For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this author of the sonnet "England in 1819" who urged the title entity to "drive my dead thoughts over the universe" in a poem which asks "If Winter comes, can Spring be far behind?"

lead_in: The Chisso Corporation's release of toxins containing this element caused an outbreak of Minamata disease.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this metal. Its bioaccumulation may poison top predators, such as swordfish and tuna.

q2.quetsion_text: Unfounded allegations link this mercury-containing preservative used in multidose flu vaccines to autism. It's also an antiseptic.

q3.quetsion_text: Metallothioneins, which complex with mercury, have lots of this amino acid. This amino acid has an imidazole side chain and can be acidic or basic at physiological pH.

lead_in: This author's three-year correspondence with Paul Auster was anthologized in the volume Here and Now.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this South African author, who won the Man Booker prize twice, for Disgrace and Life & Times of Michael K.

q2.quetsion_text: The only Nigerian winner of the Man Booker Prize is this author, who won for his novel about the spirit-child Azaro, The Famished Road.

q3.quetsion_text: Goya painted one of these traveling up a hill in one his Black Paintings. One of these is also depicted beside two men in Gustave Courbet's The Meeting.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this microscopic technique that images the structure of a surface using a cantilever with a sharp tip, which is deflected by interactions with surface atoms.
q1.raw_answer: atomic force microscopy or AFM (accept scanning force microscopy or SFM; prompt on partial)

q2.quetsion_text: Depression of the cantilever in an atomic force microscope may be modelled with this law, which says the force needed to extend a spring is proportional to the distance.

q3.quetsion_text: Cantilever deflection can be measured with piezoresistivity, laser vibrometry, optical interferometry, or by using this electrical circuit element. Its two parallel branches are connected by a voltmeter and each have two resistors; three resistances are known and one must be determined.

lead_in: Mendel found that roundness in peas has this property. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this property, which is possessed by the allele which is expressed phenotypically in a heterozygote. The allele with this property is represented by a capital letter in a Punnett square.
q1.raw_answer: dominant allele [or dominance; or word forms]

q2.quetsion_text: If one parent is homozygous for a dominant allele and the other parent is heterozygous for a gene that follows perfect Mendelian inheritance, then what percent of the F1 generation would have the dominant phenotype?
q2.raw_answer: 100% [or all of them; or same-knowledge equivalents]

q3.quetsion_text: In this type of mutation, a mutant phenotype makes a protein that disrupts the function of the wild-type protein, usually by forming an inactive dimer. They often result in cancer.

lead_in: Heinrich Biber imitated five different types of them in his Sonata Representativa in A, while recordings of them play a large part in Einojuhani Rautavaara’s Cantus Arcticus, a concerto “for [them] and orchestra”. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify these especially musical animals, one of which also inspired Frederick Delius’s On Hearing the First Cuckoo in Spring.
q1.raw_answer: birds [accept birdsong or variants; or Aves; reverse prompt on “cuckoo(s)” and sigh heavily]

q2.quetsion_text: This Italian composer mimicked several different birds in his Gli Uccelli and wrote one of the first pieces to call for recorded birdsong, using a nightingale at the end of the third movement of his Pines of Rome.

q3.raw_answer: Quartet for the End of Time [or Quatuor pour le fin du temps; by Olivier Messiaen]

q2.quetsion_text: Longfellow wrote an epic poem about this Native American hero, who fights the magician Pearl-Feather and loves Minnehaha.

q2.quetsion_text: The Orsini affair brought down the government of this British Prime Minister. This man gave the civis romanus sum speech after the Don Pacifico affair to justify the blockade of Piraeus.
q2.raw_answer: Henry John Temple, 3rd Viscount Palmerston [accept either]

q3.quetsion_text: This British political party was led by Palmerston, as well as by William Gladstone and David Lloyd George. This opponent of the Conservative Party generally supported laissez-faire economics in the 19th century.

lead_in: This effect is the change in frequency of a wave for an observer moving relative to it. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this effect illustrated by the change in pitch of a siren as it moves towards - and past - an observer.

q2.quetsion_text: In special relativity, the Doppler effect is modified by this phenomenon, which manifests in a clock in a moving reference frame appearing to be slower to a stationary observer. The factor of slowing is the reciprocal of the equation for length contraction.

q3.quetsion_text: For an object undergoing length contraction, the length seen by the stationary observer is equal to the proper length divided by this quantity.

lead_in: Total alkali silicon diagrams can be used to visualize the classification of these rocks. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this class of rock, which includes basalt and granite, and which typically have an origin from earth’s interior.

q2.quetsion_text: This extrusive rock is comprised mostly of volcanic glass, which gives it its vitreous appearance. It has a conchoidal fracture and is often found alongside rhyolite. They can also comprise tektites.

q3.quetsion_text: An igneous rock that forms inside another igneous rock, is given this name. The most common mechanism of forming them involves magma that intrudes a pluton that subsequently hardens.

lead_in: In this technique, the stationary phase has functional groups that participate in Coulombic interactions with the analyte of interest. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this chromatography technique that allows for the isolation of compounds based on their charge.
q1.raw_answer: ion-exchange chromatography [or ion chromatography; prompt on partial]

q2.quetsion_text: When isolating ions from coal, one observes an increasing selectivity of ion exchange for divalent cations from manganese through copper. That series mirrors this series that shows an increasing stability of high-spin octahedral metal complexes of first-row transition metals for replacing water by other ligands.

q3.quetsion_text: The Irving-Williams series is predicted by this theory, which assumes fully electrostatic interactions between the metal and the ligand. It predicts a splitting of d orbitals into e-sub-g and t-sub-2g levels.

lead_in: After the Washington Star reported this study's existence in 1972, Congress created the National Commission for the Protection of Human Subjects of Biomedical and Behavioral Research. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this study in which American doctors infected several hundred poor black sharecroppers from Macon County with syphilis at the namesake institute, before then knowingly failing to treat any of them.
q1.raw_answer: Tuskegee syphilis experiment [accept any equivalent mentioning Tuskegee]

q2.quetsion_text: In 2010, the U.S. government formally apologized to this country, whose President Juan José Arévalo allowed the Truman administration to operate similar syphilis experiments there during the 1940s.

q3.quetsion_text: This doctor became the first globally known medical professional from the U.S. for discovering how to repair vesicovaginal fistula, a method he discovered through extensive gruesome experimentation on slave women.

lead_in: This man is thought to have negotiated the Arusha Accords in bad faith, but got his comeuppance when his own Hutu extremists killed him to initiate the Rwandan genocide. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Rwandan president who was shot down in his French-built plane on August 6, 1994 at the start of the genocide.

q2.quetsion_text: The character of Colonel North in Hotel Rwanda is based primarily on this real-life Canadian commander of UNAMIR credited with saving 20,000 lives.

lead_in: After meeting with the Lord Mayor of London and other members of high society, this poet was finally able to get published; her first book of poetry is dedicated to the Countess of Huntingdon. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this poet wrote a poem in praise of the commander-in-chief of the Continental Army, "To His Excellency, George Washington."

q2.quetsion_text: This African-American poet collected Wheatley's and Jupiter Hammon's poetry in an Anthology of Negro Poets in the U.S.A. His own books include a fictionalization of Prosser's rebellion titled Black Thunder.

q3.quetsion_text: This African-American poet compiled The Penguin Anthology of 20th Century American Poetry, which Helen Vendler blasted for including too many second-rate poets for the sake of multiculturalism.

lead_in: This novel’s title character has an affair with Drew Preston while living in Saratoga Springs, and many of its major characters are later killed while hiding in Union City to avoid charges brought by Thomas Dewey. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this novel whose protagonist is mentored by his idol, the mobster Dutch Schultz.

q3.quetsion_text: Doctorow wrote a 2009 novel about the lives of the eccentric, hoarding Collyer brothers, one of whom is named Langley and the other of whom shares this name with the attributed author of the Iliad and the Odyssey.

lead_in: A chair, a stepstool, three no-doubt-displeased cats, and an S-shaped splash of water are among the items depicted in midair in a photograph of this man. For 10 points each:

lead_in: Name some things related to mental states that are “about something”, or intentionality, for 10 points each.

q2.quetsion_text: This American philosopher argued for the practicality of the “intentional stance” to predict behaviors in a book of the same name. This eliminative materialist also claimed that natural selection sufficiently explains the evolution of life in Darwin’s Dangerous Idea.

lead_in: This novel opens with the protagonist killing a mouse with a skillet.

q1.quetsion_text: Name these folds in which strata slope downward from the center. They come in ramp and rollover varieties, and are signs of the presence of petroleum.

q3.quetsion_text: Anticlines are a type of this structure that occurs any time a mobile material is forced through a brittle one. Salt domes are another example.

lead_in: This man opposed the sorcerer king Soumaoro. For 10 points each:

lead_in: This novella is set at a country house called Bly. For 10 points each:

lead_in: The shadow of this object is said to float "midway on the waves" in a poem in which it as described as a "miracle of rare device" and as being "sunny" but "with caves of ice". For 10 points each:

lead_in: Answer these questions about the medieval tournament, from which modern competitions of all sorts get that name,

q1.quetsion_text: In this centerpiece sport of a tournament, two mounted knights charged each other with lances to try and unseat one another.

lead_in: In statistics, power refers to the ability of a model not to commit this error. For 10 points each:

q1.raw_answer: type II error [or error of the second kind]

q2.raw_answer: Egon Pearson or Jerzy Neyman [accept Neyman-Pearson theory; do not accept or prompt on "Karl Pearson"]

q3.quetsion_text: When comparing multiple hypotheses, you may use this technique in which you maintain a familial significance cutoff, but divide the cutoff by the number of hypotheses when testing each hypothesis. This technique, named for an Italian, minimizes the probability of erroneous significant effects.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this book of the Bible, a Pauline epistle that also includes famous quotes like "through a glass darkly" and "I have become all things to all people."

q2.quetsion_text: Paul addressed this issue of the early church in Romans 2:25Â–29. He states that this is "of the heart" and that if you break the law it as though you have not done this. Not having this practice done differentiated many early Christians from Jews.

q3.quetsion_text: Paul showed his misogynistic side in this epistle addressed to a mentee of his. It states that women should "be in silence" and is frequently used in arguments over whether women are allowed to become priests.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this phenomenon often studied in human geography, by which people relocate from one country to another.

q2.quetsion_text: This term describes factors that encourage potential immigrants to move to a specific destination, such as especially good job opportunities in the target country.

q3.quetsion_text: Unlike immigration, which is usually permanent, this type of population movement, in which people follow their herds of livestock, is usually cyclical with the seasons.

lead_in: Historical characters who appear in this book include Marcion and Nebuchadnezzar. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this book, written in the form of a play, which was inspired by a Bruegel painting. Its title character resists his desire for Ammonaria and the lure of the satanic Hilarion.
q1.raw_answer: The Temptation of Saint Anthony (or La Tentation de Saint Antoine)

q2.quetsion_text: The Temptation of Saint Anthony is by this author, who also created the adulterous Emma Bovary.

q3.quetsion_text: This other Flaubert novel details Frederic Moreau's infatuation for Madame Arnoux.

lead_in: This event was prompted in part by an 1829 gold rush, and more directly by the 1830 Indian Removal Act. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this forced migration of native groups. It resulted in the Cherokee leaving their lands in Georgia and moving to what became Oklahoma.

q2.quetsion_text: The Trail of Tears began after some Cherokee signed this 1835 treaty. John Ross tried to stop the US from ratifying and enforcing this treaty.

q3.quetsion_text: This other "civilized tribe", impacted by the Trail of Tears, included the Hitchiti in its namesake confederacy. They signed the treaties of Indian Springs and Fort Jackson after fighting the US.
q3.raw_answer: Creek Indians [or Creek confederacy; or Muskogee]

lead_in: Answer the following about a data structure that isn't used in the real world: the red-black tree, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: The red-black tree is this type of search tree, which means that every node has at most two children. This type of search works on an already-sorted array and cuts the interval length in half on each iteration.

q2.quetsion_text: The reason for marking nodes as red or black is to maintain this property of a tree, which means that there is a bound on the number of descents one must make when searching a red-black tree.

q3.quetsion_text: The height of a red-black tree is thus proportional to this function of n, where n is the number of nodes of the tree. It is also the Big O runtime of binary search.

lead_in: The Romans imported their gods from other peoples. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: In the Metamorphoses, this god sails to Rome in snake form and takes up residence on an island in the Tiber. He saves Rome from a plague, befitting his role as a god of healing.

q2.quetsion_text: The Romans were never entirely at ease with these Phrygian self-castrating priests of Cybele who ran through the streets flogging themselves with the accompaniment of tambourines and pipes.

q3.quetsion_text: The Romans celebrated this Praeneste goddess of woods and orchards with her festival on the Ides of November. Unsurprisingly, she was adorned with much fruit.

lead_in: For 10 points each, name these Eastern European writers who wrote about characters who become soldiers in the Russian army, and then leave, but end up re-joining anyway because of mistaken identity involving Germans.

q1.quetsion_text: That happens to poor Sergeant Grischa, who is eventually captured by Germans in this writer's The Case of Sergeant Grischa, the first volume of his hexology The Great War of White Men. His brother Stefan wrote The Royal Game.

q2.quetsion_text: This writer's Private Ivan Chonkin deserts the army when he gets confused, but after becoming a peasant, the NKVD confuses him for a German spy, leading him to arrest the NKVD officers and earn comical praise from General Drynov.

q3.quetsion_text: The real-life figure of Otto Irbe, who joins the Red Army, then leaves and becomes a German legionnaire before the Russians capture him and mistakenly send him to the gulags is one of numerous people who inspired this writer's The Gulag Archipelago.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this novel about the final days and recollections of a corrupt Mexican tycoon, whose family urgently tries to discover where his will is hidden.
q1.raw_answer: The Death of Artemio Cruz [or La Muerte de Artemio Cruz]

q2.quetsion_text: This Mexican author of The Death of Artemio Cruz also wrote Aura and The Old Gringo.

q3.quetsion_text: Pollo Phoibee falls into the Seine in this massive Fuentes novel, whose setting shifts to various historical times including the assassination of Tiberius and Phillip II's construction of El Escorial.
