q1.quetsion_text: Prolific Swiss firm Herzog & De Meuron collaborated with artist Ã€i WÃ¨iwÃ¨i on the design of an athletic stadium also known as the Bird's Nest, which is located in this city.

q2.quetsion_text: Běijīng's China Central Television Tower, which features two slanted towers connected by a cantilever, was designed by OMA, a firm headed by this Dutch architect. His theories are outlined in Delirious New York.

q3.quetsion_text: This firm, which designed the Willis Tower and the Burj Khalifa, is presently working on the incredibly efficient Pearl River Tower in Guangzhou. One of its architects won the commission to design One World Trade Center.

lead_in: This essay asserts that "who kills a man kills a reasonable creature, God's image; but he who destroys a good book, kills reason itself".

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this attack on the Press Ordinance of 1643, a passionate defense of freedom of speech named after an Athenian court.

q2.quetsion_text: "Areopagitica" was written by this English poet, who elegized his drowned friend Edward King in "Lycidas" and attempted to "justify the ways of God to men" in his Paradise Lost.

q3.quetsion_text: In "Lycidas", a speech given by the "pilot of the Galilean lake" concludes with a warning that this oft-analyzed, enigmatic object is "at the door", where it "stands ready to smite once, and smite no more".

lead_in: The Community Charge, a policy of this type pushed through by Margaret Thatcher, contributed to her fall from power. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this type of tax applied uniformly to each individual. A different type of tax known by the same name was banned in the US by the Twenty-Fourth Amendment.

q2.quetsion_text: This man led the Peasant's Revolt in 1381 in response to a new poll tax. Supported by priest John Ball, he was killed during Richard II's reign.

q3.quetsion_text: Tyler's revolt broke out in Essex and this coastal region east of Sussex. Jack Cade and Thomas Wyatt also rebelled in this region, where Augustine of Canterbury converted a king named Aethelbert.

lead_in: Annette Weiner analyzed the frequent exchange of immovable goods, such as women's property, with movable ones, such as men's gifts, in this system of exchange.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this system of exchange consisting of red and white objects that are traded in north and south directions. Everyone can participate in this system on Dobu, though in other places only chiefs participate.

q2.quetsion_text: White armbands called mwali were made of these things and frequently traded in the kula exchange. Cowrie ones were used as currency among indigenous North Americans, as well as some East Africans.

q3.quetsion_text: Marcel Mauss introduced this term to refer to exchanges that metonymically represent the entire society their participants are a part of, and not simply a trade of goods.

lead_in: In one scene of the novel in which he appears, this character is almost suicidal in prison when he chances upon and befriends the Abbe Faria.

q1.quetsion_text: Give the real name of this character who goes on to seek his revenge against men like Fernand and Danglars.
q1.raw_answer: Edmond Dantes [accept either; prompt on "The Count of Monte Cristo" or "Abbe Busoni" or "Lord Wilmore"]

q2.quetsion_text: Dantes is the protagonist of this Alexandre Dumas novel, in which he escapes from prison and disguises himself as the ruler of an island in order to carry out his revenge.
q2.raw_answer: The Count of Monte Cristo [or Le Comte de Monte-Cristo]

q3.quetsion_text: Dantes is imprisoned for supposedly subscribing to this political view. The father of Villefort, the judge who condemns him, also holds this political view.
q3.raw_answer: Bonapartism [or word forms, such as Bonapartist; accept anything that communicates the idea "he wants Napoleon to come back"]

lead_in: Rollo May wrote that this school of thought was overly authoritarian. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this school of therapy founded on the belief that the driving force in people is to find meaning in their lives. It was appropriately outlined in Viktor Frankl’s book Man’s Search for Meaning.

q2.quetsion_text: Man’s Search for Meaning is primarily about Frankl’s experiences in one of these institutions, in which he noted that numerous people experienced depersonalization and lost the will to live without meaning.
q2.raw_answer: a concentration camp [prompt on prison camp or jail]

q3.quetsion_text: Aspects of logotherapy are similar to this theory created by Abraham Maslow that organizes human concerns into a pyramid, with physiological concerns at the bottom. People who have satisfied all of their concerns are said to be “self-actualized.”

lead_in: An equation giving this quantity named for Van Slyke includes the natural logarithm of 10 and the sum of the concentrations of acid and base.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this quantity, often symbolized beta, equal to the derivative of moles of strong acid with respect to pH.

q2.quetsion_text: The pH of a buffer is given by the Henderson-Hasselbalch equation, which sets pH equal to this quantity minus the log of the concentration of the acid over its conjugate base. This quantity increases as acidity decreases.
q2.raw_answer: pKa [or the logarithmic constant; do not accept or prompt on "Ka"]

q3.quetsion_text: In the acid-base form of this technique, the halfway point occurs where the pH is equal to the pKa of the solution. This technique uses a buret to determine concentrations of unknown compounds.

lead_in: Answer the following about tea, for the stated number of points each.

q1.quetsion_text: Oil extracted from the bergamot orange provides the characteristic flavor of this black tea blend, which takes its name from the British Prime Minister who authored the Reform Act of 1832.

q2.quetsion_text: Green tea ice cream is usually made using powdered green tea known by this Japanese term. It is contrasted with the un-ground leaves of sencha.

q3.quetsion_text: While its name sounds Tibetan, this tea actually originates from the Wuyi mountains in China’s Fujian province. Its claim to fame, other than possibly being the first recorded tea in history, is that its leaves are smoked while drying.
q3.raw_answer: lapsang souchong [or zhengshan xiaozhong; or seisanshoshu]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this letter, which names Jesus as a forerunner to the romantic movement. It was written by a man who was jailed after suing the Marquess of Queensberry for libel.

q2.quetsion_text: This author of De Profundis is better known for writing The Picture of Dorian Gray and The Importance of Being Earnest.

q3.quetsion_text: In this unrelated Wilde play, the title Russian barmaid joins a group of assassins, but ultimately stabs herself rather than murder her love, Czar Alexis.

lead_in: Whereas lactose intolerance might just give you diarrhea and cramps, its unsung, scarier cousin, fructose intolerance, can eventually lead to this awful thing happening.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this really bad condition that results in azotemia, or the buildup of nitrogen-containing compounds in the bloodstream, anemia, due to severely decreased production of erythropoietin, and uremia.
q1.raw_answer: kidney failure [or renal failure; or renal insufficiency]

q2.quetsion_text: Kidney failure is diagnosed by seeing if this measure of renal functional severely decreases. It is a numerical measure of how much stuff per time passes through the namesake network of capillaries that's surrounded by Bowman's capsule.

q3.quetsion_text: Other than straight up getting a transplant, kidney failure can be mitigated by hooking a patient up to one of these machines that manually perform the work of the kidney.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this winner of the 2001 Nobel Prize in Economics, along with Joseph Stiglitz and George Akerlof.

q2.quetsion_text: George Akerlof's best known essay may be this one, in which information asymmetry is discussed in the context of selling used cars.

q3.quetsion_text: Signaling, along with screening, are ways of reducing this specific type of information asymmetry. It is a situation in which undesired results come up in the market prior to the transaction, as opposed to its after-transaction counterpart that involves additional insulated risk.

q1.raw_answer: Way of St. James (or St. James' Way or El Camino de Santiago or Chemins de Saint-Jacques-de-Compostelle or Il Cammino di Santiago di Compostela or der Jakobsweg)

q2.quetsion_text: Saint James is the patron saint of this nation. His cathedral, the Santiago de Compostela, is located in Galicia in this country.
q2.raw_answer: Kingdom of Spain (or Reino de EspaÃ±a)

q1.quetsion_text: Name this essay which recounts an incident in which the author, a colonial police officer in Burma, is forced against his will to take the title action "solely to avoid looking a fool."

q2.quetsion_text: "Shooting an Elephant" is an early essay by this British author, who attacked Stalinism and totalitarianism in the novels Animal Farm and 1984.

lead_in: Answer the following about rewards for a heroic death in world mythologies,

q1.quetsion_text: Valkyries take slain warriors to this building in Asgard, where they drink mead and eat from an ever-regenerating pig until they're needed at Ragnarok.

q2.quetsion_text: In this culture's lore, successful warriors who died in battle become hummingbirds that follow the sun. They also believed in a separate paradise for victims of water-related deaths.

q3.quetsion_text: Heroes in the Iliad fight for this attribute, the renown or glory by which a person's deeds outlast their death. The first line of Herodotus's history notes that it aims to preserve this attribute of its subjects.

q2.quetsion_text: You've probably heard about how unstable things are in this post-revolutionary country, currently led by Ali Zeidan. The instability is understandable, considering it had been led by Mu'ammar Gaddafi for more than 40 years before the revolution.

q3.quetsion_text: Rebels in this country have recently captured the towns of Bor and Malakal. This country's president, Salva Kiir Mayakar, has been its leader since its inception.

lead_in: Article 9 of this country's constitution renounced its right to engage in "war as a sovereign right of the nation." For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this country whose most recent constitution was drafted under the supervision of Douglas MacArthur's occupying troops. This nation's surrender ended World War II.

q2.quetsion_text: Under politicians like Sato Eisaku and Junichiro Koizumi, this political party has dominated Japanese politics since World War II.
q2.raw_answer: Liberal Democratic Party [or LDP; do not accept or prompt on "Democratic Party of Japan"]

q3.quetsion_text: The Allies partially dismantled these large Japanese business firms after the war, though many reformed to become kigyo shudan or "enterprise groups". They included companies like Mitsubishi.

lead_in: 19th-century composers loved to stretch the limits of sonata form. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: This long, very difficult solo piano piece in F minor by Chopin uses a hybrid between sonata form and theme and variations. Another Chopin piece in the same genre alternates between placid F-major and stormy A-minor sections.
q1.raw_answer: Ballade No. 4 [or Opus 52; prompt on "Ballade"; accept equivalents for "No. 4" like "fourth"]

q2.quetsion_text: This composer used a "multi-function" sonata form in pieces like his Piano Concerto No. 2 in A Major, his Fantasia and Fugue on the chorale "Ad nos, ad salutarem undam" for organ, and his Piano Sonata in B Minor. He also wrote some Transcendental Etudes and Hungarian Rhapsodies.

q3.quetsion_text: This composer began stretching the limits of sonata form with his extremely difficult, one-movement fifth piano sonata. His other piano pieces include "Vers la flamme."

lead_in: Answer the following about horrible, horrible, programming languages, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: The god-awful language of Brainfuck pretty much works by being able to only increment this data type, which is a variable that is a reference to another variable. In C, you can declare one using an asterisk.

q2.quetsion_text: Because it is incredibly esoteric, it took about eight years before the first one of these constructs was implemented in Malebolge. In C++, one type of them can be declared using the word “for.”

q3.quetsion_text: The language Whitespace, in which the only valid commands are space, tab, and new line, follows this programming paradigm, the opposite of declarative programming. In this paradigm, statements in a computer program change the state of computation.

q3.quetsion_text: In the Coulomb gauge, the electric potential varies inversely with distance, so it can be neglected when analyzing radiation problems described by this term. Diffraction problems are often divided into "near-field" and those described by this term.

q2.quetsion_text: This immunosuppressant is used to prevent transplant rejection by blocking interleukin-2 signalling. Its "target" is a protein that regulates cell growth.

q3.quetsion_text: Target of rapamycin is this type of protein which phosphorylates proteins at the hydroxyl groups of two specific amino acid residues. Both of those amino acids also name a families of proteases.

lead_in: The differential form of this law states that the divergence of E is equal to rho over permittivity of free space. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this law, one of the four Maxwell equations, which relates the flux through a surface to the charge enclosed by said surface.

q2.quetsion_text: Gauss's law can be used to show that the electric field inside a conducting sphere takes on this value because it contains no enclosed charge. In Gauss's law for magnetism, the divergence of the magnetic field equals this value.

q3.quetsion_text: Gauss's law can be used to show that the potential of this configuration of charges is equal to twice the charge density times Coulomb's constant times the natural log of a ratio of distances from the configuration. Its electric field is thus proportional to one over distance.
q3.raw_answer: infinite line of charge [or obvious equivalents, such as an infinite number of charges in a linear configuration]

lead_in: At the end of this story, Armand Aubigny burns a letter that reveals he is part black. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this short story about a Cajun child discovered at a gateway by the Valmonde family.

q2.quetsion_text: In this novel by the author of "Desiree's Baby," Edna Pontellier commits suicide by walking into the Gulf of Mexico after carrying on an affair with Robert Lebrun.

q3.quetsion_text: This American author of "The Story of an Hour" wrote "Desiree's Baby" and The Awakening.

lead_in: It is 1572, and you are a very rich Muslim ruler. Name some of the responsibilities you now have, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: You, like most Muslims you rule, are compelled by the Quran to pay this tithe on your excess income that helps those in need.

q2.quetsion_text: Since you belong to this sect of Islam, your zakat contribution is part of the khums, or “fifth” of your income you must give to charity. This sect of Islam also means you believe Ali and his descendents are the true successors of Muhammad.

q3.quetsion_text: You do rule over some people exempt from zakat, including this group of non-Muslims, who you protect as long as they pay the Jizya tax to make up for their infidelity.

q1.quetsion_text: "The Shadow Over Innsmouth," "The Dunwich Horror," and "The Call of Cthulhu" are among the many works in the genre by this huge-faced American recluse.

q2.quetsion_text: The author of the collection Widdershins, which contains the classic horror novella The Beckoning Fair One, shares this first name with the gamekeeper who has an affair with Constance Chatterley in a D.H. Lawrence novel.
q2.raw_answer: Oliver (accept Oliver Onions or Oliver Mellors)

q3.quetsion_text: Ghost Stories of an Antiquary and its imaginatively-named sequel More Ghost Stories of an Antiquary were written by this English author, whose most famous story is probably "Oh, Whistle, and I'll Come to You, My Lad."

lead_in: This man and Matthias Ringmann are credited with the first usage of the word “America” to refer to the continent of the New World. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this German cartographer whose 1507 map, Universalis Cosmographia, is the oldest surviving map to use the name America.

q2.quetsion_text: In 1569, this type of map projection was created by the namesake Flemish cartographer. A standard map projection, it is noted for distorting the size and shape of large objects, thus making Greenland look huge.

q3.quetsion_text: This thinker developed the Dymaxion map, which is projected onto an icosahedron and can then be unfolded and flattened to two dimensions. He also proposed a Dymaxion car and received a patent for a geodesic dome.

lead_in: These items were banned by the Dress Act of 1746 after the Battle of Culloden. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this apparel whose popularity Hugh Trevor-Roper attributed to a Quaker named Thomas Rawlinson, and not to generations of people who roamed the Scottish Highlands.

q2.quetsion_text: Trevor-Roper thus suggests that the kilt is an example of one of these ideas, which are essentially cultural norms that, by repetition, are taken to imply a continuity with the past. Eric Hobsbawm and Terence Ranger collected multiple essays illustrating them in a 1983 book.
q2.raw_answer: invented traditions [prompt on partials; accept word forms; accept The Invention of Tradition]

q3.quetsion_text: Trevor-Roper traced the kilt fraud to Vestiarium Scoticum and The Costume of the Clans, books by two Englishmen who claimed descent from the Stuarts and this dynasty. The Old Pretender married into this dynasty, which included a king who routed the forces of Kara Mustafa in 1683.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this novel set in the town of Saumur. Characters in this work include Cruchot and Nanon, the servant of the title woman, and it's part of a series that also included Pere Goriot.

q2.quetsion_text: Eugenie Grandet is a part of this French author's massive Human Comedy.

q3.quetsion_text: In addition to writing the Human Comedy novels, Balzac wrote a novel about a man named Benassis who serves in this title profession. A "district" one of these people falls in love with Alexandra Andreyevna before her death in a Turgenev short story.

lead_in: In one poem, this character shalt "wander like a breeze by lakes and sandy shore, beneath the crags of ancient mountain, and beneath the clouds, which image in their bul both lakes and shores." For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this "cradled infant" who slumbers peacefully while the speaker ponders "abstruser meanings" in solitude.
q1.raw_answer: Hartley Coleridge [accept Samuel Coleridge's child or any obvious equivalents; prompt on "Coleridge"]

q2.quetsion_text: This two-word phrase is what the frost performs, unhelped by any wind, at the beginning of "Frost at Midnight."

q3.quetsion_text: In another section of "Frost at Midnight" Coleridge describes these things as "the poor man's only music" that stirred within him a "wild pleasure, falling on mine ear most like articulate sounds of things to come."

lead_in: Identify the following about Serbo-Bosnian literature, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: The most famous work of Serbian author Milorad Pavic comes in male and female editions and is titled for one of these books "of the Khazars." Samuel Johnson spent nine years creating one for the English language.
q1.raw_answer: dictionary [or dictionaries; accept Dictionary of the Khazars]

q2.quetsion_text: The national epic of Serbia and Montenegro, written by Prince-Bishop Petar II Njegos, is titled for this type of "wreath." A novel about the aging Shingo by Yasunari Kawabata is titled for the "sound" of one of these geological features.
q2.raw_answer: mountains [accept The Mountain Wreath or Gorski Vijenac or The Sound of the Mountain or Yama no Oto]

q3.quetsion_text: This Nobel-winning Bosnian author wrote such novels as The Vizier's Elephant and The Woman from Sarajevo, but is most famous for his sprawling historical work The Bridge on the Drina.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this orchestral piece, also known as Fingal's Cave, which was written after the same trip that inspired the composer's Scottish Symphony.

q2.quetsion_text: The Hebrides Overture and the Scottish Symphony were composed by this man, whose chamber pieces include a String Octet in E-flat major.

q3.quetsion_text: The first movement of Mendelssohn's Reformation Symphony twice uses this six-note motif, played by the strings with an interruption by the brass.

lead_in: This film includes a dangerous stunt in which actor Yakima Canutt jumped from his steed to a front horse, then fell and passed under all six horses without dying.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this John Ford film in which the John Wayne-played Ringo Kid falls in love with the prostitute Dallas, who is part of an entourage heading to Lordsburg when they are beset by a savage Apache attack.

q2.quetsion_text: In this other collaboration between John Ford and John Wayne, a romantic comedy set in Ireland, Wayne's character Sean Thornton shovels his dowry money for Mary Kate into a furnace, and gets into a memorable protracted fistfight with her brother Will, which at one point is broken off so that they can get drunk.

q3.quetsion_text: In his film Wee Willie Winkie, Ford cast this omnipresent child actress, who melted her way into America's heart in Bright Eyes, Curly Top, and Heidi.

lead_in: In one scene in this play, four girls pose as wheels in a mock car-crash called the "Dance of the Lost Traveller". For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this 1959 play in which the traditionalist Baroka clashes with the more modern Lakunle over the right to marry a village girl named Sidi.

q2.quetsion_text: The Lion and the Jewel was written by this Nigerian playwright of Requiem for a Futurologist and Madmen and Specialists. Simon Pilkings catastrophically prevents a ritual suicide in his Death and the King's Horseman.

q3.quetsion_text: Soyinka's first published works appeared in a magazine founded by Ulli Beier and titled, in imitation of a Sartre essay, for a "Black" version of this Greek mythological character, the husband of Eurydice.

lead_in: The protagonist of this film breaks out of jail in a delirious haze after accidentally eating cocaine but gets rearrested after meeting an orphan girl played by Paulette Goddard and eating a huge amount of food.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this silent film whose most famous scene shows the Little Tramp pulled into the gears of a giant machine while working on a hectic assembly line.

q2.quetsion_text: This writer, director, and star of Modern Times and City Lights was, along with Harold Lloyd and Buster Keaton, one of the most famous silent film-era comedians.

q3.quetsion_text: The increasingly political nature of Chaplin's films came to a head with this 1940 attack on Hitler, Chaplin's first talkie. In it, Chaplin plays Adenoid Hynkel, also known as "Der Phooey".

lead_in: This is the deepest lake in North America. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this lake, with the towns of Fort Resolution and Hay River on its shores, which is the source of the Mackenzie River.
q1.raw_answer: This city is located on the northern shore of the Great Slave Lake. The Tibbitt to Contwoyto Winter Road connects isolated mines to this capital of the Northwest Territories.

q2.quetsion_text: This city is located on the northern shore of the Great Slave Lake. The Tibbitt to Contwoyto Winter Road connects isolated mines to this capital of the Northwest Territories.

q3.quetsion_text: In 1978, the U.S. and Canada launched Operation Morning Light, which recovered nuclear debris from the Great Slave lake after this country's nuclear-powered satellite fell out of orbit into the lake.
q3.raw_answer: Soviet Union [or Sovetsky Soyuz; or Union of Soviet Socialist Republics; or USSR; or CCCP; or Soyuz Sovetskikh Sotsialisticheskikh Respublik; prompt on Russia]

lead_in: This religious tradition differs from the Lutheran tradition on whether Christ is physically present in the Eucharist, among other things.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this religious tradition, which was founded by a French theologian who wrote Institutes of the Christian Religion and made it the established religion in Geneva.

q2.quetsion_text: This Dutch word refers to mass outbreaks of iconoclastic Calvinist violence in which mobs would destroy Catholic art. Most of these actions occurred in the Low Countries.

q3.quetsion_text: This ruler sent the Duke of Alba to govern the Netherlands following a major 1566 Beeldenstorm. The Netherlands organized an alliance against this ruler in the Treaty of Nonsuch.
q3.raw_answer: Philip II of Spain [or Philip I of Portugal; or Philip the Prudent; or Felipe in place of Philip; or Felipe el Prudente; prompt on "Philip"]

lead_in: This character predicts "I am the last that will last keep his oath" after signing a certain paper. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this character who lectures his friends about not keeping that oath after finding them each with a love letter, then extemporizes about the importance of skirt-chasing after his own love letter to Rosaline is discovered.

q2.quetsion_text: Biron is a character in this play, in which the King of Navarre and his lords flirt with the Princess of France and her ladies despite having forsworn women for three years.

q3.quetsion_text: In Act V, Scene II of Love's Labour's Lost, the schoolmaster Holofernes puts on a show in which he and other actors present themselves as these personifications of medieval chivalry and are ruthlessly heckled by the audience.

lead_in: Along with Charles Crocker, Mark Hopkins, and Collis Potter Huntington, this tycoon was a member of the "Big Four". For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this businessman who named a university for his dead son. He commissioned Eadweard Muybridge to figure out if a galloping horse ever had all of its feet off the ground.

q2.quetsion_text: Stanford's company built the western portion of this project, which was finally completed with the hammering of a golden spike at Promontory, Utah.
q2.raw_answer: First Transcontinental Railroad [or Pacific Railroad; prompt on "Overland Route"]

q3.quetsion_text: Stanford, like this later man, served as governor of California. This eventual Chief Justice of the Supreme Court lost the 1916 presidential election to Woodrow Wilson.

lead_in: Hume stated that this mode of being was “pure philosophical fiction” since man is inherently inclined to form a society. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this hypothetical period of time of human history before the establishment of organized society or political institutions.
q1.raw_answer: state of nature [prompt on “prehistory”, since I am feeling generous; prompt on “nature”]

q2.quetsion_text: The state of nature was described as “solitary, poor, nasty, brutish, and short” in one section of this English philosopher’s treatise Leviathan.

q3.quetsion_text: In Leviathan, Hobbes argues that societies form since man instinctively shies away from this. Freud argued that political aggression and childhood games like hide and seek demonstrate man’s drive towards this in Beyond the Pleasure Principle.
q3.raw_answer: death [or dying; or other word forms]

lead_in: His 1828 collection of Odes and Ballades includes an ode to Napoleon's column, and he wrote of all the sailors who have drowned in the seas in his poem "Oceano Nox".

q1.quetsion_text: Name this French author of an unfinished epic with sections dedicated to the story of Nimrod, the death of Jesus Christ, and the storming of the Bastille. That work is The End of Satan.

q2.quetsion_text: Victor Hugo is better known for this novel, in which the gypsy Esmerelda inspires love in the Archdeacon Claude Frollo and the title character, the bellringer Quasimodo.
q2.raw_answer: The Hunchback of Notre Dame [or Notre-Dame de Paris]

q3.quetsion_text: Hugo's Les Miserables opens with several chapters devoted to this clergyman, who later covers for Jean Valjean after the latter robs the church's silver, by claiming that he gave the silver to Jean as a gift.

lead_in: A pair of rabbits, two mounted riders, and a flock of sheep are among the minor background details of this painting, which Walter Friedländer suggested depicted characters from the Hypnerotomachia Poliphili. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this 1514 painting in which a boy dips his hand into a pool of water between two women, one naked and one clothed.
q1.raw_answer: Sacred and Profane Love [or Amor Sacro e Amor Profano; or Amor Divino e Amor Profano; or Divine and Profane Love; or Venus and the Bride]

q2.quetsion_text: Sacred and Profane Love was painted by this Venetian artist, who also painted such mythological scenes as Bacchus and Ariadne for Alfonso d’Este. He lends his name to a brownish-orange hair color he favored.

q3.quetsion_text: A knight carrying a red banner bearing the papal arms and leading a Turk and a Moor, two putti erecting a cross on a cloud, and St. Peter reading from a book all appear in this Titian painting, created for the Frari Basilica.
q3.raw_answer: the Pesaro Madonna [or the Pala Pesaro; or, as Wikipedia seems to insist, the Madonna di Ca' Pesaro]

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this government that was opposed by the Maquis and took power after the failure of the Dyle Plan.

q2.quetsion_text: The Vichy regime was headed for most of its existence by this asshole who led French troops at the Battle of Verdun.

q3.quetsion_text: This admiral was also part of the Vichy regime, but switched sides to the Allies after he was captured in Algiers. The switch enabled the Allies to quickly capture French possessions in North Africa, but this man was assassinated soon after the switch.

lead_in: The south, east, and west Sundarbans Wildlife Sanctuaries are located in the southwestern part of this country. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Asian country, where the Bayazid Bostami shrine and Patenga Beach are found in a port city on the Karnaphuli river.
q1.raw_answer: People's Republic of Bangladesh [or Gana Prajatantri Bangladesh]

q2.quetsion_text: This city on the Buriganga River is home to the Shaheed Minar and is the capital of the same country that contains Chittagong, Bangladesh.

q3.quetsion_text: Bangladesh is separated from this country by India's Siliguri Corridor. In 2008, this country dissolved its monarchy and became a constitutional republic
q3.raw_answer: Federal Democratic Republic of Nepal [or Sanghiya Loktantrik Ganatantra Nepal]

lead_in: This museum's namesake "villa" is modeled after the Villa of the Papyri and houses a life-size bronze statue attributed to Lysippos called Victorious Youth. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this museum whose permanent collection includes James Ensor's Christ's Entry Into Brussels and a marble sculpture found outside Hadrian's tomb in Tivoli, the Lansdowne Heracles.
q1.raw_answer: J. Paul Getty Museum [accept J. Paul Getty Villa or J. Paul Getty Center]

q2.quetsion_text: This museum, which is run by a large state college, has an extensive collection of Daumier paintings and drawings, and its prized possessions Gustave Moreau's Salome Dancing Before Herod, and John Singer Sargent's Portrait of Dr. Samuel Pozzi.
q2.raw_answer: Hammer Museum [accept Armand Hammer Museum of Art and Culture Center or AHMACC]

q3.quetsion_text: Both the Getty Museum and the Hammer museum are located in this city, whose Philharmonic Orchestra performs in the Walt Disney Concert Hall.

lead_in: The first Euler angle, usually represented phi or alpha, represents the angle of this phenomenon, usually about the z-axis. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this change in the axis of a rotating body. It is commonly observed in a spinning top along with a wobble in the axis.

q2.quetsion_text: The wobble in the rotational axis as a top - or other rotating object, such as the Earth - precesses is known by this term, which involves a change in the second Euler angle.

q3.quetsion_text: This phenomenon occurs when two rotational axes of a three-dimensional system point in the same direction, leading to the loss of a degree of freedom. It's an intrinsic problem for the Euler angle representation.

lead_in: This woman was chosen to head the jury selection for the main competition at the 2014 Cannes Film Festival. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this director who, in 1993, became the first woman to win the Palme d'Or; in her winning film, The Piano, the mute Ada develops feelings for Baines.

q2.quetsion_text: Jane Campion hails from this country, whose landscapes were featured in the Lord of the Rings trilogy.

q3.quetsion_text: Campion's jury awarded the Palme d'Or to this movie by Turkish director Nuri Ceylan. In it, Mr. Aydin struggles to maintain relationships with those near to him as he runs a hotel and writes for a local newspaper.

lead_in: In the transcription-coupled version of process, TFIIH unwinds a DNA strand so that XPG and XPF-ERCC1 can create a dual incision.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this DNA repair mechanism whose failure is the most common cause of xeroderma pigmentosum.

q2.quetsion_text: Nucleotide excision repair often repairs damage done by ultraviolet radiation, which can include the formation of dimers of this pyrimidine which, unlike uracil, has a methyl group on C5.

q3.quetsion_text: The formation of pyrimidine dimers by UV radiation is a major cause of skin cancers, including this most malignant kind of skin cancer.

lead_in: Name the following terms used to describe the scientific process, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This two-word term refers to Paul Feyerabend's observation in Against Method that fixed, universal methodological rules governing the progress of science are counterproductive.

q2.quetsion_text: This term is used to refer to the process of "puzzle-solving" that scientists engage in for the majority of their careers in Thomas Kuhn's The Structure of Scientific Revolutions. It is contrasted with revolutionary science.

q3.quetsion_text: This term refers to a distinct concept or thought pattern in epistemology that "shifts" in a scientific revolution. Imre Lakatos suggested the idea of "research programmes" as an alternative to this concept.

lead_in: Machiavelli criticized this ruler for replacing a large portion of his infantry with Swiss mercenaries.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this prudent king of France, who signed the Treaty of Picquigny with Edward IV to isolate his main rival, Charles the Bold.
q1.raw_answer: Louis XI [or The Universal Spider; or The Spider-King; or any answers mentioning both spiders and Louis; prompt on "Louis (the Prudent)"]

q2.quetsion_text: Louis's brother Charles joined this Charles the Bold-forged alliance of feudal nobles that stood against Louis XI.
q2.raw_answer: The League of the Public Weal [or La ligue du bien Publique]

q3.quetsion_text: Charles the Bold and Philip the Good ruled this medieval kingdom bordering France. This kingdom was named for a people led by Gundobad, who issued that people's namesake "Code."

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this colony once led by William Claiborne. Its governor in 1689 was deposed in a rebellion led by John Coode.

q2.quetsion_text: This border between Maryland and Pennsylvania, named for two colonial-era surveyors, was the traditional separator of the American South from the North.
q2.raw_answer: Mason-Dixon Line [or Mason and Dixon Line]

q3.quetsion_text: Every fifth milestone on the Mason-Dixon Line bore the coat of arms of the Penn family on one side and of this family on the other side. Lord Baltimore was from this family.

lead_in: One writer who used this language described how Tevye the Dairyman "Strikes It Rich" in one story. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this language also employed by Isaac Singer, the author of The Magician of Lublin.

q2.quetsion_text: Singer wrote a story about Jacques Kohn, an actor who championed the works of this Jewish writer of "A Hunger Artist" and The Trial.

q3.quetsion_text: In this other Singer short story, a baker is cuckolded by his wife Elka and believes everything that people tell him. After Elka's death, he is briefly convinced by the Spirit of Evil to urinate in the bread he bakes for the town.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this reporter-turned explorer, who greeted a long-missing British missionary in central Africa with the understatement "Dr. Livingstone, I presume?"

q2.quetsion_text: Description acceptable. Livingstone's goal was finding this geographic feature uncharted by Europeans, which Arab traders led him to at Lake Victoria.
q2.raw_answer: finding the origin of the White Nile River [accept descriptive answers substituting source, headwaters, etc. for "origin"; prompt on "finding Lake Victoria"; do not accept any answer indicating "Blue Nile"]

q3.quetsion_text: This earlier Scottish explorer traveled along the Niger river a few decades before the Scramble for Africa and drowned in it in 1806.

lead_in: Answer the following about electronic music, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This composer of Musica Ricercata and études like "Fanfares" and "The Devil's Staircase" wrote two electronic pieces, and imitated the sound of electronic music in a tone-cluster heavy, "micropolyphonic" orchestral piece.
q1.raw_answer: György Ligeti [the piece is Atmosphères; "Gyorgy" is pronounced similar to "George"]

q2.quetsion_text: Edgard Varèse, who wrote innovative pieces like Poème électronique and Déserts, which includes three "interpolations of organized sound," emigrated from France to this country. The composer of the electroacoustic piece Philomela, Milton Babbitt, hailed from this country, as did Charles Ives.
q2.raw_answer: United States of America [accept either underlined part; accept USA]

q3.quetsion_text: Gérard Grisey and Tristan Murail are known for working with this kind of electronic music, in which fast Fourier transforms are used either to modify acoustic signals or to aid in composition based on those signals.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Strachey introduced the "ad hoc" and "parametric" types of this technique, which respectively allow functions to be "overloaded" by accepting different types and allow functions or data types to be written generically. Along with encapsulation and inheritance, it is one of the defining features of object-oriented programming.

q2.quetsion_text: While some suggest it should've been named for Moses SchÃ¶nfinkel, Strachey coined the name of this technique, in which a function that takes multiple arguments is transformed into a chain of single-argument functions.

q3.quetsion_text: Strachy also designed CPL, a programming language influenced by this archaic language, for which BackusÂ–Naur form was developed.

lead_in: A campaign ad for this politician, featuring famous Kentucky institutions, accidentally included footage of the Duke basketball team. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this senior senator from Kentucky who currently serves as Senate Minority Leader.

q2.quetsion_text: This current Kentucky Secretary of State is McConnell's presumptive Democratic opponent in his 2014 re-election bid. If elected, she would become the youngest active Senator.

q3.quetsion_text: This other female Democratic candidate is an incumbent from Louisiana. She chairs the Senate Committee on Energy and has been targeted for her support of the Affordable Care Act.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Athens, Georgia's music scene birthed many bands, including this group that featured Michael Stipe on vocals. Their many hits include "Everybody Hurts," "Man on the Moon," "Losing My Religion," and "Shiny Happy People."

q2.quetsion_text: This alt-country band is also from Athens, with members including Mike Cooley and Patterson Hood. They're known for sprawling concept albums like The Dirty South and Southern Rock Opera.

q3.quetsion_text: The B-52s, who are also from Athens, recorded this hit song about the title sea creature. It's spotted at a party where "everybody had matching towels," and is mistaken for an inanimate object.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this kind of bond-breaking symbolized by fishhook arrows, wherein each atom retains one of the electrons from the bond.
q1.raw_answer: homolytic cleavage [or word forms, such as homolysis]

q2.quetsion_text: Homolytic cleavage of a neutral molecule generates two of these extremely-reactive species with unpaired electrons, which can wreak havoc in the human body unless stopped by antioxidants.

q3.quetsion_text: The "nitrite" type of this functional group undergoes photolytic homolytic cleavage in the Barton reaction. A beta-hydroxy one is the output of the Reformatsky reaction.

lead_in: This scientist wrote the oft-cited paper "Homage to Santa Rosalia, or Why Are There So Many Kinds of Animals?" and was an early developer of the niche concept in ecology. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this "Father of Limnology," a Yale ecologist who asked why so many types of phototrophs can coexist in a relatively isotropic environment in the landmark paper "The Paradox of the Plankton."

q2.quetsion_text: Many limnologists can moonlight as paleobotanists by studying ancient deposits of this substance on lake bottoms. It contains male gametes, which travel down a tube towards the female pistil base.

q3.quetsion_text: Joe Connell's barnacle experiments demonstrated the difference between the "realized" niche and this other type of niche, which is the ecological space an organism could theoretically occupy in the absence of competition.

lead_in: This novel's protagonist seeks to figure out what happened to Gordon Ngubene, who mysteriously died during a police interrogation. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this novel in which Ben du Toit investigates the death of his friend, only to be mysteriously murdered while investigating the aftermath of the Soweto Riots.
q1.raw_answer: A Dry White Season [by Andre Brink]

q2.quetsion_text: This Faulkner-inspired André Brink novel features thirty or so narrators, and traces the disintegration of the friendship between Nicholas and Galant amidst a 19th-century slave rebellion.

q3.quetsion_text: André Brink's The First Life of Adamastor is a reimagining of a monstrous character from this epic poem, in which Vasco da Gama encounters various gods and monsters on the way to India. It is considered the national epic of Portugal.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this expression for a wavefunction of a system with multiple identical fermions.

q2.quetsion_text: This approximate technique in computational chemistry computes energy for many-body systems writing the wavefunction as a Slater determinant.

q3.quetsion_text: The Hartree-Fock approximation can be used to approximately construct these mathematical entities that describe the distribution of electrons in a molecule or atom. They are written with a star if they are antibonding and atomic ones can be computed by the LCAO method.

lead_in: This character's brother Valentin is shot to death in a duel after an over-strong sleeping potion kills her mother.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this peasant girl who is jailed for killing her infant child. A dashing professor seduces her and then abandons her to watch a demonic Walpurgis Night pageant.

q2.quetsion_text: This German author wrote about Gretchen's fate in the first part of his Faust, which he revised continually for over sixty years.

q3.quetsion_text: After studying foreign forms such as the ghazal, Goethe coined this term for the growing convergence of artistic traditions, which he hoped would override separated national conceptions of poetry and prose.

lead_in: A literary woman with this name is said to be “doubly dead in that she died so young” in a poem whose narrator enjoins her lover Guy de Vere to “weep now or never more” at the sight of her body on a bier. For 10 points each:

q3.quetsion_text: This German Romanticist wrote the aesthetic treatise "On the Formative Imagination of Beauty" and a psychological novel about a day-dreamer and aspiring poet titled Anton Reiser.

lead_in: Many square-planar complexes, such as Vaska's complex, violate this rule first proposed by Irving Langmuir.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this rule, which can be thought of as an extension of the octet rule to transition metal complexes.

q2.quetsion_text: Complexes with 18 electrons have the same electronic configurations as these pretty stable elements,which include neon, helium, and argon.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this proposal to ban slavery in territories acquired from Mexico following the Mexican-American War.

q3.quetsion_text: The Wilmot Proviso was denounced at a meeting in this city, which followed the Mississippi Convention and took place three months prior to the passage of the Compromise of 1850. Although that convention here advocated compromise, a followup meeting in this city affirmed the states' right to secession.

lead_in: STO-3G and 6-31G are frequently used examples of these constructs. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these collections of functions used in computational chemistry. Linear combinations of functions from these collections, which are not atomic orbitals, are used to construct molecular orbitals.

q2.quetsion_text: The STO-3G and 6-31G basis sets use basis functions of this type. This type of basis function is named for a German mathematician and has a radial part of the form "r to the k times e to the (minus a r squared)," much like the normal pdf.
q2.raw_answer: Gaussian basis set [or Gaussian basis function; or Gaussians]

q3.quetsion_text: When augmenting a Gaussian basis set to include these functions, one adds an asterisk to the name of the set. These functions correspond to higher-angular-momentum orbitals for light atoms, such as p orbitals for hydrogen.

lead_in: William I, Duke of Aquitaine founded one of these institutions at Cluny, whose reforms were championed by Saint Odo; another at Monte Cassino was destroyed in World War II. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these religious communities which sprung up in the Middle Ages, where typically celibate Christians lived and worked. Their inhabitants often copied classical texts by hand.

q2.quetsion_text: This saint and founder of the Monte Cassino monastery formulated a namesake "Rule" for monks. His followers used the motto orare est laborare, or "to pray is to work".

q3.quetsion_text: An early and unexpected calamity of this type befell the abbey at Lindisfarne, off the coast of England, in 793.
q3.raw_answer: Viking raids [accept any answer indicating that Norse raiders damage a place; prompt on answers such as "sacking", "raid," "burning," etc. which do not specify the attackers]

lead_in: The incipient movement of this substance versus the critical shear stress is considered on the Shields diagram. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this term for matter produced by the weathering of rocks at the Earth's surface and transported by wind, ice, water, or gravity.

q2.quetsion_text: This diagram in sediment transport plots the boundaries between erosion, transportation, and deposition of sediment on a graph of flow velocity versus particle size. A refinement of this diagram was implemented by Sundborg.

q3.quetsion_text: An outdoor example of these open-channel structures was built by G. K. Gilbert at Berkeley to study sediment transport. The University of Tsukuba built a giant recirculating example of these structures, which carry unidirectional gravity-driven free-surface flow, as opposed to closed ducts or conduits.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this poem, a love story set in a place "with up so floating many bells down". It repeats different permutations of the phrase "sun moon stars rain" to show the passage of time.

q2.quetsion_text: "anyone lived in a pretty how town" was written by this American poet, who penned "i sing of Olaf glad and big" and famously eschewed capitalization and punctuation and used unusual typography in many of his poems.

q3.raw_answer: spring [or "Spring is like a perhaps hand"]

lead_in: Show you have the chemical engineering knowledge to work at BP, ExxonMobil, or Shell by answering the following questions about petroleum chemistry. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Crude oil is a mixture of these organic compounds whose only functional groups are alkanes, alkenes, and alkynes. They consist entirely of two elements.

q2.quetsion_text: When crude oil enters an oil refining plant, it is first distilled to separate the differently sized components. Then, the heavier components undergo this process, which breaks them down into smaller, more useful hydrocarbons.

q3.quetsion_text: In this form of cracking, the feedstock is vaporized, mixed with a powdered zeolite, then sent to a reactor. Its name references the fact that the extremely high temperatures prevent the zeolite from behaving like a solid.

lead_in: "How Long Is the Coast of Britain? Statistical Self-Similarity and Fractional Dimension" is ne of Benoit Mandelbrot's first considerations of these sets, whose name he would later coin. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these sets that display self-similarity at all scales, such as the Koch snowflake and the Sierpinski triangle.

q2.quetsion_text: Before fractals were developed, this German mathematician repeatedly removed the open middle thirds from a set of line segments to develop a set with fractal properties. He also invented set theory.

q3.quetsion_text: Mandelbrot's famous fractal set is closely related to this other fractal set that display chaotic properties. It concerns the points z equals x plus i y on the complex plane where the series z sub n plus one equals z sub n squared plus c, where c is a complex number, does not diverge to infinity.

lead_in: This command is the first line of a poem that invites the reader to "ride ten thousand days and nights, till age snow white hairs on thee." For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this instruction, which precedes other impossible tasks, such as "tell me where all the past years are" and "get with child a mandrake root."
q1.raw_answer: "Goe, and catche a falling starre" [or "Go, and catch a falling star"]

q2.quetsion_text: "Go and catch a falling star" is one of the songs in the Songs and Sonnets of this poet of "The Flea."

q3.quetsion_text: In this poem from Songs and Sonnets, the speaker asserts that Love knows "no season...nor clime, nor hours, days, months, which are the rags of time." It calls the title entity a "busy old fool" and a "saucy pedantic wretch."

lead_in: Robert Parr quantified this theory by defining its central concept as half the second derivative of total energy, with respect to electron number.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this theory that classifies substances based on their atomic radius, oxidation state, polarizability, electronegativity, HOMO, and LUMO.
q1.raw_answer: HSAB theory [or Pearson hard soft acid base theory; or Pearson theory]

q2.quetsion_text: Parr's definition of hardness can be approximated as half of this quantity, minus electron affinity. This quantity is a measure of how easy it is to remove an electron from an atom in the gaseous state, and the second one is much higher than the first for sodium.
q2.raw_answer: ionization energy [or IE; or ionization potential]

q3.quetsion_text: Kornblum's rule, an application of HSAB theory, states that in ambident nucleophiles, this non-doublebond-forming reaction mechanism is more favorable for the more electronegative atom, because the carbocation (carbo-CAT-ion) is a hard acid.
q3.raw_answer: SN1 [or unimolecular substitution; prompt on substitution]

lead_in: This novel's protagonist works as an engraver in a silver shop and befriends people like the tomboy Mick Kelly and the diner owner Biff Brannon. For 10 points each:

lead_in: This concept was fully developed by de Broglie and is intimately tied to his relation which states that wavelength is inversely proportional to momentum.

lead_in: Answer these questions about factors in the decline of the Qing dynasty, the last imperial dynasty of China, for 10 points each.

lead_in: The reputation of the composer of this piece as a fomenter of the Risorgimento suffered after historians discovered that Immenso Jehova, and not this piece, was the subject of Milanese encore requests. For 10 points each:

q3.quetsion_text: Durer produced three gigantic woodcuts for Maximilian I depicting an arch, a procession, and a large carriage, all of which are described by this adjective. The arch was printed from 192 separate woodblocks.

lead_in: This ruler killed his wife Fausta by putting her in an overheated bath. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this emperor who secured power by defeating Maxentius at the Battle of Milvian Bridge. As emperor, he issued the Edict of Milan.

q2.quetsion_text: Constantine became the first Roman ruler to accept this religion.

q3.quetsion_text: The man who baptized Constantine had this name. A more famous Roman with this name was a Bishop of Caesarea who wrote an Ecclesiastical History of the early church.

lead_in: This historian argued that Islamic science and scholarship was the major intellectual influence on the development of scholasticism in the High Middle Ages. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Oxford Historian, the author of The Making of the Middle Ages.

q2.quetsion_text: Southern argued that the state Fulk III set up as count of this region, including the building of a large network of castles in territory he didn't yet fully control, was a watershed in medieval state-building and bureaucratization.

q3.quetsion_text: Southern wrote a monograph on this saint and his biographer, Eadmer, as well as a full-scale biography of this saint subtitled "a portrait in a landscape." Chapter 6 of Southern's biography discusses the argument found in this Canterbury resident's Proslogion.
q3.raw_answer: St. Anselm of Canterbury [accept St. Anselm of Bec or St. Anselm of Aosta]

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: This government was created after the First World War in the namesake town. In power until the rise of the Third Reich, it had to deal with hyperinflation and the payment of $5 billion in war reparations.

q2.quetsion_text: This first president of the Weimar Republic was Germany's first democratically elected leader. This Social Democrat signed a pact with Army Quartermaster General Wilhelm Groener and fled Berlin during the Kapp Putsch.

q3.quetsion_text: This February 1933 event occurred six days before Parliamentary elections. Allegedly set by Marinus van der Lubbe, the Nazi party blamed this event on the Communists.
q3.raw_answer: burning of the Reichstag (accept equivalents like "fire" and "arson")

lead_in: Name the following about titrations, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This technique is used to quantify the dissolved oxygen in environmental water samples. Manganese(II) sulfate is added to solution, which is subsequently oxidized in its first step, and later the solution is re-acidified and an iodometric back-titration is performed to quantify the oxidized manganese.

q2.quetsion_text: Another titration method involves the indirect measurement of this quantity, which is related to electrophoretic mobility by the Henry equation. Ionic polyelectrolytes are used in water treatment to effect changes in this quantity and induce greater stability or flocculation of suspended particles.

q3.quetsion_text: When performing titrations, you usually want to stop at this point, at which the analyte is effectively consumed by the titrant. It is also the point at which titration curve has the highest slope.

lead_in: This man gave the first Day of Affirmation Speech while visiting the University of Cape Town.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this politician who memorably gave an impromptu speech in Indianapolis after hearing of the murder of another man. This politician quoted Aeschylus and said "what we need in the United States is not violence or lawlessness, but love and wisdom."

q2.quetsion_text: Kennedy was reacting to the death of this civil rights leader, who gave the "I Have a Dream" speech in 1963.

q3.quetsion_text: Robert Kennedy himself was assassinated in the Ambassador Hotel in this state, where he had just won the 1968 Democratic primary before his death.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this "Big Man" politician who promoted his fellow Kalenjin to high positions in his government, which was rocked by the murder of Robert Ouko and the loss of 10% of his country's GDP in the Goldenberg Scandal.

q2.quetsion_text: Daniel arap Moi was a president of this African country. Moi named himself "Nyayo," meaning "footsteps," to describe his relationship to his predecessor Jomo Kenyatta.

q3.quetsion_text: Moi looked even worse when Bishop Alexander Muge coincidentally died in one of these incidents shortly after accusing Moi's government of banditry. Robert Mugabe has also made strategic use of these apparently random events, as when Susan Tsvangirai died in one that injured her husband Morgan.
q3.raw_answer: car accidents (or car crashes; or automobile accidents)

lead_in: Answer the following about legal education and certification in the United States, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This university in northern Manhattan hired the first American professor of law, James Kent, in 1793. Alexander Hamilton attended it while it was called Kings College.
q1.raw_answer: Columbia University in the City of New York [or Columbia College]

q2.quetsion_text: After law school, an aspiring lawyer must take this comprehensive test to be certified to practice law in a given state.

q3.quetsion_text: This man passed the bar in New York in 2004 and California in 2014, but has been denied a law license due to a controversial invocation of the "good moral character" test, after The New Republic's 1998 repudiation of thirty-six investigative journalism pieces that he fabricated.

lead_in: This empire divided itself into provinces called satrapies after it revolted from and overtook the Medes.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this dynasty of classical Persian emperors such as Darius, which helped repatriate the Jews from Babylon to their homeland under the rule of Cyrus the Great.

q2.quetsion_text: This Achaemenid emperor's 480 BCE invasion of Greece, in which he ordered his men to whip the Hellespont, takes up the latter part of Herodotus's Histories.

q3.quetsion_text: This Achaemenid public works project linked Susa, a capital in modern-day Iran, to Sardis in Anatolia. It allowed horse-mounted mail couriers to go super-fast.

lead_in: The 2004 sequel to this novel centers on an epidemic of political indifference, as first exemplified by 83% of the populace casting blank ballots in an election. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this 1995 novel about a different epidemic, whose sufferers are detained in an asylum in which the King of Ward 3 is murdered by the doctor's wife, who remains unaffected by the title condition.
q1.raw_answer: Blindness [or Ensaio sobre a cegueira; or Essay on Blindness]

q2.quetsion_text: Blindness was written by this Lusophone author, who exiled himself to Lanzarote after the Portuguese government's attempts to censor his novel The Gospel According to Jesus Christ.

q3.quetsion_text: In 1995, Saramago won a prize named for this author of the play El-Rei Seleuco, whose most famous work is a long poem that includes a council of the Olympian gods and introduces the evil demigod Adamastor.
q3.raw_answer: Luis Vaz de Camoes [or Luis de Camoens]

lead_in: This artist collaborated with Pirkle Jones on the Life magazine photo-essay "The Death of a Valley", which depicted the flooding of Monticello, California by the new Lake Berryessa. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this photographer who chronicled the internment camp at Manzanar for the War Relocation authority but remains most famous for a photo of Florence Owens Thompson called Migrant Mother.

q2.quetsion_text: Fellow pioneering female photographer Margaret Bourke-White may be most famous for her photographs of this Indian nationalist leader sitting at a spinning wheel, taken shortly before his assassination by Nathuram Godse.
q2.raw_answer: Mahatma Gandhi [or Mohandas Karamchand Gandhi; prompt on "Bapu"]

q3.quetsion_text: The most expensive photograph sold by a female photographer is this woman's Untitled #96. She used mannequins and prosthetic limbs in her series Sex Pictures and modeled herself for her most famous series, Untitled Film Stills.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this American sociologist who claimed that sociology should focus on blending abstract concepts and empirical data into "middle-range" theories in his book Social Theory and Social Structure
q1.raw_answer: Robert King Merton [do NOT accept "Robert Cox Merton"]

q2.quetsion_text: Merton's theory of criminal deviance focuses on the relationship between culture, social structure, and this term he borrowed from Emile Durkheim. This term indicates a disintegration of social norms and a disconnect between goals and means to obtain them.

q3.quetsion_text: Merton divided the function of social habits into "manifest" and "latent", terms he pilfered from this subconscious-obsessed German psychologist who wrote The Interpretation of Dreams.

lead_in: Twentieth-century English novelists were fond of writing travel memoirs during their journeys abroad.

q1.quetsion_text: This author chronicled some of his travels with his wife Frieda in the collections Twilight in Italy and Sea and Sardinia. He attracted controversy for the sexual explicitness of his novel Lady Chatterley's Lover.

q2.quetsion_text: This author described his three years living in Cyprus in the memoir Bitter Lemons. His time living in Egypt inspired his Alexandria Quartet.

q3.quetsion_text: This book by Rebecca West is an account of the history of Yugoslavia, and her own six-week journey through the country. Its publication coincided with the country's invasion by the Nazis.
q3.raw_answer: Black Lamb and Grey Falcon: A Journey Through Yugoslavia

lead_in: Faith is defined as "believing in" as opposed to "believing that" in this book's second volume, Faith and Reality. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this two-volume 1951 book of Christian existentialism, based on its French author's Gifford Lectures. It discusses the importance of reflection and "feeling as a mode of participation."
q1.raw_answer: The Mystery of Being [or Le Mystere de l'être]

q2.quetsion_text: The Mystery of Being is the magnum opus of this Christian existentialist philosopher who also wrote Homo Viator and Man Against Mass Society.

q3.quetsion_text: Marcel was a fan of this concept, which is the basis for much of Emmanuel Levinas's ethics. Simone de Beauvoir wrote in The Second Sex that woman was the "privileged" example of this concept.

lead_in: In The Birth of the Clinic, this thinker discussed the medical gaze which dissociates the person’s identity from his body. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this thinker who in that same book also discussed the modern narrative of medicine in which doctors will eventually end disease.

q2.quetsion_text: Foucault's best known work is this one in which he contrasts the public execution of Robert-Francois Damiens with the Mettray prison colony. It traces the evolution of the penal system to the modern, "panopticon."
q2.raw_answer: Discipline and Punish: The Birth of the Prison

q3.quetsion_text: This other work was further explained in Foucault's The Archaeology of Knowledge. It begins with a discussion of Las Meninas, and it argues that different time periods considered different things acceptable as scientific truth.
q3.raw_answer: The Order of Things: An Archaeology of the Human Sciences

lead_in: A tedious boxing and weightlifting mini-game in this game inspired a Retsupurae in-joke in which slowbeef and Diabetus say this game's name at the end of every video. F

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this ridiculous third-person shooter in which police officer Jack Slate uses his dog Shadow to instantly murder the criminals of Grant City.

q2.quetsion_text: Dead to Rights was an over-the-hill title produced by this company, which rolled out Galaxian, Dig Dug, and Pac-Man well before merging with Bandai.

q3.quetsion_text: Jack performs this action near the end of Dead to Rights, despite the FBI clearing him of murder charges. James Bond goes to Tokyo after performing this action in You Only Live Twice.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this pope who succeeded Anastasius IV, the first and only English pope.
q1.raw_answer: Adrian IV (accept Nicholas Breakspear; prompt on "Adrian")

q2.quetsion_text: The Catholic Church in Britain stretches all the way back to this first Archbishop of Canterbury. He shares his his name with the author of City of God and Confessions.

q3.quetsion_text: Catholicism in England took a crazy turn after Henry VIII converted to Anglicanism. This rebellion, which followed the Pilgrimage of Grace and included many of the same members, was actually led by and named after a Protestant. Like most rebellions in the 1500s, this one did not go well and everyone was hanged.

lead_in: This Mongol tribe led the Zubu confederacy, and its last leader was Toghrul, who helped the Jin Dynasty defeat a Tatar rebellion. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this tribe that converted to Nestorianism in the 11th century. They were allies of the Khamag Mongols during the rise of Temujin, who broke them up after becoming Genghis Khan.

q2.quetsion_text: This Khereid princess became Genghis Khan's daughter-in-law when she married his youngest son Tolui. She was the mother of the khans Mongke, Kublai, and Hulagu.

q3.quetsion_text: Khereid princess Doquz Khatun convinced her husband Hulagu Khan to spare the Christians living in this capital of the Abbasid Caliphate. Its 1258 sacking allegedly caused the Tigris to run black with ink.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this student of Ghiberti and teacher of Donatello, an architect who completed many projects for his patron Cosimo de' Medici, including Florence's Palazzo Medici.
q1.raw_answer: Michelozzo di Bartolommeo Michelozzi [accept either underlined portion]

q2.quetsion_text: Michelozzo collaborated with Donatello on a tomb for a cardinal from this other family. A chapel named for this family contains Masaccio's Tribute Money.

q3.quetsion_text: Masaccio's Tribute Money shows this apostle finding money to pay a tax collector in the mouth of a fish. A basilica named for this saint in the Vatican was designed by architects like Michelangelo and Bramante.
q3.raw_answer: Saint Peter [or Petrus; or Petros; or Simon Peter; or Shimon; or Simeon]

lead_in: This man collaborated with Milt Jackson and Thelonious Monk on recordings of "Bags' Groove" and "Swing Spring".

q1.quetsion_text: Name this trumpeter who popularized modal jazz with his album Kind of Blue, which became the best-selling jazz album of all time.
q1.raw_answer: Miles Davis [or Miles Dewey Davis III]

q2.quetsion_text: Kind of Blue opens with an introduction played by Paul Chambers and this pianist. Scott LaFaro and Paul Motian were part of his namesake trio, and he wrote the song "Waltz for Debby".
q2.raw_answer: Bill Evans [or William John Evans; do NOT accept "Gil Evans"]

q3.quetsion_text: Bill Evans is not related to Gil Evans, with whom Miles collaborated on this jazz-classical-fusion album, which includes adaptations of Joaquin Rodrigo's Concierto de Aranjuez and Manuel da Falla's "Will o' the Wisp".

lead_in: These equations have streaming terms on the left side and collision terms on the right. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this set of equations linking the probability density function of an s-particle system with the probability density function of an s+1-particle system.

q2.quetsion_text: The BBGKY hierarchy for an s-particle subset of an n-particle system can be obtained by integrating the equation describing this theorem over the terms representing the remaining n minus s particles. This theorem states that the distribution function is constant along any phase space trajectory.

q3.quetsion_text: Liouville's theorem implies that this hypothesis is valid when the initial distribution of microstates is uniform. It is related to molecular chaos and is a necessary precondition of the equipartition and Poincaré recurrence theorems.

lead_in: This writer was responsible for the reversal of the definitions of "objective" and "subjective" to their current English meanings.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this English writer, whose major work of non-fiction focuses on the distinction between "fancy" and "imagination" and who introduced the German Idealist ideas of Fichte and Schelling to English literary criticism.

q2.quetsion_text: The title sailor tells of the cruel fate that befell him and his crewmates after he shoots an albatross with a cross-bow in this poem by Coleridge.

q3.quetsion_text: Coleridge recalls his schooldays in this conversation poem, which describes the title meteorological phenomenon performing its "secret ministry".

lead_in: Bassoons introduce this work’s third section, a setting of the comic song “Was kommt dort von der Höh”, also known as the “fox song”. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this concert piece that also quotes the graduation song “Gaudeamus igitur”, written to thank the University of Breslau for bestowing an honorary degree on its composer.
q1.raw_answer: the Academic Festival Overture [or the Akademische Festouvertüre]

q2.quetsion_text: The Academic Festival Overture was composed by this German, whose first symphony was nicknamed “Beethoven’s Tenth”. This man composed A German Requiem and a famous lullaby.

q3.quetsion_text: The Academic Festival Overture was partly inspired by the work of this man, who quoted “Gaudeamus igitur” in his overture to Flotte Burschen. This Austrian also composed Morning, Noon, and Night in Vienna and Light Cavalry.
q3.raw_answer: Franz von Suppé [or Francesco Ezechiele Ermenegildo Suppé Demelli]

lead_in: In her most famous literary appearance, this character is accused of plaguing ladies' lips with blisters and of drumming at soldiers' ears, before her accuser is interrupted by the word "Peace!"

q1.quetsion_text: Name this figure who supposedly "gallops night by night through lovers' brains" in a gnat-drawn hazelnut chariot. She is also said to be "the fairies' midwife".

q2.quetsion_text: That speech about Queen Mab is delivered by this character, who puns "Ask for me tomorrow, and you shall find me a grave man" shortly after being fatally stabbed by Tybalt.

q3.quetsion_text: Before his death, Mercutio also wishes a plague on the feuding houses of Montague and Capulet, the central families of this Shakespeare play.

lead_in: In 2004, Stephen Hawking used this relationship to resolve the black hole information paradox. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this relationship that links theories of quantum gravity with exact counterparts in quantum field theory. For example, type IIB ["2-B"] string theory in ten dimensions can be reformulated in terms of supersymmetric Yang-Mills theory in four dimensions.
q1.raw_answer: AdS/CFT correspondence [accept answers describing a relationship between anti-de Sitter space and conformal field theory; prompt on, but do not otherwise reveal, "Maldacena duality" or "gauge/gravity duality"]

q2.quetsion_text: This Argentine physicist proposed the AdS/CFT correspondence in 1997. In 2013, he and Leonard Susskind conjectured that entangled particles are connected by wormholes.

q3.quetsion_text: The AdS/CFT correspondence is a special case of the holographic principle, which states that the boundary of a region of space contains a complete description of it. For example, information pertaining to an object that has fallen into a black hole is encoded in this part of the black hole.

lead_in: This river was frequently called Jayhoun in reference to one of the rivers of Eden, but at other times was called Gozan

q1.quetsion_text: Name this river whose ultimate source is thought, by some, to be an ice cave in the Wakhan corridor. This river was regarded by historiographers as the southern border of Turan.

q2.quetsion_text: Geographers and poets alike contrasted Turan with this region. This region lends its name to the modern country formerly known as Persia.
q2.raw_answer: Iran [or Greater Iran; or obvious equivalents, such as Eran]

q3.quetsion_text: This resource lends its name to the Dasht-e-Kavir, the large desert in the middle of the Iranian plateau. A number of odd mummies have been uncovered at Chehrabad, a facility where this resource is extracted.
