q1.quetsion_text: Name these transformations observed when one state of matter becomes another state by the transfer of heat.

q2.quetsion_text: An example of a second-order phase transition is the transition from ferromagnetism to paramagnetism at this temperature. This temperature's namesake discovered piezoelectricity with his brother, Jacques.

q3.quetsion_text: The magnetic susceptibility above the Curie temperature is described by a law named for Pierre Curie and this scientist. The concept of domains in magnets was developed by this person, which is why they are sometimes named for him.

lead_in: This writer sent his wife Rosina into a madhouse, an experience detailed in A Blighted Life; Rosina later painted an unflattering portrait of him in her roman-a-clef Cheveley. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Victorian novelist of Paul Clifford who wrote a "mystical mystery" called Zanoni, which focuses on a man who is immortal.

q2.quetsion_text: Bulwer-Lytton wrote this play, in which the title statesman states that "the pen is mightier than the sword."

q3.quetsion_text: This once-popular novel of Bulwer-Lytton, inspired by a campy Karl Briullov painting, features the nobleman Glaucus visiting the title town before a major calamity.

lead_in: In this novel, it is revealed that the human race was created solely to provide a replacement part for the spaceship of the Tralfamadorian explorer Salo, who befriends the space explorer Rumfoord. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this 1959 novel starring the incredibly lucky Malachi Constant. It was written seven years after its author’s first novel, Player Piano.

q2.quetsion_text: The Sirens of Titan was written by this American author, whose experiences as a POW surviving the firebombing of Dresden inspired his novel Slaughterhouse-Five.

q3.quetsion_text: The 211th, 212th, and 213th Amendments to the Constitution mandate the enforced “equality” of all American in this Vonnegut story, whose extraordinary title character is shot by the Handicapper General Diana Moon Glampers.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this film genre that is exemplified by films like Mildred Pierce and The Big Combo.

q2.quetsion_text: This film is widely considered one of the earliest and best examples of film noir. Directed by Billy Wilder, insurance salesman Walter Neff falls for the Barbara Stanwyck portrayed Phyllis Dietrichson in this film.

q3.quetsion_text: Jacques Tournier directed this other film noir. In it, the Robert Mitchum-portrayed Jeff Bailey is tracked down by Kathie Moffat and Whit Sterling. Spoiler alert: He dies in the end.

lead_in: The intensity of this process is inversely proportional to the fourth power of the wavelength of the incident light involved. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this process, named for an English physicist, whose effects on sunlight explain why the sky appears blue.

q2.quetsion_text: Rayleigh scattering is an example of this type of scattering, analogous to a similar type of collision in classical mechanics, in which kinetic energy is conserved.

q3.quetsion_text: Rayleigh scattering involves particles which have radii much smaller than the wavelength of the incident light. When particle radius exceeds ten percent of the light's wavelength, the intensity can be accurately calculated using the scattering model named for this German physicist.

lead_in: One of these poems that praises the Earl of Leicester describes "where pan and Bacchus their high feasts have made / beneath the broad beech and the chestnut shade." For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this genre of poetry that includes "To Penshurst" by Ben Jonson. This type of poetry usually celebrates the author's rich friend by immortalizing the namesake type of edifice.
q1.raw_answer: country house poem [do not accept or prompt on partial answers]

q2.quetsion_text: This English poet continued the country house poem tradition with his "Upon Appleton House." Another of his poems states "the grave's a fine and private place, but none, I think, do there embrace."

q3.quetsion_text: This other poet wrote the country house poem "At Penshurst." When not authoring popular lyrics like "Go, lovely rose," he plotted to seize Parliament for Charles I before the rise of Cromwell.

lead_in: In one poem, this poet described victory filling "the little rented boat" and everything becoming "rainbow, rainbow, rainbow!" For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this poet of "The Fish" who claimed that "the art of losing isn't hard to master" in the villanelle "One Art" and wrote the collections North and South and Geography III.

q2.quetsion_text: In Bishop's poem "The Armadillo," one of these events destroys an owl's nest. The speaker of a Robert Frost poem notes that "from what I've tasted of desire", he holds with those who favor this sort of event for the ending of the world.

q3.quetsion_text: A Bishop poem about this Daniel Defoe character "In England" observes "My island seemed to be a sort of cloud-dump" and remarks that "Friday was nice, and we were friends."

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this type of reaction often used to reduce alkenes or alkynes, involving the addition of molecular hydrogen to another compound and generally requiring a catalyst.

q2.quetsion_text: This catalyst, named for a Swiss-British chemist, can be used in the catalytic hydrogenation of an alkyne to stop the reduction at the cis-alkene and prevent alkane formation.

q3.quetsion_text: Lindlar's catalyst is often "poisoned" by this aromatic heterocyclic nitrogenous base, which occurs naturally in coal tar and is also used in the manufacture of dyes.

lead_in: This philosopher explained the old way of philosophy and art as manifestations of a weak “will to power.” For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this German philosopher who wrote Thus Sprach Zarathustra and The Birth of Tragedy.

q2.quetsion_text: This Nietzsche dualistic system of morality, central to On the Genealogy of Morals, credits traits like kindness and humility to one morality and traits like strength and nobility to another.

q3.quetsion_text: Nietzsche used this term to describe the hostility directed against stronger people by weaker people, which is the source of wrongheaded morality systems.

lead_in: Name these locations in the Pacific Ocean, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This country was previously known as the New Hebrides. Its national anthem, "Yumi, Yumi, Yumi," was written in its native Bislama language.

q2.quetsion_text: Jarvis Island, Baker Island, and Howland Island are all a part of this country's Pacific Remote Islands Marine National Monument. This country has a missile base on Wake Island.

q3.quetsion_text: This island in the Marshall Islands was the site of the 1954 Castle Bravo test and Operation Crossroads, after which most of this island's population was relocated to nearby Kili Island.

lead_in: The line integral of a function around a closed curve is equal to the double integral of this operator applied to the function around the area enclosed by the curve according to Green’s theorem. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this operator symbolized “del cross f.” A vector field is irrotational if this operator applied to the field is zero everywhere.

q2.quetsion_text: While the curl of a vector field gives another vector field, the divergence of a vector field gives this type of field. This type of quantity has a magnitude but no direction, and is thus contrasted with a vector.

q3.quetsion_text: The cross product is not defined in n-dimensional space unless n equals 3 or this number. This is the maximum number of colors needed to color a map on a torus, according to the Heawood conjecture.

lead_in: Identify the following people encountered by Odysseus and his crew, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: After this guy spurns xenia and eats a bunch of Odysseus’s crew, Odysseus gets him drunk, blinds him, and then claims to be named “outis”, or “nobody”. Later stories describe this Cyclops’s unrequited love for Galatea.

q2.quetsion_text: Hesiod claims that Odysseus fathered two sons, Nausithous and Nausinous, with this nymph during the seven years he spent as a hostage on her island of Ogygia.

q3.quetsion_text: Eleven of Odysseus’s twelve ships are destroyed by these large cannibals, who live on the island of Telepylus and are ruled by King Antiphates.

lead_in: Tertiary amines are often hindered enough that they act as these compounds, not nucleophiles. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these compounds which, according to the Lewis definition, are electron pair donors, and according to the Bronsted-Lowry definition, are proton acceptors. Ammonia is a weak one.
q1.raw_answer: bases [or Lewis bases; or Bronsted-Lowry bases]

q2.quetsion_text: Another way to define bases is that they're compounds which form aqueous solutions in which this quantity is less than the pH. The sum of this quantity and pH equals 14, in water at 25 degrees Celsius.

q3.quetsion_text: When Lewis bases form adducts with Lewis acids, the reaction makes this type of covalent bond, in which both bonding electrons are donated by one molecule. In coordination compounds, this type of bond does not change the oxidation state of a metal.
q3.raw_answer: dative covalent bonds [prompt on coordinate bonds]

lead_in: At the beginning of this poem, Pedro de Valdivia is captured and killed. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this 16th-century epic poem written by Alonso de Ercilla. It focuses on the rebellion of Caupolican against the Spanish in modern-day Chile.

q2.quetsion_text: La Araucana was written during this period of culture, in which the painter Diego Velazquez and the authors Lope de Vega and Miguel de Cervantes flourished.
q2.raw_answer: Spanish Golden Age [or Siglo de Oro]

q3.quetsion_text: During the Spanish Golden Age, this nun worked to reform the Carmelite order. This mystic advocated "mental prayer" in books like The Interior Castle and The Way of Perfection.
q3.raw_answer: Saint Teresa of Avila [or Teresa de Cepeda y Ahumada]

lead_in: Roger Sessions taught music at this university for over two decades, where his students included Edward T. Cone and David Lewin.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this university that was the center of the American academic avant-garde music movement in the mid-20th century. Milton Babbitt taught here for over forty years, and Paul Lansky currently teaches here

q2.quetsion_text: Many of the Princeton composers practiced total serialism, an extension of the twelve-tone technique invented by this founder of the Second Viennese School and composer of Pierrot Lunaire.

q3.quetsion_text: A composer from this country employed serialism in many of his pieces, including The Hammer without a Master. Another composer from here used serialism in the "Modes of Durations and Intensities" movement of his Four Rhythm Studies

lead_in: This modern-day country was where Mykola Skrypnyk shot himself in his apartment rather than recant his policies. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this modern-day country, which as a republic in the 1930’s was the site of a massive famine called the Holodomor. Many historians believe the famine was as a result of Soviet collectivization programs.
q1.raw_answer: Ukraine [or Ukrainian Soviet Socialist Republic, prompt on Soviet Union, prompt on Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, prompt on USSR, do not accept “Russia”]

q2.quetsion_text: The Soviet collectivization programs and the First Five-Year-Plan were the brainchild of this dictator, who led the Soviet Union during World War II.
q2.raw_answer: Joseph Stalin [or Iosif Vissarionovich Stalin; or Ioseb Besarionis dze Jugashvili]

q3.quetsion_text: The Soviet secret police carried out this 1940 massacre of Polish nationals in the namesake Russian woodlands. About 22,000 were slain during it, and the Soviets blamed it on the Nazis.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this location discovered by some plane crash survivors including Mallinson and Miss Brinklow, as well as the World War I veteran Hugh Conway.

q2.quetsion_text: The Tibetan paradise of Shangri-La features prominently in this novel.

q3.quetsion_text: This author of Lost Horizon wrote about a teacher at Brookfield that marries Katherine in Goodbye, Mr. Chips.

lead_in: Answer some questions about the antagonists of Bugs Bunny

q1.quetsion_text: This incompetent hunter's difficulties with pronouncing the letter "r" are amply demonstrated in his catchphrase: "Be vewy, vewy quiet. I'm huting wabbits."

q2.quetsion_text: In "Water, Water Every Hare" and one other short, Bugs Bunny twice faces off against the creation of a mad scientist: an orange monster made entirely out of this substance.

q3.quetsion_text: In "Operation: Rabbit" and four other shorts, Bugs was paired with Wile E. Coyote, who is known for his attempts to capture the Road Runner using perpetually-malfunctioning gadgets bought from this company

lead_in: This author used Attar's The Conference of the Birds as a structural inspiration for his first novel, Grimus.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this British-Indian author of Midnight's Children, who had a fatwa issued against him by Ayatollah Khomeini over the heretical content of his The Satanic Verses.

q2.quetsion_text: Rushdie described his life during the fatwa, including his marriage to Padma Lakshmi, in this memoir, which was released in 2012.

q3.quetsion_text: This English author of the novel G. condemned Rushdie for not discontinuing publication of The Satanic Verses. He collaborated with Mike Dibb on the book and TV series Ways of Seeing, which analyzed art ideology.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name these beings exemplified by Iblis, who became known as Shaytan after his expulsion. The seventy-second sura discusses these beings, which include the qarīn that tempt individual people.

q2.quetsion_text: The suing of jinn is occasionally taken seriously in Saudi Arabia, where Islamic law, also known by this term, is implemented. It is considered the infallible law of God, in contrast to human interpretations, or fiqh.

q3.quetsion_text: If you want to sue a jinn for damages, you can go before one of these Islamic judges, who will hopefully laugh you out of the courtroom.These judges are responsible for applying fiqh and the fatwas of muftis.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this novel in which the wheelchair-bound historian Lyman Ward complains about the morals of his assistant Peggy and narrates a biography of his grandmother, the artist Susan Ward.

q2.quetsion_text: This American author of Angle of Repose also wrote The Spectator Bird.

q3.quetsion_text: One of Stegner's students at Stanford was this author who wrote about the Stamper family in Sometimes a Great Notion and about the sadistic Nurse Ratched in One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest.

lead_in: Answer some questions about Roman music, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: The Roman school of polyphony was led by this Renaissance composer, whose Pope Marcellus Mass was said to have "saved polyphony".

q2.quetsion_text: This Italian composer's Roman Trilogy consists of Pines of Rome, Fountains of Rome, and Roman Festivals.

q3.quetsion_text: A trip to Rome inspired this Tchaikovsky orchestral work, which opens with a bugle call inspired by the Italian cavalry and includes a rousing tarantella.
q3.raw_answer: Capriccio Italien, Op. 45 [accept either underlined portion]

lead_in: The solid-liquid line on this compound’s phase diagram has a negative slope. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this compound which is removed from mixtures using desiccants. It freezes at 0 Celsius and boils at 100 Celsius.

q2.quetsion_text: Water belongs in one of these constructs denoted C2v. These constructs are used to classify molecules based on their internal planes of symmetry, and they’re used to generate character tables.

q3.quetsion_text: This molecule, which belongs to the point group C3v, is synthesized industrially using an iron-based catalyst in the Haber-Bosch process.

lead_in: This compound transfers carbon dioxide to pyruvate as a prosthetic group for pyruvate decarboxylase. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this B vitamin consisting of an imidazoline ring fused to a sulfur containing ring with a valerate side chain. It has an extremely high affinity for avidin and streptavidin.
q1.raw_answer: biotin [or vitamin B7; or vitamin H]

q2.quetsion_text: Secondary antibodies can be linked to biotin, then hybridize to primary antibodies, in this analytical technique used to detect the presence of a given protein. Horseradish peroxidase is a common reporter for this technique. It was not named for a biologist.

q3.quetsion_text: Horseradish peroxidase is useful because, in addition to amplifying a signal, it catalyzes an oxidation reaction that results in this phenomenon, the production of light. Luciferase catalyzes this process in fireflies.

lead_in: The speaker of this poem recalls his fear of "the chronic angers of that house" while describing a figure whom "no one ever thanked." For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this poem about a figure who "got up early / and put his clothes on in the blueblack cold." This poem concludes with the speaker reflecting, "What did I know, what did I know / of love's austere and lonely offices?"

q2.quetsion_text: "Those Winter Sundays" is about Robert Hayden's relationship with this kind of person, also exemplified by a man who can't come up with a story in a Li-Young Lee poem. One is called "a man in black with a Meinkampf look" in a Sylvia Plath poem.
q2.raw_answer: the poet's father [or daddy or other equivalents]

q3.quetsion_text: The speaker describes a father who can "drown a bug in one spit of tobacco juice" in "Old Florist," one of this author's many "greenhouse poems." He describe a person who "played it light and loose" and "cast a shadow white as stone," the "sickle" to the speaker's "rake" in "I Knew a Woman."

lead_in: In Sylvia Townsend Warner's Kingdoms of Elfin, this place is Queen Melior's elfin court, where a pair of eunuchs engage in a fight to the death after sorcerer destroys the cocks used in a cockfight. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this mythical forest that is supposedly the home of the tomb of Merlin. In a Chretien de Troyes story, Yvain pours spring water onto a giant slab and a thunderstorm terrorizes this place.

q2.quetsion_text: Broceliande is a forest in this region of France, whose own mythology includes a story about the devil unleashing torrents of water to flood the mythical city of Ys.

q3.quetsion_text: These shape-shifting water-sprites of Breton folklore are thought to be the spirits of druids who opposed Christianity. They can be snuffed out if you ask them to name the days of the week, "for they will try to change the subject."
q3.raw_answer: korrigan [or korandon, ozigan, nozigan or torrigan if you believe Wikipedia]

lead_in: This government was decisively defeated at the Battle of Toba-Fushimi. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this government whose founder and namesake won the Battle of Sekigahara. It lost to supporters of imperial rule in the Boshin War.

q2.quetsion_text: In the Tokugawa shogunate, the daimyo were at the top, followed by this warrior-caste. People in this class followed the warrior code of bushido.

q3.quetsion_text: From 1614 to 1615, the Tokugawa shogunate destroyed the Toyotomi clan by besieging this castle, whose namesake city was a major rice trading center in the Edo period.

lead_in: Two flasks are used in this process, though the receiving flask is usually kept at a much lower temperature.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this method of separating a liquid mixture based on the volatility of each component. It can be used to purify ethanol.

q2.quetsion_text: The overhead from a laboratory-scale distillation is fed into this long tube leading to the receiving flask. Liebig names a common type of this piece of glassware. In it, the vapor is converted back into a liquid product.

q3.quetsion_text: In a laboratory, liquids to be distilled or refluxed are usually kept in this type of flask, which gives the most uniform heating. Unlike Erlenmeyer flasks, they have to be clamped down while in use; otherwise, they fall over.

lead_in: Henry Moore's Nuclear Energy and Jean Dubuffet's Monument with Standing Beast are both located in this city. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Midwestern city whose Art Institute is home to Lorado Taft's Fountain of the Great Lakes and whose United Center is home to Omri Amrany's The Spirit, a statue of Michael Jordan.

q2.quetsion_text: The centerpiece of Chicago's Millennium Park is this liquid mercury-inspired stainless steel sculpture by Anish Kapoor, which strongly resembles a large bean. Its underside contains a reflection-distorting "omphalos".

q3.quetsion_text: This Catalan artist created a sculpture formerly titled The Sun, the Moon, and One Star that is now known as his Chicago. The Philadelphia Museum of Art is now home to his painting Dog Barking at the Moon.

lead_in: In one of this man's works, an aspirin salesman kills a child with his car, becomes afraid of cars, and is cured when a psychiatrist teaches him to hate children; in another, an incredibly stupid boy becomes a famous soccer referee. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this fictional character, an eccentric Argentine-hating Bolivian who is hired by Panamerica to create soap operas.
q1.raw_answer: Pedro Camacho [accept either underlined portion; prompt on BUT DO NOT OTHERWISE REVEAL "the Scriptwriter"]

q2.quetsion_text: Pedro Camacho is the second title character of this 1977 novel, whose autobiographically-inspired narrator marries the first title character.
q2.raw_answer: Aunt Julia and the Scriptwriter [or La Tia Julia y el Escribidor]

q3.quetsion_text: Aunt Julia and the Scriptwriter was written by this Peruvian Nobel Laureate, whose other novels include The Green House and The Time of the Hero.
q3.raw_answer: Mario Vargas Llosa [or Jorge Mario Pedro Vargas Llosa, 1st Marquis of Vargas Llosa; prompt on partial answer]

lead_in: This composer replaced the catchy "Alleluia sur la trompette, alleluia sur la cymbale" movement of his symphony L'ascension with the even more fun "Transports de joie" when he transcribed it for organ. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this 20th-century French composer of the Quartet for the End of Time.

q2.quetsion_text: Messiaen included a proto-serialist piece titled for these musical concepts "of values and intensities" in his Quatre études de rythme. In general, he used several of them "of limited transposition," such as the octatonic scale.

q3.quetsion_text: Messiaen's serialist pupils included Pierre Boulez, who wrote Le marteau sans maître and this piece, which begins with the dramatic "Don" and includes his three "Improvisations sur Mallarmé."
q3.raw_answer: Pli selon pli [accept Fold by Fold or Fold upon Fold]

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: 90s one hit wonder Haddaway is most famous for this song, which was memorably used in the Night at the Roxbury SNL sketch. The title question is followed with the line, "Baby, don't hurt me."

q2.quetsion_text: This band's hit "Flagpole Sitta" declared "I'm not sick, but I'm not well." Their album King James Version is really good.

q3.quetsion_text: This band, which seems to mostly be one dude messing around in a studio, had the B.B. King-sampling hit "Standing Outside a Broken Phonebooth with Money in My Hand."

lead_in: Since the 1950s, many trade treaties have included provisions that disputes between countries and companies would be resolved by independent arbitrators. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: In 2003, CPI, Cargill and ADM sued the government of Mexico for levying a tax on products that contained this substance. Pepsi Throwback replaces this now-common sweetener with sugar.
q1.raw_answer: high fructose corn syrup [or HFCS; or glucose-fructose; or isogluclose; or corn sugar]

q2.quetsion_text: A 2009 Australian law that mandated plain-paper packaging for these products sparked a multi-billion dollar arbitration case from an American company. Companies that manufacture these products were once obligated to fund TheTruth.com in the US.

q3.quetsion_text: Vattenfall, a company in this industry, is suing Germany for Germany's 2012 plan to phase out this industry. Watts Bar 1 in Tennessee was the last investment in this industry to go online in the United States.
q3.raw_answer: nuclear power [or nuclear energy; prompt on energy]

lead_in: The number 6943 appears in the center of his work States of Mind I: The Farewells, and he portrayed suburban construction in The City Rises.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this artist who depicted a walking man in bronze in Unique Forms of Continuity in Space. A sculpture of his fist was created by his colleague Giacomo Balla.

q2.quetsion_text: Boccioni was a member of this early-20th-century Italian art movement whose work depicted technology, speed, and violence, and whose manifesto was written by Filippo Marinetti.

q3.quetsion_text: A red and black-dominated painting by futurist Carlo CarrÃ  depicts one of these events involving the anarchist Angelo Galli. An unfinished 1867 painting by Manet depicts the one involving Charles Baudelaire.

lead_in: This song is sometimes known by its first line, "Vedi! Le fosche notturne", and it describes how women turn days from gloom to bright sunshine. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this piece from act 2, scene 1 of Il Trovatore, in which a group of Spanish Gypsies set to work.
q1.raw_answer: the "Anvil Chorus" [prompt on "the Gypsy Chorus" or "Coro di Zingari"]

q2.quetsion_text: Il Trovatore was composed by this Italian, whose other operas include Rigoletto and Aida.

q3.quetsion_text: Il Trovatore also features the aria "Di quella pira", in which Manrico vows to save his mother Azucena from this fate. This fate also befalls Pollione and Norma at the end of a Vincenzo Bellini opera.
q3.raw_answer: being burned at the stake [or being burned on a (funeral) pyre; or other obvious equivalents involving being burned to death]

lead_in: In one painting, a team of horses pull a cart through a river in the foreground while rainbow arcs over this building in the background. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this building, pictured "from the Meadows" and "from the Bishops' Grounds" in two nineteenth-century paintings by the same artist. It features the tallest church spire in the United Kingdom.

q2.quetsion_text: Those depictions of Salisbury Cathedral were painted by this English landscape artist, whose many depictions of the Stour River valley include The Lock, Willy Lott's Cottage, and The Hay Wain.

q3.quetsion_text: Constable included a gypsy woman tending to a cooking fire in his second painting titled for this specific location in the Stour Valley, which was completed 26 years after an 1802 depiction of a copse of trees here.
q3.raw_answer: Dedham Vale [or The Vale of Dedham]

lead_in: This agreement caused the St. John's and Mi'kmaq tribes to provide troops for the Continental Army and was signed in the namesake Massachusetts city. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this July 19, 1776 treaty, the first foreign agreement of the newly established United States.

q2.quetsion_text: The St. John's and Mi'kmaq tribes are among those that composed this five-nation confederacy that primarily resided in Maine and Nova Scotia. It was the eastern neighbor of the Iroquois Confederacy.

q3.quetsion_text: Many Wabanaki resided in this French colony, many of whose residents became Cajuns in Louisiana after they were expelled during the French and Indian War.

lead_in: Because the frequency of these objects' emitted light decreases with their size, they can be tuned to produce different colors. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these nanoparticles which behave like particles-in-a-box. These objects fluoresce when electrons fall in energy from the conduction band back to the valence band.

q2.quetsion_text: Quantum dots are made from this type of material, which has electrical properties that are intermediate between an insulator and a conductor.

q3.quetsion_text: Highly conjugated organic molecules also behave like particles-in-a-box and can fluoresce. Conjugation usually requires this type of bond, which forms when p orbitals overlap parallel to the bonding axis.

lead_in: This culture preserved several human "trophy heads" that were probably suspended with a rope that ran through a hole in the forehead.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this culture better known for the geoglyphs it created in a namesake desert.

q2.quetsion_text: The Nazca culture was based in this modern-day country. This country was also home to a civilization that built the city of Machu Picchu.

q3.quetsion_text: This legendary Sapa Inca was the founder of the Kingdom of Cusco. Some tales suggest that this man and his sister-wife Mama Ocllo built a temple to the sun god Inti at Inti's instruction.

lead_in: In Solzhenitsyn's Gulag Archipelago, this word is said to "descend from the judicial bench like the blade of a guillotine, stopping short of beheading the prisoner but breaking the spine." For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this penal labor camp system based mainly in Siberia that was started in 17th century tsarist Russia. Its name, which is Greek for "galley," was reintroduced in 1943 by Stalin.

q2.quetsion_text: While serving as aide-de-camp to the governor of Transbaikalia in the Russian Far East, this anarchist author of The Conquest of Bread inspected the katorga system and compared it to the French penal system.

q3.quetsion_text: This katorga alum was exiled to Omsk, an experience mirrored by a man he wrote about, Rodion Raskolnikov.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this condition which sees both the stomach and small intestine become inflamed, resulting in diarrhea and vomiting.

q2.quetsion_text: Gastroenteritis is most commonly caused by this viral genus in the family Reoviridae. that is the most common cause of diarrhea in small children.

q3.quetsion_text: Another form of gastroenteritis is traveller's diarrhea, which is most commonly caused by the enterotoxigenic version of this bacteria closely related to Salmonella. It often causes food poisoning and occasionally spurs recalls of farm products.

q1.quetsion_text: Good programming practice usually involves leaving these notes in the source code that are removed during compilation. In most languages, you can begin an inline one with two forward slashes.

q2.quetsion_text: Establishing a naming convention for variables is a good practice. This convention for variables with multiple words keeps the first word's first letter lower case, but has every other word's first letter capitalized.
q2.raw_answer: camel case [or mixedCase; or compoundNames; or camelBack]

q3.quetsion_text: For a large code base, it is important to periodically do this. This process is the improvement of existing code without changing its functionality and may involve the rewriting of several classes into smaller classes.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this plan cooked up by Winfield Scott, which involved surrounding the Confederacy by sea and cutting it in half by controlling the Mississippi river.

q2.quetsion_text: A major step in the Anaconda Plan was capturing this key Mississippi city. Its commander, John C. Pemberton, surrendered to Grant on July 4, 1863, supposedly causing this city to not celebrate the 4th of July until 1945.

q3.quetsion_text: At the same time as the Siege of Vicksburg, this Confederate commander conducted his namesake raid into Indiana and Ohio. He won at the Battle of Corydon but was captured at Salineville, after which he used an air shaft to escape from the Ohio Penitentiary.

lead_in: After the adoption of this tactical mode of organization, Roman soldiers were organized into lines of hastati, principes, and triarii.

q1.quetsion_text: Name these tactical units of a Roman legion, which consisted of 120 men each, typically organized into a formation 3 deep and 40 wide.

q2.quetsion_text: The Romans adapted the manipular formation from the tactics employed by this Italic people, who dealt a massive defeat to the Romans at the Battle of Caudine Forks. This people was the largest group of the socii to revolt.

q3.quetsion_text: The manipular formation replaced this formation in the Roman army. This formation was employed by both hoplites and sarissa-wielding pikemen, and was designed to project an impenetrable front of spears.

lead_in: Answer the following about weird Asian mythical animals,

q1.quetsion_text: This person was guided by the yata-garasu, a three-legged crow from the region of Kumano. The rise of this person brought an end to the Age of the Gods.

q2.quetsion_text: Kumiho are Korean varieties of these animals that frequently transform into beautiful women to seduce men and then eat their livers or hearts. The kami Inari uses these animals as messengers.

q3.quetsion_text: The fenghuang is often considered a Chinese example of this kind of fiery bird, which is reborn when it arises from its own ashes.

lead_in: Answer the following about Wilhelm Wundt, whose pre-Freudian innovations lead some to call him the "father of modern psychology,"

q1.quetsion_text: Wundt pioneered the use of this method to study the mind in his lab at Leipzig. In modern terms, this method uses a control group and manipulates an independent variable to see the effects on a dependent variable.
q1.raw_answer: experiment al method [or controlled experiment s; or experiment al study; or obvious equivalents mentioning experiment ]

q2.quetsion_text: Wundt advocated this key method of structuralist psychology, in which a person reflects on their own thoughts to isolate the component parts of their conscious experience.

q3.quetsion_text: This British student of Wilhelm Wundt translated Wundt's work into English, warning about the effects of "stimulus error" on introspection and coining the term "empathy" in the process.
q3.raw_answer: Edward B. Titchener [or Edward Bradford Titchener ]

lead_in: A hydride shift is an example of this type of reaction. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this type of reaction, in which the carbon skeleton of a molecule undergoes a change. Two pericyclic examples of this type of reaction are the sigmatropic Cope and Claisen reactions.

q2.quetsion_text: This rearrangement involves the loss of nitrogen from an alpha-diazo-carbonyl compound and the 1,2- rearrangement of an alkyl group to generate a ketene. This reaction is also an intermediate step in a separate one-carbon homologation of carboxylic acids.
q2.raw_answer: Wolff rearrangement [the homologation is the Arndt-Eistert synthesis]

q3.quetsion_text: For a rearrangement to be pericyclic, it must possess a cyclic transition state and also possess this property. SN2 reactions have this property, but SN1 reactions do not.
q3.raw_answer: concerted [or one step or single step or any clear equivalents]

lead_in: Israel's official policy of "ambiguity" and its unrecognized facility at Dimona are two reasons why it has never become a signatory to this treaty. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this treaty from which North Korea withdrew in 2003 after announcing tests at the Yongbyon site. It preceded the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty.
q1.raw_answer: Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons [or Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty]

q2.quetsion_text: This man was captured in Italy by Mossad agents and tried for treason after leaking information about Israel's nuclear program to the British media in 1986.

q3.quetsion_text: These two rival countries, both non-signatories of the Non-Proliferation Treaty, fought the Kargil War against one another in 1999 over land in Kashmir.
q3.raw_answer: Republic of India and Islamic Republic of Pakistan [accept Ganarajya Bharat in place of "India"]

lead_in: A couple shepherds and umbrella pine trees were added to a painting showing the lone surviving arch of the Ponte d'Augusto in this city. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: A "view at" what Umbrian city was painted by the teacher of Berthe Morisot and Camille Pissarro?

q2.quetsion_text: This French artist painted the plein air preparatory sketch The Bridge at Narni and the later landscape View at Narni.

q3.quetsion_text: This fellow member of the Barbizon School with Corot showed a peasant man striding through a freshly tilled field in The Sower, and three peasant women doubled over as they pick up leftover bits of wheat in The Gleaners.

lead_in: The arrangement of figures in this painting suggests a possible familiarity with Pieter Bruegel the Elder’s The Blind Leading the Blind. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this 1919 painting, in which a row of nine wounded World War I soldiers with bandages over their eyes walk in a line along a duckboard towards a dressing station.

q2.quetsion_text: Gassed is a work of this expatriate American painter of Carnation, Lily, Lily, Rose and The Daughters of Edward Darley Boit, who scandalized Paris Salon-goers with a portrait of Virginie Gautreau called Madame X.

q3.quetsion_text: Sargent painted murals for the Public Library and the Museum of Fine Arts in this New England city. His El Jaleo is in its Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum.

lead_in: This man bashed the New Left in his book Slouching Towards Gomorrah. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Solicitor General, who as Acting Attorney General fired Special Prosecutor Archibald Cox in the Saturday Night Massacre. In 1987, Ted Kennedy claimed this judge envisioned a land where “women would be forced into back-alley abortions.”

q2.quetsion_text: The term “to bork” Supreme Court nominees was also used in 1991 in reference to the contentious hearings regarding this African American attorney accused of sexually harassing Anita Hill. He is still on the Supreme Court.

q3.quetsion_text: A 1988 privacy protection act about this practice was enacted partly because the Bork confirmation hearings leaked Bork’s history of this practice to the press, even though it was completely innocuous.
q3.raw_answer: video rental history [accept anything involving renting videos or movies]

lead_in: Alexander Pope's work of this type was produced a decade after his rendition of an earlier work, but was half ghost-written by William Broome and Elijah Fenton.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this type of work. Robert Fagles used the phrase "man of twists and turns" in the opening lines, for a phrase which Robert Fitzgerald rendered as "man skilled in all ways of contending".
q1.raw_answer: translation of Homer's Odyssey into English

q2.quetsion_text: This Russian author's Notes on Prosody accompanied his much-maligned translation of Eugene Onegin. He was responsible for the Russian translation of his own novel Lolita.

q3.quetsion_text: This woman was called the "Glenn Gould" of translators by Harold Bloom for her translation of Don Quixote. Along with Gregory Rabassa, she is the standard English translator of Gabriel Garcia Marquez.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this novel in which a woman must decide which of her two children will live when she enters Auschwitz. Years later in Brooklyn, the title character forms a suicide pact with her schizophrenic lover Nathan Landau.

q2.quetsion_text: Sophie's Choice was written by William Styron, who also authored a controversial novel titled for the Confessions of this historical figure, who launched the largest slave insurrection in US history.

q3.quetsion_text: Styron's story "A Tidewater Morning" can be compared to "Dry September", a short story by this other American author about a lynching. This man's story "Delta Autumn" is set just before the 1940 presidential election.

lead_in: The strength of these forces increases with the size of the molecules involved since polarizability in general increases with the volume of the electron cloud. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this type of van der Waals force that arises due to the formation of instantaneous dipoles, which induce dipoles in neighboring molecules. They are the only significant intermolecular attractive force present in noble gas atoms.

q2.quetsion_text: The magnitude of a London dispersion force depends on the polarizability of the molecules involved, the distance between them, and this other quantity for the molecules. This quantity is equal to minus the energy of the HOMO according to Koopmans’ theorem.

q3.quetsion_text: The strength of London dispersion forces varies with the inverse of the distance between them raised to this power. The cycloalkane with this many carbons has a stable chair and unstable boat conformation.

lead_in: Answer the following about everyone’s favorite guild confederation, the Hanseatic League for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: The Hanseatic League’s “capital” was at this Germanic port in Schleswig-Holstein. Willy Brandt was born in this city.

q2.quetsion_text: The Hanseatic League became embroiled in the raids of the Victual Brothers, privateers hired by Albert of Mecklenburg to attack the ships of Margaret I, a queen of this country.

q3.quetsion_text: Margaret I later founded the Kalmar Union and united Denmark, Norway, and this other Scandinavian country.

lead_in: One of these entities titles a Gustav Meyrink novel about Athanasius Pernath, while another is created by the title character of Cynthia Ozick's The Puttermesser Papers. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these entities. In a Michael Chabon novel, Kornblum helps Joe Kavalier smuggle himself out of Prague in a coffin containing the most famous one of them.

q2.quetsion_text: This author described Judah Loew's creation of the golem in his Cratylus-inspired poem "El Golem". More famous stories by this blind Argentinean include "El Aleph" and "The Garden of Forking Paths".
q2.raw_answer: Jorge Luis Borges [or Jorge Francisco Isidoro Luis Borges]

q3.quetsion_text: This Borges character wrote a treatise on chess proposing the removal of one of the rook's pawns, but is more famous for attempting to organically replicate parts of the novel Don Quixote by reliving the experiences of Cervantes.

lead_in: This man argued that slavery was institutionalized in the constitutions of neither the federal nor the slave states in The Unconstitutionality of Slavery. For 10 points each:

lead_in: Evidence of this phenomenon at mid-oceanic ridges confirmed the theory of seafloor spreading. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this process, recent examples of which include the Brunhes-Matuyama and Laschamp events. It divides the geologic time scale into periods known as chrons, and its historical distribution implies stochastic behavior.
q1.raw_answer: geomagnetic reversal [accept equivalent descriptions like the Earth's magnetic field flipping poles; prompt on partial answers]

q2.quetsion_text: This term refers to a partial or total reversal of the Earth's magnetic field that lasts only a few thousand years. The Laschamp and Pringle Falls events are considered examples of these happenings.

q3.quetsion_text: This model, named for its two formulators, is the standard computer simulation used for studying geomagnetic reversals. It is a time-dependent numerical solution of the 3-D MHD equations describing a self-sustaining dynamo.

lead_in: This type of differential equation problem involves finding the solution to an ODE given the value of the function of interest at the starting point or time.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this type of differential equation problem that contrasts with a boundary-value problem.
q1.raw_answer: IVP [or initial-value problem; or Cauchy problem]

q2.quetsion_text: A big deal for IVPs is whether a problem is well-posed, which is the case if a solution exists, if the solution depends on the data, and if the solution has this property. It means that there is one Â– and only one Â– solution.

q3.quetsion_text: Picard's existence theorem guarantees that a solution exists and is unique for a first-order IVP if the derivative of the function has this form of continuity. It requires that the difference at any two points on a function be less than or equal to a rational number multiplied by the difference in independent variable.

lead_in: Josquin used this technique his motet "Alma redemptoris mater/Ave regina caelorum." For 10 points each:

q3.quetsion_text: One of the innovations of the Ars Nova was imperfect mensuration, the sign for which looks like a "C." That sign, which is often misunderstood to stand for "common time," is now used to denote a measure with this number of beats.

lead_in: This statement is proved by building a DFA, then invoking the pigeonhole principle to show that there must be some portion of the DFA that can be repeatedly traversed over and over. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this statement that is used to prove the non-regularity of certain languages.

q2.quetsion_text: Regular languages are closed under union, intersection, and this other operation, which returns the set of all strings that can be formed by taking the union with the original language.

q3.quetsion_text: Regular languages are also closed under this other operation, in which each symbol of the alphabet is mapped to a letter of a different alphabet. Although the property of being closed under this operation isn't useful in proofs by itself, the property of being closed under the inverse of this operation can be used to prove the regularity of non-trivial languages.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this signaling molecule, whose levels in bacteria fluctuate based on whether glucose or lactose is being metabolized. This second messenger is synthesized by adenylyl cyclase.

lead_in: Compatibilization procedures can be used to impart this property to two polymers that would otherwise not be capable of it. For 10 points:

q2.quetsion_text: The immiscibility of two liquids is key to the liquid-liquid form of this procedure, which involves a solute moving from one solvent to another as they are brought into contact. The more contact between the two phases, the greater the efficiency of this process.

q3.quetsion_text: Useful in understanding extraction systems, this law states that, for a solute and two immiscible solvents, the ratio of the concentrations of the solute in each solvent equals a constant.
q3.raw_answer: Nernst distribution law [accept distribution law; prompt on "Nernst('s law)"]

lead_in: One of his recurring protagonists recalls learning about sex from an Ojibwe girl named Tracy in the story "Fathers and Sons".

lead_in: Answer these questions about changes within the military of the late Roman republic, for 10 points each.

lead_in: This series of events was motivated by Savonarola's prophetic preaching against the church of Pope Alexander VI.

lead_in: This historical region between the Dniester and Prut rivers was split off of Moldavia when Moldavia united with Wallachia to become Romania in the mid-19th century.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this massive silver deposit whose output continued until the mid-1880s.

q2.quetsion_text: The Comstock lode was in this modern-day state, where a mint in the capital city helped fund the Civil War. Gangster Bugsy Siegel helped finance casinos along The Strip in this state.

q3.quetsion_text: This businessman's father, George, earned his fortune in a mining company at the Comstock Lode. This husband of the chorus girl Millicent Willson had a lavish residence designed by Julia Morgan.

lead_in: Answer the following about the U.S. space program in the years just after the first moon landing,

q1.quetsion_text: This program, which launched three astronauts at a time atop Saturn V rockets, included all successful moon landings. Its dramatic mission numbered 13 was termed "a successful failure."
q1.raw_answer: Apollo Program [or Project Apollo; accept equivalents mentioning "Apollo"]

q2.quetsion_text: This pilot of Freedom 7, the first manned Mercury mission, later became the oldest man on the moon as commander of Apollo 14. He used a scoop to hit golf balls on the lunar surface.

q3.quetsion_text: This last set of manned Soviet missions teamed up with the Apollo program for a 1975 Test Project illustrating detente. The APAS docking mechanism was designed for the nineteenth mission of this name, letting Tom Stafford and Alexey Leonov shake hands.
q3.raw_answer: Soyuz [or Soyuz 19; or Apollo-Soyuz Test Project; or Apollo-Soyuz mission; or Eksperimantalniy Polyot Soyuz-Apollon; prompt on "ASTP"; prompt on "Union"]

lead_in: Kapitonov and Jurka discovered helitrons in this organism, and the "b-z" locus is an oft-studied region on its chromosome 9. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this organism. The genome of the B73 strain of this organism was released in a landmark 2009 paper by Schnable et al., and strains of this organism are often categorized as "SS" or "NSS."
q1.raw_answer: maize [or corn; accept Zea mays or Z. mays]

q2.quetsion_text: This cytogeneticist discovered the role of transposons in maize using the Ac/Ds system. She also produced the first genetic map for maize, and is the only woman to be awarded an unshared Nobel in Physiology and Medicine.

q3.quetsion_text: Helitron transposons in maize replicate using this type of DNA replication, which results in a single strand of DNA. It is not theta replication, but the lambda phage replicates using this process during lytic development.
q3.raw_answer: rolling-circle replication [accept rolling-circle amplification or RCA or RCR]

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this daughter of Tantalus who lost her many children to Apollo and Artemis.

q2.quetsion_text: Niobe's husband, Amphion, used a lyre to build the walls of this city. This city was founded by Cadmus.

q3.quetsion_text: Niobe lost all her children after she boasted that no one in her city should worship this goddess, since Niobe had ten more children than she did.

lead_in: The fringe separation in a certain experiment is equal to the order times wavelength times screen distance divided by this value.

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this value multiplied by the sine of the angle and set equal to the order times wavelength as the condition for the existence of a bright fringe.
q1.raw_answer: double slit separation [or obvious equivalents, such as the distance between the two slits; prompt on small d]

q2.quetsion_text: The double slit experiment was performed by this English scientist.

q3.quetsion_text: Claus JÃ¶nsson was the first physicist to perform the double-slit experiment with these particles instead of photons, a now-common setup. A thought experiment due to Feynman illustrates wave-particle duality by considering passing individual ones of these particles through the double-slit, which will create a diffraction pattern because each one passes through both slits, despite the fact that, classically, each one can only pass through one slit.

lead_in: A polylinker on these structures allows them to be used as cloning vectors.

q1.quetsion_text: Name these circular pieces of DNA in bacteria that are replicated independently of the chromosomal DNA.

q2.quetsion_text: This term refers to cells that can uptake plasmid DNA during transformation. Calcium chloride can be used to induce bacteria to have this property.
q2.raw_answer: competent cells [or competence; or word forms]

q3.quetsion_text: Another method of making bacteria transform plasmid DNA is this one, in which the cell is rapidly shocked, which increases the membrane's permeability for a short duration.

lead_in: This philosopher distinguished between political society and civil society in The Philosophy of Right.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this German philosopher who examined the progress of consciousness towards absolute knowledge of the "other" in The Phenomenology of Spirit.

q2.quetsion_text: In his Lectures on the Philosophy of History, Hegel described Alexander, Caesar, and this figure as "men of action" necessary for the progress of humanity. Hegel also called this man a "world-spirit ... who stretches over the world and dominates it" when witnessing this man's entry into Jena.

q3.quetsion_text: Hegel was influenced by this other German philosopher, who he succeeded as philosophy chair in Berlin. This man argued that self-consciousness requires anstoss, a repulsive awareness of its limitations in Foundations of Natural Right and his Wissenschaftslehre.

lead_in: This character, who is referred to as a “little squirrel” by her husband, once forged her father’s signature to obtain a loan, a fact over which she is blackmailed by Nils Krogstad. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this character who slams the door as she leaves her husband Torvald at the end of an 1879 play.
q1.raw_answer: Nora Helmer [prompt on “Helmer”; accept Nora Helmer]

q2.quetsion_text: Nora Helmer is the protagonist of this Norwegian’s play A Doll’s House.

q3.quetsion_text: This Austrian author’s first play is a sequel to A Doll’s House called What Happened After Nora Left Her Husband. This reclusive author of The Piano Teacher won the 2004 Lit Nobel.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this comprehensive literary study by Erich Auerbach that examined the ways in which Western writers depicted the everyday lives of people.
q1.raw_answer: Mimesis: The Representation of Reality in Western Literature

q2.quetsion_text: The last section of Mimesis discusses Proust's In Search of Lost Time and this author's novel To The Lighthouse.

q3.quetsion_text: Woolf created the character of Judith Shakespeare in this feminist essay to show that a woman with Shakespeare's talent would not be as successful due to limited opportunities. It posits that the title location is necessary to a woman if "she is to write fiction."

lead_in: On the last day of this five-day long festival, brothers and sisters give each others blessings and gifts. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Indian "festival of lights," which commemorates, among other things, Rama's victory over Ravana, and the birthday of Lakshmi.

q2.quetsion_text: The celebration of the defeat of Naraka is the aspect of Diwali most significant to members of this South Indian ethnic group, who are fond of worshiping Shiva's six-faced son Murugan.

q3.quetsion_text: In Bengal, the Lakshmi Puja component of Diwali has largely been superseded by a festival to this scary-looking deity, oft-depicted with one foot on Shiva's chest.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Ezekiel is commanded to prophesy against this pair, the leader of Meshech and Tubal, and the land from whence he comes. The first member of this pair is allied with nations like Persia, Ethiopia, and Libya against Israel. Jacques Chirac claimed that George W. Bush invoked this pair as justification for invading Iraq.
q1.raw_answer: Gog and Magog (Gog is the leader; Magog is the land)

q2.quetsion_text: Ezekiel sees the dead resurrected in this place before seeing Gog and Magog destroyed.

q3.quetsion_text: The Book of Ezekiel begins with one of these conveyances coming out of a cloud of fire, pulled by creatures with the faces of a man, a lion, an ox, and an eagle.

lead_in: Complete the following lines from Allen Ginsberg's "Howl," for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: "Howl" begins with Ginsberg observation that he saw the best minds of his generation destroyed by this condition.?

q2.quetsion_text: Part III of "Howl" begins with repeated assertions that Ginsberg is with dedicatee Carl Solomon in this place, a fictionalized psychiatric hospital.

q3.quetsion_text: In a memorable incident from the first section of "Howl," Ginsberg's comrades throw this food "at CCNY lecturers on Dadaism" before presenting themselves "on the granite steps of the madhouse."

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: If a ball is in freefall, then the position of the ball after a time t is given by the initial position plus the initial velocity of the ball times t, plus one-half the acceleration due to gravity times this function of t.

q2.quetsion_text: Of course, since there is air on Earth, the ball will reach a terminal velocity. The force that opposes the weight of the ball is this non-conservative one.
q2.raw_answer: drag [or air resistance; or fluid resistance; prompt on viscosity; prompt on friction]

q3.quetsion_text: For regimes with very small Reynolds numbers, this law states that the drag force on a sphere in a fluid is equal to six pi times the viscosity times the velocity of the object times the radius of the object.

lead_in: Answer these questions about the history of pre-modern astronomy, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This city's astronomers developed a theory of planetary motion during the Chaldean period. Astronomers' tables from here help us date the reign of its ruler Nebuchadnezzar II.

q2.quetsion_text: This civilization's priest-astronomers focused on Venus and the rise of the Pleiades each April. Their base 20 numeral system, including zero, let them notate their Long Count calendar.

q3.quetsion_text: This polymath at the Abbasid House of Wisdom wrote out tables for the planets in Zij al-Sindhind. He also wrote a book on solving for variables, whose al-jabr operation now names "algebra".

lead_in: The ping-pong and ternary-complex mechanisms are unusual models of the interactions of these proteins.

q1.quetsion_text: Name these proteins that bind to substrates and catalyze biological reactions

q2.quetsion_text: Reversible enzyme inhibition occurs in roughly three types: two that are kinda confusing and easily mistakable for one another, and this kind, in which the substrate can't bind to the enzyme when the inhibitor is bound.
q2.raw_answer: competitive inhibition [the other types being uncompetitive and non-competitive inhibition]

q3.quetsion_text: In this kind of irreversible inhibition, an enzyme binds to an intended substrate like normal, but then the fiendish substrate forms a stable covalent bond with the enzyme, knocking it out of commission! Vigabatrin for GABA-T and aspirin for COX 1 and 2 are two examples of this kind of inhibitor.

lead_in: This series of events was motivated by Savonarola's prophetic preaching against the church of Pope Alexander VI.

q1.quetsion_text: Name these massive burnings of supposedly sinful objects like paintings and books. The largest one took place in the Piazza della Signoria on Mardi Gras.
q1.raw_answer: Bonfires of the Vanities [or FalÃ² delle vanitÃ ]

q2.quetsion_text: Savonarola directed the Bonfire of the Vanities in this city, where he helped oust Piero the Unfortunate of this city's ruling Medici family.

q3.quetsion_text: This French king's invasion of Italy seemed to confirm Savonarola's prophetic teaching that a "new Cyrus" would arrive to purge Christians of their sins.
q3.raw_answer: Charles VIII of France [or Charles the Affable]

lead_in: Answer these questions about the influence of Sanskrit culture pretty far away from India,

q1.quetsion_text: The past nine kings of this Southeast Asian country have used the name "Rama," after the mythical character. The British governess Anna Leonowens tutored one king of this nation.

q2.quetsion_text: The name of this older pre-Thai state is derived from Rama's ancestral home in India. It fell to the Burmese in 1768.
q2.raw_answer: Ayutthaya kingdom [the original Sanskrit name is "Ayodhya"]

q3.quetsion_text: Kings of this earlier Southeast Asian empire adopted Sanskrit names such as Jayavarman and Suryavarman. It started a complex irrigation system around Angkor.

lead_in: Russell Conwell delivered the "Acres of Diamonds" speech on the benefits of wealth at many of its meetings.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this turn-of-the-20th-century adult education movement. It involved lecturers and entertainers traveling a "circuit" and speaking to audiences.

q2.quetsion_text: This politician spoke on the Chautauqua circuit until his 1925 death following the Scopes "monkey trial". This Nebraskan delivered the "Cross of Gold" speech at the 1896 Democratic National Convention.

q3.quetsion_text: The Chautauqua gatherings were organized similarly to camp meetings, which held these intense outdoor gatherings during the Second Great Awakening.

lead_in: Answer these questions about transportation, the sentence by which criminals would be shipped to penal colonies far away, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This continent was first used by the British for prison colonies such as New South Wales.

q2.quetsion_text: This French penal colony off of the coast of French Guiana was mainly used for prisoners not of French birth. Alfred Dreyfus was imprisoned here.

q3.quetsion_text: For Londoners, transportation was an alternative to time in this central prison near the Old Bailey, which was burnt during the Gordon Riots.

lead_in: COPI coats vesicles to allow them to transport proteins from the Golgi apparatus to this organelle in a retrograde fashion. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this organelle whose “rough” type is studded with ribosomes. Its membrane is continuous with the outer nuclear membrane.

q2.quetsion_text: The N-linked form of this protein modification process occurs in the endoplasmic reticulum. The Golgi apparatus can use this process to direct proteins toward the lysosome by adding mannose-6-phosphate to them.

q3.quetsion_text: In striated muscle cells, these structures are used to transmit electrical signals from the sarcolemma to the sarcoplasmic reticulum.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name these quasiparticles which are the vibrational modes in condensed systems. Debye was able to better predict heat capacity in the low temperature limit by considering their contributions.

q2.quetsion_text: This type of scattering occurs when light interacts with acoustic oscillations like phonons.

q3.quetsion_text: Brillouin also names a zone which is the representation of a cell in this kind of space, the Fourier transform of direct space.
q3.raw_answer: reciprocal space (accept momentum space or k-space)

lead_in: This operation, which is only defined on a Hilbert space, is analogous to the Poisson bracket from Hamiltonian mechanics. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this operation which for two operators A and B is simply defined as AB minus BA.

q2.quetsion_text: This principle can be explained by the fact that position and momentum obey a canonical commutation relation. It states that the product of the standard deviations of the measurements of position and momentum must be larger than h-bar over 2.
q2.raw_answer: Heisenberg uncertainty principle [either of the two underlined words is sufficient]

q3.quetsion_text: The commutator of position and momentum equals this constant times h-bar. The impedance of a circuit element equals its resistance plus this constant times its reactance, which allows the current through it to be represented using a phasor.
q3.raw_answer: i [or the imaginary unit, or the square root of negative one]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this African-American author of Giovanni's Room who fictionalized his own religious awakening in his most famous novel, Go Tell It on the Mountain.

q2.quetsion_text: This book by Baldwin contains two essays on race relations, "My Dungeon Shook" and "Down on the Cross."

q3.quetsion_text: Baldwin's collection Going to Meet the Man includes this short story whose narrator finally comes to understand his troubled brother, the title character, after watching him play piano at a jazz club in Greenwich Village.

lead_in: Many officers from this country were killed by Soviet troops in the Katyn Massacre. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this country which was ruled largely by the General Government during World War II. Jurgen Stroop liquidated a rebellious Jewish ghetto in this country, where Auschwitz was built.

q2.quetsion_text: This Soviet organization led by Lavrenty Beria orchestrated massive killings of Poles, especially in the Ukraine.
q2.raw_answer: NKVD [or People's Commissariat for Internal Affairs; or Narodnyy Komissariat Vnutrennikh Del]

q3.quetsion_text: Nikita Khrushchev related many of the NKVD's abuses in this address, which denounced the way in which Stalin twisted the system for his own "glorification."
q3.raw_answer: the Secret Speech [or "On the Cult of Personality and its Consequences"; or Khrushchev's Address to the Twentieth Party Congress of the Soviet Union]

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name these semiconductor devices that underlie most modern electronics, coming in BJT and - more commonly - MOSFET varieties.

q2.quetsion_text: The first working transistor was made from this polycrystalline semiconductor found below silicon on the periodic table.

q3.quetsion_text: Schottky diodes consist of a junction between this type of material and a semiconductor. Matching the work function of this material to the underlying semiconductor forms an ohmic contact.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name these recordings which contain an notable eighteen and a half minute gap that was ostensibly created by a mistake of Rose Mary Woods.
q1.raw_answer: Watergate Tapes (or Nixon White House tapes, accept anything indicating that these are recordings of the activities of Richard Nixon which were produced during the Watergate scandal)

q2.quetsion_text: This man's attempts to subpoena the Watergate Tapes led to the Saturday Night Massacre, where both Elliot Richardson and William Ruckelshaus resigned rather than fire him.

q3.quetsion_text: The eighteen and a half minute gap in the tapes conveniently occurred during a discussion between Nixon and this White House Chief of Staff. This self-described "Nixon's son-of-a-bitch" suggested that his boss pardon the draft dodgers on the eve of his resignation.

lead_in: César Franck's Opus 1 contains three pieces in this genre using an early version of his cyclic form. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this genre of Clara Schumann's most famous piece, which was written in G minor. Robert Schumann wrote three pieces, in D minor, F major, and G minor, in this genre.

q2.quetsion_text: This composer revised his First Piano Trio in B major to remove quotations from Beethoven and Schubert songs; his other two piano trios are in C major and C minor. He also composed A German Requiem.

q3.quetsion_text: This composer's rediscovered "Easter Sonata" was recently premiered alongside her extremely difficult Piano Trio in D Minor. This composer of an E-flat major string quartet and the piano cycle Das Jahr had a sibling who wrote two piano trios, in D minor and C minor.
q3.raw_answer: Fanny Hensel [accept Fanny Cäcilie Mendelssohn-Bartholdy or Fanny Mendelssohn-Hensel or Fanny Hensel-Mendelssohn; prompt on "Mendelssohn"]

lead_in: The protagonist of this story throws a brick through a plate-glass window, eats large meal and refuses to pay, is mistaken for a celebrating Yale football fan, and steals a silk umbrella, all to no avail. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this story about a homeless man named Soapy, who initially fails to get himself arrested, then resolves to change his life upon hearing a church organ, but is almost immediately arrested for loitering.

q2.quetsion_text: In this story by the same author, Bill and Sam’s plot to kidnap the title son of Ebenezer Dorset goes awry when the boy turns out to be so obnoxious that they end up paying Dorset to take him back.

q3.quetsion_text: “The Cop and the Anthem” and “The Ransom of Red Chief” were written by this American short story master, whose love of twist endings is expressed most famously in “The Gift of the Magi”.

lead_in: This phenomenon has been most commonly studied at the synapse between CA1 and CA3 neurons in the hippocampus. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this mechanism which increases the connection strength between two neurons. Its early phase involves the incorporation of more AMPA receptors.

q2.quetsion_text: CA3 cells and CA1 cells are connected by Schaffer collaterals, which are these structures. These long nerve fibers conduct impulses between neurons.

q3.quetsion_text: These glutamine receptors appear along with AMPA receptors in synapses. Magnesium blocks this receptor, making it impermeable to calcium and sodium.

lead_in: In a state quarter picture, a man with a walking stick looks at this formation as a bird flies in front of it.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this formation frequently ascended via the Cable Route. It was the subject of a number of photos by Ansel Adams.

q2.quetsion_text: Half Dome is located in this picturesque National Park in California.

q3.quetsion_text: Downstream from Nevada Fall, along the Merced River, lies this Yosemite waterfall, which can be accessed from a popular trail that begins at the Happy Isles. The Emerald Pool is located near this waterfall, which was mistaken for a Philippine waterfall on a 1932 stamp.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this lover of Attis, a Near Eastern goddess of fertility who was later worshipped in Rome.

q2.quetsion_text: This act was done by priests of Cybele in Rome to honor the mythic disfigurement of Attis. Cronus did this to his father Uranus using a sickle.

q3.quetsion_text: This kind of object, apparently containing Magna Mater, was moved from Pessinos in Asia Minor to Rome around 200 BCE to "adopt" her. Elagabalus's sun god was worshipped at this sort of object in Emesa.
q3.raw_answer: a black rock [or black stone; or meteorite; or baetylus]

lead_in: Its large cast of characters includes the American painter Jenny Brown, the fiendish twins Ric and Rac, and 876 Spanish workers in steerage. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this 1962 novel set on the Vera, on the way from Veracruz to Bremerhaven.

q2.quetsion_text: Ship of Fools was the only novel written by this Texas-born author, better known for such shorter works as Noon Wine, “Flowering Judas”, and Pale Horse, Pale Rider.
q2.raw_answer: Katherine Anne Porter [or Callie Russell Porter]

q3.quetsion_text: Ship of Fools, like this other only fully extant novel by a Southern author, was made into a movie starring Vivien Leigh. This Margaret Mitchell novel depicts Scarlett O’Hara’s life in Georgia during and after the Civil War.

lead_in: Much like carboxylic acids, these compounds react with alcohols to form esters. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these functional groups that can be hydrogenated to produce aldehydes using poisoned palladium on barium sulfate. These groups can be thought of as carboxylic acids in which the hydroxyl group is replaced by atoms from a group of elements that are highly electronegative.
q1.raw_answer: acyl halides [or acid halides; accept specific types like acyl chlorides or acid chlorides; prompt on partial answer]

q2.quetsion_text: Acyl chlorides react with quinolines and cyanide to produce these compounds, which are named after the German chemist who names a reaction to produce indoles from o-nitro-toluene and diethyl oxalate using an ethoxide base. These compounds are very useful in the synthesis of the opium-derived natural product papaverine.

q3.quetsion_text: Reissert derivatives are a useful way to prepare aldehydes containing this atom, which has the second- lowest priority in CIP rules. NMR often uses chloroform containing this atom, which is found in heavy water.
q3.raw_answer: deuterium [or D; or 2H; do not accept or prompt on "H2"]

lead_in: Answer the following about murals, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: Perhaps the foremost proponent of Mexican muralism was this painter of the Detroit Industry murals and Man, Controller of the Universe, also known for his turbulent marriage to Frida Kahlo.
q1.raw_answer: Diego Rivera [or, of course, Diego María de la Concepción Juan Nepomuceno Estanislao de la Rivera y Barrientos Acosta y Rodríguez]

q2.quetsion_text: Aaron Douglas’s murals for the Schomburg Center can be found in this American city. Romare Bearden and Jacob Lawrence, the latter of whom painted the Migration Series, also gained fame while working in this city.
q2.raw_answer: New York City [or NYC; reverse-prompt on “Harlem”]

q3.quetsion_text: This Englishman was commissioned to paint the six Manchester Murals after the success of his artistic depiction of Victorian society, the painting Work. He used himself and his wife Emma as models for his The Last of England.

lead_in: Thomas Sterling’s The Evil of the Day is a murder mystery based on this play, in which Bonario rescues Celia from an attempted rape at the hands of the title character. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this play in which the title character enacts an elaborate plan involving faking his own death in order to trick Corbaccio, Corvino, and another greedy inheritance-seeker.

q2.quetsion_text: Volpone and his cunning servant Mosca were created by this Jacobean playwright of Every Man in His Humour, who also wrote about comical scammers in The Alchemist.

q3.quetsion_text: This memorably-named character from Volpone is a doofy English traveler who keeps a detailed diary of his actions. A smarter Englishman, Peregrine, tricks him into hiding under a tortoiseshell to avoid arrest for sedition.
q3.raw_answer: Sir Politick Would-Be [accept either underlined portion]

lead_in: Unlike a related "mezzo" technique, this technique was little used after its circa-1650 invention by Jan van der Velde, until Jean Baptiste Le Prince's guide popularized it France. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this etching variant, a printmaking technique named for the ink-like effects that it renders.

q2.quetsion_text: The term aquatint was coined by this British landscape artist who executed Twelve views of South Wales. Along with his brother Thomas, this "Father of English watercolour" produced several paintings of Windsor Castle.

q3.quetsion_text: This man produced aquatints such as Look How Solemn They Are! and The Sleep of Reason Produces Monsters as a part of his Los Caprichos series. He also painted The Third of May, 1808.

lead_in: Dozens of people huddle under Mary's robes while angels stand behind her in this artist's Virgin of Mercy. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this painter, who worked with his brother-in-law, Simone Martini, on an Annunciation including St. Margaret and St. Anansus.

q2.quetsion_text: Unless you believe Vasari, Martini was probably the pupil of this leading Sienese artist. His Maesta altarpiece was tragically sawn in half in 1711 and was originally painted for the Siena Cathedral.

q3.quetsion_text: Martini's saint-strewn Maesta takes up the entire north wall of the Great Council Hall of this Sienese town hall that also contains Lorenzetti's Allegory of Good and Bad Government.

lead_in: This collection's "Et Cetera" section includes a tale of a sorcerer who creates a pool of ink to show a vision of a caliph's doppelganger that ultimately murders the caliph himself. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this book that opens with a story in which Lazarus Morell liberates slaves, only to resell them again and again before murdering them. Another section of this collection describes the atrocities of Ching Shih, the "lady pirate."
q1.raw_answer: A Universal History of Infamy [or A Universal History of Iniquity; or Historia universal de la infamia]

q2.quetsion_text: A Universal History of Iniquity was penned by this master of the philosophical short story, whose other collections include Dr. Brodie's Report and The Aleph.

q3.quetsion_text: This short-story collection, which includes "Blue Tigers" and "The Rose of Paracelsus," is Borges's last. Its title story focuses on a scholar who gives away the thoughts of an English dramatist to a random person over the phone.
q3.raw_answer: Shakespeare's Memory [or La memoria de Shakespeare]

lead_in: Identify the following about unusual negative quantities in physics, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: So-called "left-handed" examples of these artificial substances can exhibit a negative index of refraction. Other examples of these substances can be used to create superlenses capable of bypassing the diffraction limit.

q2.quetsion_text: The possibility of a negative energy density in quantum field theory was shown by this effect, named for a Dutch physicist, in which a force is generated in a vacuum between two uncharged conductors brought extremely close together.

q3.quetsion_text: Visser et al. suggested that negative mass may arise from angle excess in the cosmic variety of these one-dimensional objects, which sweep out two-dimensional worldsheets as they move through space.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this kind of test used to compare statistical models. Its has its namesake distribution under the null hypothesis, and it is the basis ANOVA.

q2.quetsion_text: An f test can be used to test if two populations with the same mean are also equal in this value, the squared of standard deviation.

q3.quetsion_text: F-tests are no longer robust when this condition is violated, and thus have a higher type I error rate. Under this condition, variance is constant and errors are not correlated with the explanatory variable.
q3.raw_answer: homoscedasticity (accept on homogeneity of variance; do not accept "heteroskedasticity")
