q1.quetsion_text: Name this 1830 event names after a month that ended the reign of the House of Bourbon in France.
q1.raw_answer: July Revolution (accept Three Glorious Days or Trois Glorieuses)

q2.quetsion_text: Charles X was overthrown because people really did not like this prime minister of his who helped draft the St. Cloud Ordinances.

q3.quetsion_text: This chamber of deputies gave this address that helped lead to the July Revolution in May of 1830 to protest Charles's rule.
q3.raw_answer: Address of the 221 Deputies (accept whatever that is in French)

lead_in: This vector operation is used to calculate torque and magnetic force.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this form of vector multiplication that gives a result perpendicular to the two original vectors.

q2.quetsion_text: This type of derivative on multivariable functions assumes that all of the independent variables, but one, are constant. Differential equations using this type of derivative are often contrasted with ordinary differential equations.

q3.quetsion_text: The cross product of the del operator, which takes partial derivatives, and a vector field is this operation, whose surface integral is related to a line integral by Stokes's theorem.

lead_in: Some critics of this book have focused on its reliance on the ideas of KojÃ¨ve in interpreting Hegel.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Francis Fukuyama work, which declared that after the end of the Cold War, liberal democracy would become the final form of government.
q1.raw_answer: The End of History and the Last Man

q2.quetsion_text: This German anti-Enlightenment philosopher was one of the earliest advocates of pure historical relativism, arguing that each epoch's conceptions are equally valid. His historically-minded works include This Too, On the Change of Taste, and the Critical Forests.

q3.quetsion_text: This German philosopher included the essay "On the Use and Abuse of History for Life" in his Untimely Meditations. He introduced his idea of the Ãœbermensch in Thus Spoke Zarathustra.

lead_in: This coin was worth ten asses, which is why its name translates as "containing ten."

q1.quetsion_text: Name this small silver coin, the most common circulated in the Roman Empire.

q2.quetsion_text: This emperor's predecessor, Diocletian, was the final emperor to issue bronze denarii. This emperor defeated Maxentius at the Battle of Milvian Bridge and converted to Christianity.
q2.raw_answer: Constantine the Great [or Constantine I; or Saint Constantine]

q3.quetsion_text: Constantine issued this pure-gold coin to replace the aureus and re-stabilize the empire's coinage. On the markets, one of these coins was valued at 275,000 debased denarii.

lead_in: This man led the Romans to victory against the deposed supporters of Tarquinius Superbus at the Battle of Silva Arsia, after which he inaugurated the tradition of riding a four-horse chariot at triumphs. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this colleague of Lucius Junius Brutus, who replaced Collatinus to become the third consul of the Roman Republic.
q1.raw_answer: Publius Valerius Publicola [accept either underlined part; accept Poplicola]

q2.quetsion_text: After a 508 BCE war with this man, Publicola surrendered his daughter Valeria as part of the peace treaty. This man survived an assassination attempt by Gaius Mucius Scaevola.

q3.quetsion_text: According to legend, during Lars Porsena's invasion of Rome, Publius Horatius Cocles held off the invading force at the Sublicius, an example of this type of structure.

lead_in: The banning and subsequent un-banning of this book was discussed in a 1980 essay collection by its author titled What Happened to it, or How South African Censorship Works. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this novel whose protagonist, Rosa, is jailed in the wake of the Soweto uprising after a meeting with her childhood friend Baasie prompts her to return to South Africa.

q3.quetsion_text: In July's People, civil unrest forces this family to flee to the countryside with the title character, their former servant. Its members include Bam, who builds a water tank for the village, and Maureen, who flees towards a mysterious helicopter at the end of the book.

q2.quetsion_text: The deaths of Sir Danvers Carew and Hastie Lanyon spur this lawyer to further investigate the mysterious relationship between his client Henry Jekyll and the brutish Mr. Hyde.

q1.raw_answer: marijuana [or cannabis; or obvious equivalents, such as pot, sativa, MJ, weed, bud, Mary Jane, marijuwana, grass, herb, ganja, chronic, reefer, Acapulco gold, Texas tea, Thai sticks, or Panama red]

q3.quetsion_text: In Ovid's Fasti, this man Â– and not Romulus Â– kills Remus with a shovel after Remus insultingly jumps over Romulus' walls, for whose construction this man served as foreman.

lead_in: The vertical-cavity surface-emitting type of this device uses two distributed Bragg reflectors as end-mirrors for the active region.

q1.raw_answer: lasers [or light amplification by stimulated emission of radiation]

q3.quetsion_text: The cantilever in AFM is commonly made from this type of material, in which charge accumulates as a result of mechanical stress. PZT and quartz are examples of this material.

lead_in: This work argues that the idea of "progress" in Enlightenment Europe combined with Romanticism and the growing discourse to obscure one civilization's influence on another. For 10 points each:

Heumann contributed to a racialized Romanticist nationalist tradition centering at this university. q3.quetsion_text: Bernal argued that the main Romanticist who influenced the Göttingen scholars was Johann Gottfried Herder, an exponent of this German literary movement named for a Friedrich Maximilian Klinger play.

The multiplicative element described by this term exists for every nonzero real number and is simply the real number's reciprocal.

lead_in: It states that the mean value of "e to the minus W over k T" equals "e to the minus delta F over k T." For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Anyone, especially Chris Ray, can use this equality to determine the change in free energy when a system is driven out of equilibrium by averaging the work done over a large number of trials.

q2.quetsion_text: Importantly, the Jarzynski equality is valid for processes that do not satisfy this condition. This kind of process minimizes inefficiency due to heat loss and is exemplified by the Carnot cycle.

q3.quetsion_text: The Jarzynski equality can be derived from the Crooks equation, which is a special case of this theorem. It gives the probability that an isolated system's entropy will spontaneously decrease.
q3.raw_answer: fluctuation theorem [do not accept or prompt on "fluctuation-dissipation (theorem)"]

lead_in: Herbert Storing and Murray Dry have compiled the definitive collection of these texts. For 10 points each:

lead_in: Rheumatoid arthritis is a disease of this type characterized by the presence of an antibody targeted against human tissue in the blood. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this class of diseases which also includes systemic lupus erythematosus and type 1 diabetes mellitus. These diseases are characterized by the body’s own immune system attacking itself.

lead_in: At the end of this story, one of its characters points out that bodegas are open all night long. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Ernest Hemingway short story in which a pair of waiters discuss why an old man, who orders a large amount of brandy, might need the title qualities of their café.

lead_in: This effect was first demonstrated in nature by showing that red imported fire ant workers kill queens that are homozygous dominant at the Gp-9 locus. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this potential explanation for altruism hypothesized by W. D. Hamilton, in which a certain allele causes organisms to preferentially treat others whom they recognize as bearing the same allele.

q2.quetsion_text: The term "greenbeard effect" was coined by this British evolutionary biologist in his book The Selfish Gene. He also wrote The Extended Phenotype.

q3.quetsion_text: W. D. Hamilton also popularized the idea of kin selection, in which organisms maximize the "inclusive" type of this concept. This concept denotes an organism's ability to survive and reproduce in a given environment.

lead_in: This philosopher argued that judgments about the existence of the external world must be bracketed - a method he called Ã©poche. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this German philosopher who wrote three volumes of Ideas and developed the idea of the "life-world" in The Crisis of the European Sciences and Transcendental Phenomenology.

q2.quetsion_text: Husserl wrote a series of meditations inspired by this French philosopher, whose Meditations on First Philosophy try to establish what is certain by imagining that all one's cognitive faculties are misled by an evil demon.

q3.quetsion_text: Husserl was also the original dedicatee of this book, which describes two modes of attitudes toward objects called readiness-at-hand and presence-at-hand, and takes Dasein, or existence, as its central concept.
q3.raw_answer: Being and Time [or Sein und Zeit]

lead_in: Methemo-glob-inemia causes characteristic mid-80s readings in this technique.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this technique in which a sensor is placed on a fingertip or earlobe, enabling one to measure the amount of bound hemoglobin.

q2.quetsion_text: Pulse ox readings are higher for these oxygen-rich blood vessels since they carry blood from the heart and lungs to the body. The pulmonary one is an exception, since it's deoxygenated.

q3.quetsion_text: Your pulse ox will not appear off if you are suffering from this condition, in which a diatomic gas with a triple bond steals the hemoglobin real estate normally needed by oxygen.
q3.raw_answer: carbon monoxide poisoning [or obvious equivalents, such as CO poisoning]

lead_in: This city on the Arkansas River is home to the BOK tower.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this city in Oklahoma, home to the Golden Driller statue and Oral Roberts University.

q2.quetsion_text: Tulsa defines the Cross Timbers ecoregion along with this Texas city, the second most populous in the Metroplex.

q3.quetsion_text: The West and Clear forks of this river join in downtown Fort Worth. It's the longest river located entirely in Texas.

lead_in: As a child, this man's father sent him as a hostage to King Stephen, whose threat to kill this man proved useless when his father declared he had the hammer and anvil to make another son. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this knight, known for his tournament prowess, who was as a regent for Henry III after serving under his three predecessors. His surname is an honorific referring to his role as the head of royal security.
q1.raw_answer: Sir William Marshal, [or 1st Earl of Pembroke]

q2.quetsion_text: During the Third Crusade, William Marshal joined the nobles who rebelled against this statesman, who had been named Chancellor in the absence of Richard the Lionheart.

q3.quetsion_text: William Marshal also served this king, who married Eleanor of Aquitaine and prompted the killing of the "meddlesome priest" Thomas Becket.
q3.raw_answer: Henry II [accept Henry Curtmantle or Henry FitzEmpress; prompt on "Henry (Plantagenet)"]

lead_in: A constant representing this phenomenon is subtracted from the atomic number to determine effective nuclear charge in Slater's rules.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this phenomenon by which electronic repulsion counteracts nuclear attraction, which generally causes atoms with more electrons to be larger in size. 4f electrons are especially bad at contributing to this effect.
q1.raw_answer: shielding effect [or electronic shielding; or word forms; prompt on screening]

q2.quetsion_text: The inability of 4f electrons to shield causes a "contraction" among these elements on the Periodic Table. These elements are located above the actinides.

q3.quetsion_text: Lanthanide electrons demonstrate this other electronic effect much more strongly. In this effect, moving electrons generate a magnetic field that interacts with electron spin, causing energy levels to split.

lead_in: In 1966, this man joked in Newsweek that Wall Street indices "predicted nine of the last five recessions." For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this first American to win the Nobel Prize in Economics. He authored the textbook Economics: An Introductory Analysis.

q2.quetsion_text: In Samuelson's textbook, he made a notorious prediction about the growth of the economy of this country, whose GNP he predicted would achieve a major benchmark in 1984.
q2.raw_answer: Soviet Union [or USSR; or Union of Soviet Socialist Republics] [he predicted the Soviets would overtake U.S.]

q3.quetsion_text: This Harvard professor, known as the "American Keynes," was one of Samuelson's teachers. The IS- LM model is sometimes labeled the "synthesis" of this man and John Hicks.

lead_in: This man’s first book was a study of popular culture called The Mechanical Bride. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this thinker who also wrote a study of print culture called The Gutenberg Galaxy. He coined the term “global village” and pioneered much of media studies with his text Understanding Media.

q2.quetsion_text: McLuhan famously wrote in Understanding Media that the medium was “this,” suggesting that the medium itself influences how we receive information.
q2.raw_answer: message [or the medium is the message; accept massage]

q3.quetsion_text: Another study of media is this 1985 Neil Postman book mainly focused on television, in which Postman argues that TV is part of a system in which viewers’ rights to information are exchanged for entertainment.

lead_in: During this event, Rear Admiral Cockburn reportedly ordered the destruction of all the "C" type in a newspaper building, so that his name could no longer be defamed.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this event led by Robert Ross that took place shortly after Ross's forces won the Battle of Bladensburg. During it, the Lansdowne portrait was legendarily saved by a woman.
q1.raw_answer: The burning of Washington, D.C. [or the burning of the White House; or obvious equivalents]

q2.quetsion_text: The burning of Washington, D.C. occurred during this conflict between the United States and Great Britain. The Battle of New Orleans occurred shortly after this war was technically over.

q3.quetsion_text: This October 1812 battle was a British victory that thwarted an American attempt to establish a base on the Canadian side of the Niagara River. It is best remembered for being the site of British General Isaac Brock's death.

lead_in: A conspiracy theorist made the homemade film 7/7 Ripple Effect about events in this city. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this city hit by the 7/7 (SEVEN-SEVEN) terrorist attacks, which were carried out by four Islamic suicide bombers using homemade organic peroxide-based devices.

q2.quetsion_text: The 7/7 bombings occurred during the ministry of this man, a Labour Party leader also criticized for leading Britain into the Iraq War. He was succeeded by Gordon Brown.

q3.quetsion_text: In 2004, Blair allowed for certain members of this ethnic group primarily from Nepal to be able to settle in the United Kingdom. This group formed a namesake brigade within the British army, and actress Joanna Lumley has fought for this group to have full UK civil rights.

lead_in: These constructs are necessary for one solution of the function argument problem. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these duples whose first element is a function and whose second element is the namespace for non-local variables of that function. They are used in continuation passing style.

q2.quetsion_text: In this programming language, named after a British TV show, function closures are used to implement function decorators. This scripting language is an alternative to PHP that uses indented white space for syntactic purposes.

q3.quetsion_text: Python and PHP are the scripting languages that comprise the last component of this acronym for a solution stack. The other three components are a certain operating system, a certain web server, and a database solution.
q3.raw_answer: LAMP stack solution [accept anything that mentions LAMP]

lead_in: So you're building a house in China. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: You orient the objects in the house, and the foundations of the house itself, according to the principles of this system, which means "wind-water."
q1.raw_answer: feng shui [or fung shway, which is how it's pronounced]

q2.quetsion_text: Just to be safe, you avoid buying this many tables or any number of tables containing this number either as a digit or a multiple, because the word for this number is similar to the word for death.

q3.quetsion_text: You peek under the floorboards and in the attic and evict any hiding members of this persecuted religion founded by Li Hongzhi, lest authorities break in and start searing your flesh with hot iron.
q3.raw_answer: Falun Gong [or Falun Dafa; or Dharma Wheel Practice; or Law Wheel Practice]

lead_in: An example of this simple machine with a slope of 70.9 degrees was built after the Johnstown Flood to allow quick access between Johnstown and Westmont.

q1.quetsion_text: What simple machine is a tilted surface and is commonly called a ramp?

q2.quetsion_text: This value for a frictionless inclined plane is the length of its slope over its height. In general, it's the ratio of the output force using a machine to the input force.

q3.quetsion_text: Given a box of mass m, experiencing only acceleration due to gravity, g, on a frictionless inclined plane with slope theta, what is the acceleration of the box?
q3.raw_answer: g times sine of theta [do not accept partial answers]

lead_in: This man suggested that captains of ships ferrying criminals to Australia be paid by the number of people who arrived alive, which resulted in a nearly 96% reduction in mortality of the passengers. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this public-health activist of the 1800s, who became the first director of the Board of Health after helping pass the Public Health Act of 1848. His work on the London sewer system was influential in warding off cholera.

q2.quetsion_text: In the 1820s, cholera made its way into Russia via this Caspian Sea port, from where it spread up the Volga into St. Petersburg. One of the Nazi goals of Operation Barbarossa was to establish a line of control from Archangelsk to this city.

q3.quetsion_text: The seventh major cholera pandemic, caused by the El Tor strain, began in this southeast Asian country, which has more recently seen avian flu scares on its islands of Sulawesi, Borneo, and Sumatra.

lead_in: This man made the leader of the CROM labor union, Luis Morones, a secretary of labor and commerce but later split with Morones. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this man who had de facto power during a period called the maximato. He promoted a grand literacy agenda and possibly orchestrated the assassination of Venustiano Carranza with his predecessor, Alvaro Obregon.

q2.quetsion_text: Calles's term as president included this conflict in which the government's attempts to enforce anti- Church measures in the Constitution of 1917 were met with fierce resistance from the Catholics. It lasted for most of the late 1920s.

q3.quetsion_text: Soon after coming to power, Calles nullified this 1923 agreement between Mexico and the U.S., negotiated by Obregon, which guaranteed that mineral-rich lands purchased by the U.S. would not be subject to seizure by the Mexican government under Constitution of 1917.
q3.raw_answer: Bucareli accords or agreement or treaty [accept Convención Especial de Reclamaciones or Special Convention [for or of] Claims]

lead_in: This man leaves his father and son at the temple of Ceres after fleeing Troy and attempts to return back home to find his wife Creusa, only to find her ghost.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this hero whose flight from Troy occurs before he defeats Turnus and the Rutulians in an epic poem that was considered a foundation story for Rome.

q2.quetsion_text: Aeneas becomes enraged and kills Turnus after he sees the belt of this man, the son of King Evander, on his waist.

q3.quetsion_text: Aeneas sojourned in this favorite city of Juno until Mercury called him out; while there, Aeneas married its queen, Dido.

lead_in: In the introduction to this piece, the solo trumpet plays raising triplet eighth notes in the third measure before sustaining a high C in the fourth measure. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this piece composed by Joe Oliver that was named for an area of Louisiana. Its best-known recording was made in 1928 by Louis Armstrong and his band.

q2.quetsion_text: That 1928 recording included Louis Armstrong and this collection of individuals, which included Earl Hines, Jimmy Strong, Fred Robinson, Mancy Carr, and Zutty Singleton.
q2.raw_answer: Hot Five [or Louis Armstrong and His Hot Five]

q3.quetsion_text: Earl Hines used his characteristic "trumpet-style" of playing this instrument on "West End Blues." Fats Waller pioneered the "stride" style of playing this instrument.

lead_in: The zoo and garden varieties of this technique compare the similarities in sequence between similar animal and plant species, respectively.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this technique in which a probe hybridizes to DNA that has been transferred to a nitrocellulose membrane. It isn't actually named for a cardinal direction, rather being named for a British biologist.

q2.quetsion_text: In the first step of a Southern blot, these enzymes, which recognize specific sequences,cut DNA into smaller fragments. EcoR1 and HindIII are oft-used examples.

q3.quetsion_text: At the end of a Southern blot, the hybridization pattern is visualized using this technique, in which molecules or fragments labeled with short-lived isotopes are taken up and then displayed on X-ray film.

lead_in: This type of motion is contrasted with nutation, and it can either be torque-free or torque-induced. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this type of motion easily visible in gyroscopes, in which the angular momentum vector of an object rotates about an axis.

q2.quetsion_text: Thomas precession is a mathematical correction to the motion of the spin of an elementary particle derivable from this theory. In this theory, the inner product of two four-vectors is a Lorentz-invariant quantity.
q2.raw_answer: special relativity [or SR; prompt on “relativity”; do NOT accept or prompt “general relativity”]

q3.quetsion_text: Precession and nutation can both be described as changes in one of these angles, which are a convenient choice of coordinates to describe rotations. Precession is a change in the first of them, while nutation is a change in the second of them.

lead_in: Answer the following about Anabaptistism, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: Most Anabaptists adhere to a strict and literal interpretation of this collection of sayings by Jesus; it includes the command to "be perfect, as your heavenly Father is perfect," and includes the Beatitudes.
q1.raw_answer: Sermon on the Mount [or sermo in monte]

q2.quetsion_text: The earliest Anabaptist confession was written in Schleitheim in this modern-day country, where Felix Manz, Conrad Grebel, and George Blaurock started an early Anabaptist group of "brethren."
q2.raw_answer: Switzerland [or Schweiz; or Swiss Confederation; or Confederatio Helvetica; accept Swiss Brethren]

q3.quetsion_text: Most members of this Anabaptist sect live in Canada or the upper Great Plains in the U.S. Its members live in nearly self-sufficient "colonies" in which all property is owned collectively.

lead_in: Identify the following about Sarah Emma Evelyn Edmonds, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: Edmonds dressed as a man to fight in this war, as did a person who called herself Albert Cashier. Clara Barton helped the wounded at this conflict's Siege of Petersburg.
q1.raw_answer: American Civil War [or the War Between the States]

q2.quetsion_text: Edmonds served in the Houston branch of this Union veterans' organization. Founded in Decatur, its members reliably voted for Republican candidates.
q2.raw_answer: Grand Army of the Republic [or G.A.R.]

q3.quetsion_text: Edmonds fought at the Battle of Blackburn's Ford, part of a Civil War campaign of this name. Stonewall Jackson's troops defeated Union Major General John Pope at this site.
q3.raw_answer: Manassas campaign [or Battle of Manassas Junction; or Battle of Bull Run; or First Battle of Bull Run; or Second Battle of Bull Run; or First Manassas; or Second Manassas]

lead_in: A key event leading up to the creation of this kingdom was the conquest of a Bourbon kingdom in the Expedition of the Thousand. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this European kingdom created in the Risorgimento. Its creation was advocated by journalist Giuseppe Mazzini.

q2.quetsion_text: This man, the founder of the newspaper Il Risorgimento, became Italy’s first Prime Minister. A nobleman, he hailed from Turin and died after only three months in office.
q2.raw_answer: Camillo Benso, Count of Cavour [accept either part; or the Conte di Cavour]

q3.quetsion_text: During the Italian War for Independence, Victor Emmanuel II allied with Napoleon III to win this massive 1859 battle against the Austrians. It is best known for inspiring Jean-Henri Dunant to found the International Red Cross afterwards.
q3.raw_answer: Battle of Solferino and San Martino

lead_in: This organization became more brutal after a Marxist attack on Siakhal. F

q1.quetsion_text: Name this organization, most of whose early personnel were trained by Norman Schwarzkopf and the CIA. This organization was the first to operate the notorious Evin University
q1.raw_answer: SAVAK [or Sazeman-e Ettela'at va Amniyat-e Keshvar; or Organization of Intelligence and National Security]

q2.quetsion_text: An Iranian ruler who took this royal title employed the SAVAK secret police and was effectively allowed to rule as an absolute monarch after Operation Ajax. This title was also used by the Qajars and Safavids.

q3.quetsion_text: This democratically-elected PM of Iran was targeted for overthrow in Operation Ajax because of his socialist sympathies and plans to nationalize Iran's oil industry

lead_in: The hypothesis that this value is inversely proportional to the age of the universe and thus decreasing was proposed by Paul Dirac. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this constant of proportionality that appears in the numerator of the equation for the Schwarzschild radius.
q1.raw_answer: universal gravitational constant [or big G; or Newton's constant; prompt on G; do not accept "little g"]

q2.quetsion_text: The universal gravitational constant appears in this scientist's law of universal gravitation, which apocryphally came to him when he got hit on the head with an apple while sitting under an apple tree.

q3.quetsion_text: Cavendish used one of these devices, invented by his mentor John Michell, to "weigh the earth" in his famous experiment measuring the universal gravitational constant. It consists of a twisted fibre whose energy is unleashed when it is untwisted.
q3.raw_answer: torsional balance [or torsional bar; or torsional wire; or torsional pendulum]

lead_in: The hydroxyl megamaser and this type of megamaser are the most common and best-characterized, and this type of astrophysical maser has an emission line at 22 gigahertz.

q1.quetsion_text: Name these astrophysical masers that vary significantly with time but are of great importance because they are found at the outer edge of the Milky Way and distance calculation using VLBI parallax measurements is extremely accurate for them.
q1.raw_answer: water masers [or H2O masers; or "megamasers" in place of "masers"]

q2.quetsion_text: As expected from a maser, the 22 gigahertz emission line of water lies in this part of the electromagnetic spectrum. Much radio astronomy actually takes place in this slightly shorter wavelength part of the EM spectrum.

q3.quetsion_text: An early success of radio astronomy was the accidental discovery of this thing by Arno Penzias and Robert Wilson.
q3.raw_answer: CMBR [or cosmic microwave background radiation; or relic radiation]

lead_in: Answer the following about Deuterocanonical Biblical books

q1.quetsion_text: Bel feeds a dragon a concoction that makes it explode, and Susanna resists the advances of two punning, lecherous old men, in the additions to this book, about a prophet who survives a lion's den.

q2.quetsion_text: A "Paean for Wisdom" and a message to those in captivity appear in a Deuterocanonical book named for this scribe and friend of Jeremiah. This common Jewish first name means "blessed" in Hebrew.

q3.quetsion_text: The first of the two books dedicated to this historical group details the repressive attempts at Hellenization by Antiochus IV Epiphanes. Both books describe the story of Hanukkah.

lead_in: The landmark 1974 Doherty-Zinkernagel experiment proved that these cells needed to recognize two separate signals on cells infected by viral meningitis.

q1.quetsion_text: Name these predominantly CD8-expressing cells that release granulysin, granzymes, and perforin against their targets.
q1.raw_answer: cytotoxic T cells [or Tc; or T-killer cells; or killer T cells; or cytotoxic T lymphocytes; prompt on "T cells"; do NOT accept "natural killer cells" or other wrong answers]

q2.quetsion_text: Cytotoxic T cells express this surface protein, which then binds to a namesake receptor to initiate the death-induced signaling complex. It is a member of the tumor necrosis factor family.
q2.raw_answer: FasL [or Fas ligand; or CD95L; prompt on "Fas"]

q3.quetsion_text: Cytotoxic T cells cause most of the injury seen in the B form of this disease, an inflammation of the liver which can be viral or triggered by drinking too much.

lead_in: The title creature of this poem “hangs still” at the “master-fulcrum of violence.” For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this poem about a man who tries to avoid the "swallowing of earth's mouth" when he sees a bird whose "wings hold all creation in a weightless quiet."

q2.quetsion_text: "The Hawk in the Rain" is the title poem of the first collection by this English Poet Laureate and husband of Sylvia Plath.

q3.quetsion_text: Plath wrote this poem about "a bag full of God" who "Bit my pretty red heart in two." The title figure is described as "a man in black with a Meinkampf look."

lead_in: Paul Johnson and Sean Wilentz wrote about the "kingdom" of this man, who may have fed his disciple Elijah Pierson poisoned blackberries. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this "prophet" of 1830s New York, whose servant was also accused and acquitted of Pierson's murder.
q1.raw_answer: Matthias the Prophet [or Robert Matthews; or Robert Matthias; or Jesus Matthias; prompt on "Joshua (the Jewish Minister)"]

q2.quetsion_text: This woman, who was known as Isabella Baumfree while she worked for Matthias the Prophet, later delivered the "Ain't I A Woman?" speech under another name.

q3.quetsion_text: One of the first biographers of Matthias, William Leete Stone, also investigated the "awful disclosures" of Maria Monk, who claimed that she was exploited as a nun at the Hotel-Dieu in this city.

lead_in: For 10 points each, answer the following about works of literature with something in common.

q1.quetsion_text: This book by Izaak Walton presents a series of debates between Venator and Piscator and, according to Wikipedia, "celebrates the art of fishing in verse and prose."

q2.quetsion_text: John Breval's "A Compleat Key to the Nonjuror" accuses this author of plagiarizing from Moliere. This hack wrote about Amanda seducing her husband Loveless to reform him in Love's Last Shift.

q3.quetsion_text: Stories by Fletcher Platt and this writer appear in The Compleat Enchanter, which contains this man's The Mathematics of Magic. This fantasy author of the "Harold Shea" books wrote about Martin Padway's travels in 6th-century Rome in Lest Darkness Fall.

q2.quetsion_text: This is the name usually given to the class of Protestant overlords that governed Ireland during the period of British domination, including the absentee landlords of the Land War.

q3.quetsion_text: This Conservative politician gained the nickname "Bloody" for his suppression of agrarian riots in Ireland. This man promoted the creation of a "national home" for a certain peoples in a letter bearing his name.

lead_in: Sometimes, this diagram uses the spectral classification (O, B, A, F, G, K, or M) for its horizontal axis. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this doubly-eponymous diagram which contains a “main sequence” stretching from its top left to bottom right. It plots various stars on a luminosity vs temperature graph.

q2.quetsion_text: The instability strip contains many stars of this type, whose luminosity changes periodically, allowing for them to be used as standard candles.
q2.raw_answer: variable stars [accept more specific answers like “Cepheid variables”]

q3.quetsion_text: The HR diagram can also be formulated in terms of this variable and magnitude, a formulation common in the use of galactic classification diagrams. Along with temperature and mass, this variable changes when moving between spectral classes, and Wien’s Law indirectly describes the relation between this variable and temperature.

lead_in: The speaker of this poem asserts that his "innocent and quiet" mind allows him, unlike "fishes that tipple in the deep" and "enlarged winds that curl the flood", an angelic sense of liberty.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this poem whose last stanza begins with the lines "Stone walls do not a prison make, nor iron bars a cage".

q2.quetsion_text: "To Althea, From Prison" is the most famous work of this Cavalier poet.

q3.quetsion_text: In 1649, Lovelace published a collection titled for this woman. He notes "I'm still as happy as I was" in a poem addressed to her "Going Beyond the Seas" and includes the lines "I could not love thee, dear, so much, loved I not Honor more" in a poem addressed to her "Going to the Wars".
q3.raw_answer: Lucasta [accept "To Lucasta, Going Beyond the Seas" or "To Lucasta, Going to the Wars"]

lead_in: Name some things related to Continental philosophy, for 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: This thinker pointed out the parallel roots of fascism and imperialism in The Origins of Totalitarianism. She also explored the importance of obedience and the “banality of evil” in Eichmann in Jerusalem.

q2.quetsion_text: This member of the Frankfurt School and contributor to The Authoritarian Personality explored the cultural effects of the “negative dialectic” in Minima Moralia and The Dialectic of Enlightenment with Max Horkheimer.
q2.raw_answer: Theodor W. Adorno [or Theodor Ludwig Wiesengrund]

q3.quetsion_text: This British philosopher, a student of Raymond Williams, rejected the militant atheism of “Ditchens” in his Gifford Lectures and wrote the seminal textbook Literary Theory: An Introduction.

lead_in: In one story in this collection, the evil serpent-seductress Manago frames the boy Toyoo for theft; in another story, Kougi, an artist who draws fish, dies and comes back to life as a fish in Biwako. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this collection of nine horror stories by Ueda Akinari that includes "The Lust of the Snake" and "The Carp of My Dreams."
q1.raw_answer: Tales of the Moonlight and the Rain [accept Tales of the Moon and the Rain or Ugetsu Monogatari]

q2.quetsion_text: Horror writer Edogawa Rampo created a member of this profession named Kogoro Akechi, and Toru Takemitsu created a man of this profession in his only novel. Peter Wimsey is an amateur member of this profession.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Runge developed a method with Kutta for approximating the solutions to the "ordinary" variety of these equations, which relate a function and its derivatives.

q2.quetsion_text: With Laplace and Lenz, Runge gives his name to the LRL vector, which is conserved in all orbital problems involving this many bodies, which is an unsolved problem if another body is added. A common application is a binary star system.

q3.quetsion_text: Runge's theorem creates a sequence of rational functions which converge to a function of this type. These complex-valued functions are complex-differentiable at every point in their domain.

lead_in: This is the most fundamental religious characteristic of both Judaism and Islam. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this English term for tawhid - the belief in one, and only one, god.

q2.quetsion_text: This Arabic term denotes any sort of “turning away” from God, including egoism, idolatry, and polytheism. It is often divided into akbar and asghar, or greater and lesser, forms.

q3.quetsion_text: Egotistical people are doubly bad since they also emulate this figure, who defied God’s command that all angels worship Adam because he was “made of clay”, while this figure was made of fire.
q3.raw_answer: Satan [or Iblis; or Shaytan; or the Devil]

lead_in: This man rejected the existence-essence distinction posited by Aquinas, and his earliest works were commentaries entitled the “parva logicalia.” For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this philosopher dubbed Doctor Subtilis. He rejected Aristotle's account of "categories" in favor of his own characterization of existing universals as "common natures."

q2.quetsion_text: Duns Scotus' best known work is a commentary on this Peter Lombard book that comments on various individual Biblical passages.
q2.raw_answer: The Four Books of Sentences (or Libri Quattuor Sententiarum)

q3.quetsion_text: Duns Scotus also wrote a commentary on the Isagoge, an introduction to Aristotle's commentaries written by this Neoplatonist thinker and disciple of Plotinus.

lead_in: This man married his daughter to the poet Sir Philip Sidney. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this principal secretary of the English crown, who uncovered the Babington and Throckmorton plots as the de facto spymaster for Queen Elizabeth I.

q2.quetsion_text: Walsingham hired many turncoats from this religion, who were barred from advancement by the Test Act and the Act of Settlement. "Bloody Mary" fervently observed this religion.

q3.quetsion_text: Walsingham tried to intercept the Casket Letters from this Catholic ruler and enemy of Elizabeth. The Babington plot tried to install this long-imprisoned ruler on the English throne.
q3.raw_answer: Mary, Queen of Scots [or Mary Stuart]

lead_in: The work of Lodovico Castelvetro and other neoclassicists was instrumental in leading to the widespread adoption of these principles in the modern era. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these dramatic ideas, the first of which comes from Aristotle's Poetics and advises eschewing subplots. Later-added ones advocate the use of a single space and no more than 24 hours' time.
q1.raw_answer: the classical unities [or Aristotelian unities; or three unities]

q2.quetsion_text: Cardinal Richelieu led the AcadÃ©mie FranÃ§aise's attack on this Pierre Corneille play, which did not respect the classical unities. Its title character takes a break from fighting Moors to duel Don Sanche for the hand of ChimÃ¨ne.

q3.quetsion_text: This man's failure to respect the unities in his play Hernani led to a riot at the play's premiere. This Frenchman is better-known for such novels as Les MisÃ©rables.

lead_in: Possible methods of resolving this problem include a cycle called the latercus and the Alexandrian computus. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this millennia-long problem in Christianity that was resolved in the kingdom of Northumbria at the Synod of Whitby.

q3.quetsion_text: The First Council of Nicaea resolved an early Easter-date controversy by declaring that the holiday would no longer be calculated based on this Jewish month; the Quartodeciman controversy also concerned Christian practices aligned with this Jewish month.

lead_in: This man is told a story about Mary Jane Reed, whom the narrator calls "The Monkey." For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this psychoanalyst who has to hear about Alexander's various sexual exploits and his massive Oepidus complex with regard to his mother Sophie.

q1.quetsion_text: Urban Dictionary cites the “Water Temple” level from Ocarina of Time as “the equivalent to a complete rectal examination.” Ocarina of Time was, of course, an entry in this popular Nintendo series starring Link.

This character runs the Vermilion Gym and as his name indicates, likes electric-type Pokemon.

q3.quetsion_text: This Super Nintendo RPG featured the inscrutable hint to “walk the seasons from spring to winter and back to spring again.” The hero tries to re-energize the title sword by visiting eight temples and is opposed by the sorcerer Thanatos.

q3.quetsion_text: Mitterrand became president by defeating this centrist politician in the 1981 election.This man lost popularity after he accepted a gift of diamonds from his buddy Jean-Bedel Bokassa.

lead_in: Constantin Stanislavsky chose to direct this play as a tragedy, despite its author having written it as a comedy.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this play that centers on an auction, eventually won by Trofimov to the chagrin of Trigorin and others, which decides the fate of a feature of Madame Ranevskaya's estate.

q2.quetsion_text: This Russian short story master and playwright wrote Three Sisters, Uncle Vanya, and The Cherry Orchard.

q3.quetsion_text: In this Chekov story, Dr. Rabin is bankrupted by a trip taken with the postmaster Mikhail and ousted from his position by Dr. Khobotov, after which he finds himself incarcerated with the realist Gromov in the title institution.

lead_in: This work includes such characters as Erminia, the princess of Antioch, and the Muslim-allied warrior-maiden Clorinda, both of whom convert to Christianity for love of the knight Tancred. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this epic which also details Armida’s abduction of Rinaldo, a fictionalization of the First Crusade by Torquato Tasso.

q2.quetsion_text: The story of Rinaldo and Armida mirrors the story of Alcida and Ruggerio in a Ludovico Ariosto epic poem titled for this character “furioso”, which is a continuation of an unfinished Matteo Boiardo poem about him “innamorato”.

q3.quetsion_text: Orlando Furioso and Orlando Innamorato were both written in stanzas using this rhyme scheme, pioneered by Giovanni Boccaccio, in which the lines follow an a-b-a-b-a-b-c-c pattern.

lead_in: This algorithm for solving a second-order ordinary differential equation near a singular point requires only that the coefficient functions of the first- and zeroth-order terms have at worst first- and second-order removable singularities respectively. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this technique. Under the above hypothesis, Fuchs' theorem guarantees that it will find at least one solution.

q2.quetsion_text: In general, the method of Frobenius produces solutions in this form. A solution in this form can be summed to yield a more desirable closed-form solution in special cases.

q3.quetsion_text: This is the name for an equation that relates the terms of a series to one another. A step in the method of Frobenius is to derive one of these equations by equating like terms in the substituted ODE, then solving for the zeroth-order term to obtain the indicial equation.

lead_in: The sine-Gordon and the Korteweg-de Vries equations possess solutions corresponding to these phenomena. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these bizarre waves, which maintain their shape while moving translationally. Even after a collision between two of them, they maintain their original shapes.

q2.quetsion_text: Solitons can occur in real life when nonlinear effects on a wave exactly cancel the effects given this name, which arise from the phase velocity of a medium having a frequency dependence. This phenomenon causes white light to split into many colors upon entering a prism.

q3.quetsion_text: Dispersion occurs when this quantity is wavelength-dependent. This quantity acquires a directional dependence in birefringence.

lead_in: New York City has expanded its offerings of this kind of education through the CTE program, which opened The Harbor School in 2003.

q1.quetsion_text: Give this term for technical education designed to prepare students for specific trades, such as plumbing or electrical work. In the United States, this form of education is often provided through community colleges.

q2.quetsion_text: This country's vocational education system is cited as a reason for it having one of the lowest youth unemployment rates in Europe. This country's Free Democrats failed to win enough seats to secure national representation in its most recent parliamentary election.
q2.raw_answer: Federal Republic of Germany [or Bundesrepublik Deutschland]

q3.quetsion_text: German vocational education frequently pairs apprentices with one of these mid-sized German enterprises, which are typically export-oriented and occupy niche markets, usually in the machine or chemical industry.

lead_in: Name these people who helped convert Scandinavia to Christianity, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: Rimbert wrote the life of this Archbishop of Hamburg, who was known as the Apostle to the North for his missionary journeys to Sweden.

q2.quetsion_text: The English bishop Grimketel speedily canonized this Norwegian king, who was killed at Stiklestad by rebellious farmers.
q2.raw_answer: St. Olaf [or Olaf II; or Olaf Haraldsson; prompt on "Olaf"; do not accept or prompt on "Olaf Trvggyvason"]

q3.quetsion_text: The Jelling Stone, which was erected by this king, claims that this son of Gorm the Old "turned the Danes to Christianity." He was succeeded, perhaps forcefully, by his son Sweyn Forkbeard.

lead_in: You are a Tokugawa official tasked with uncovering Kakure Kirishitan, or hidden Christians. You also have a terrible secret of your own: you are Auroni Gupta. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: You hope no one notices your UCSD sweatshirt under your kimono as you try to identify Kirishitan by seeing who refuses to step on these flat images of Christian symbols, whose name literally means "stepping- on pictures."

q2.quetsion_text: As you shoot the breeze with your fellow Tokugawa officials, you casually mention that the Christian daimyo Koshini Yukinaga refused to commit this type of belly-slashing ritual suicide, and you even-more- casually mention that you learned this fact by being a completely normal Japanese man, not by playing Dynasty Warriors.

q3.quetsion_text: You begin discussing this sect of "separated" Kirishitan, who kept their hidden practices after Christianity was officially legalized in the 1870s. When you realize that the 1870s haven't happened yet, you break down and tearfully confess that you are Auroni Gupta.

lead_in: The commander of this ship, Corcoran, says he never—well, hardly ever—uses bad language. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this ship which, while docked off Portsmouth, is boarded by Little Buttercup. Dick Deadeye works here, and Sir Joseph Porter, the First Lord, also arrives here.

q2.quetsion_text: The H.M.S. Pinafore is a comic opera by this British duo, who are also responsible for The Mikado and The Pirates of Penzance.
q2.raw_answer: William Schwenck Gilbert and Arthur Seymour Sullivan [both are needed, in any order]

q3.quetsion_text: Pinafore is described as “infernal nonsense” in a song sung by Stanley, a character with this rank in Pirates of Penzance. Stanley boasts he is “well acquainted, with matters mathematical.”

lead_in: In the human genome, the most common of these elements is called Alu. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these genetic sequences which are particularly abundant in eukaryotes. They have an RNA intermediate that is reverse transcribed and then inserts itself back into the genome.
q1.raw_answer: retrotransposons [prompt on transposons; prompt on transposable elements; do not accept or prompt on "DNA transposons"]

q2.quetsion_text: Alu elements are classified as this type of retrotransposons, which lack long terminal repeats and which do not code for functional reverse transcriptase. They are shorter than LINES.

q3.quetsion_text: Alu elements get their name because they are recognized by AluI, one of these proteins, which cleave DNA at specific sequences. Molecular cloning makes heavy use of these enzymes.

lead_in: Identify the following about Thomas Love Peacock, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: Peacock’s article “The Four Ages of Poetry” prompted a response in the form of the essay “A Defense of Poetry” from this man, whose own poetic works include “Alastor”, “To a Skylark”, and “Ozymandias”.

q2.quetsion_text: Peacock’s novel Nightmare Abbey takes as its epigraph a quotation about a “dark lantern of the spirit” from Hudibras, a long poem by this author, who shares his first and last names with the author of The Way of All Flesh.

q3.quetsion_text: Peacock described the pleasures gained from contemplating “the universal mutability of things” in a poem titled for “The Philosophy of” this emotional state, also the subject of a Robert Burton book about its “Anatomy”.

lead_in: A boy lies on a grassy field with his arm over his face in this artist's watercolor Daydreaming, while a woman jealously looks over her shoulder at a couple in a beached canoe in his engraving Two Are Company, Three Are None. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this American artist who is most famous for his marine scenes, including Breezing Up and The Gulf Stream.

q3.quetsion_text: The left-most boy is falling to the ground in this Homer painting, which shows a group of mostly-barefoot boys linking arms and playing the title game.

lead_in: Answer the following about Scandinavian sculpture, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: Beloved Danish icon Bertel Thorvaldsen is best-known for designing a monument in Lucerne that commemorates the Swiss Guards and takes the form of a wounded one of these animals. Four bronze ones designed by Edward Landseer surround Nelson's Column.

q3.quetsion_text: This Swedish-American sculptor created Minneapolis's iconic Spoonbridge and Cherry and Lipstick (Ascending) on Caterpillar Tracks for Yale's Morse College. He is also known for his soft sculptures of huge everyday objects.

lead_in: India went on the offensive to seize this region in Operation Meghdoot. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this uninhabitable, militarized glacier in the Saltoro range of the Karakorum Mountains, which has a sign at its snout declaring it to be the world's highest battlefield.

q2.quetsion_text: The Siachen Glacier is an area of conflict in this region, where a long-running dispute between India and Pakistan erupted into the 1999 Kargil War.

q3.quetsion_text: Operation Meghdoot was fought because the Line of Control established in this 1972 agreement was not extended to the Siachen Glacier, likely because the negotiators thought the glacier was too worthless to fight over.

lead_in: This company was the original publisher of Oscar Sonneck’s journal The Musical Quarterly, and its 1964 acquisition of AMP added Elliot Carter, Henry Cowell, Walter Piston, and others to its catalog. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this oldest continuously active North American music publisher, now a part of the Music Sales Group, which was established in 1866 by the German immigrant for which it is named.

lead_in: This work begins with an apology in which the author asserts that "particularity" and "universality" are two opposing forces that comprise both the world and spirit. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this series of five orations addressed to "cultured despisers" who would rather study philosophy or poetry than the title discipline, which the author calls a "sense of taste for the Infinite in the finite."
q1.raw_answer: On Religion: Speeches to its Cultured Despisers [or Über die Religion]

q2.quetsion_text: On Religion: Speeches to its Cultured Despisers was written by this German Protestant philosopher who wrote The Christian Faith.

lead_in: Name these ancient Hellenic city-states, none of which are Athens or Sparta

q1.quetsion_text: This city-state used a stone track called the diolkos to move trade ships overland across its namesake isthmus.

lead_in: This location lies roughly along a line connecting the wooded regions of Thuringia with the plains of Hesse and gives a much easier route to cross its namesake river than using the Northern highlands or the Vogelsberg Hills. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this region that, for most of the Cold War, was thought of as an entry point for the Soviet invasion of Western Europe.

q1.quetsion_text: Name these cells which can be formed by reprogramming adult cells, or can be extracted from the inner cell mass of the embryo. They can differentiate into many other different cell types.
q1.raw_answer: stem cells [or induced pluripotent stem cells; or embryonic stem cells; or other types of stem cells]

q2.quetsion_text: Specifically, embryonic stem cells are extracted from this structure's inner cell mass. It develops from the morula and has around 100 to 200 cells.

q3.quetsion_text: Another way to make stem cells is by injecting the nucleus of one of these cells into an ovum which has its own nucleus removed. This term refers to pretty much any body cell that's not a germ cell.

lead_in: One poem about this item notes that "his hands had put instead an artificial wilderness and a sky like lead." For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this object, the subject of a W. H. Auden poem, which is also described at length in the 18th book of the Iliad, when its owner uses it in his fight against Hector.
q1.raw_answer: shield of Achilles [accept apsis in place of "shield"]

q2.quetsion_text: This Greek word is used to refer to a description of a work of art within another work of art. Classical examples include the description of the shield of Achilles, as well as the description of Aeneas's shield in the Aeneid.

lead_in: Identify the following regarding Pulitzer-winning plays of the 1930s, for 10 points each.

lead_in: Answer the following about far-right European political parties, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: Leaders from this country's Golden Dawn party have described Hitler as a "great personality" and praised Rudolf Hess as a hero while winning eighteen seats in its Parliament.
q1.raw_answer: Greece [or Hellenic Republic; or Elliniki Dimokratia; or Ellas; or Ellada]

lead_in: While living at Port Breeze in the U.S., this man may have encountered the Jersey Devil. For 10 points each:

lead_in: Answer the following about histology, for 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: The first step of tissue analysis is usually this process of preservation, in which the tissue is stabilized against external damage and crosslinked with additives like formaldehyde. In preparation for electron microscopy, this process also usually requires a cryoprotectant.

q2.quetsion_text: This iconic tissue staining method for light microscopy produces bluish-purple stains. It's usually abbreviated to two letters.
q2.raw_answer: H&E stain [or HE stain; or hematoxylin and eosin stain]

q3.quetsion_text: Another staining method named for this Italian was initially used to identify nervous tissue. An organelle named for him receives proteins synthesized in the endoplasmic reticulum for further modification and transport.

lead_in: In the first section of this part of a larger poem, the speaker lays out his plans to describe the "condition", "array", and "degree" of a group of people gathered at the Tabard Inn in Southwark.

q2.quetsion_text: The General Prologue, like the rest of the Canterbury Tales, was written by this 14th-century author of the Book of the Duchess.

q3.quetsion_text: After the depressing Physician's Tale, the host's request for a more pleasant tale is fulfilled by this one, in which three Flemish men set out to kill Death but end up finding gold and killing each other. Its teller describes its "theme" as "Greed is the root of all evil".

lead_in: Answer these questions about changes within the military of the late Roman republic, for 10 points each.

q1.quetsion_text: This rival of Sulla and seven-time consul reformed the military by allowing non-landowners to join the ranks and giving land as a retirement bonus.

q2.quetsion_text: Crassus revived this ancient punishment in 71 BCE, by which a commander ordered the random execution by lot of a tenth of his own men

q3.quetsion_text: Roman soldiers could not bear arms inside this symbolic boundary around the city of Rome, a taboo which Sulla's march on Rome broke. The Senate couldn't meet more than a mile outside it.

lead_in: This man was legally adopted by the Fonteii family in order to renounce his patrician status and become eligible for the office of tribune of the plebeians.

q1.quetsion_text: Name this populares leader who was murdered by a number of gladiators. His followers made him a makeshift funeral pyre, but that accidentallly caused the Curia Hostilia to burn to the ground.

q2.quetsion_text: Though this goddess's cult excluded men, Clodius attempted to intrude on her cult's mysteries and seduce Caesar's wife while disguised as a woman, leading to a scandal.

q3.quetsion_text: This orator argued that his friend Milo justifiably murdered Clodius in self-defense. This man condemned Marc Antony in the Philippics and exposed the conspiracy of Catiline in the Senate.
q3.raw_answer: Marcus Tullius Cicero [or Kikeron; or Tully]

lead_in: Plato claimed that she was the mother of Poros, or expediency, but most stories assert that she was only able to have one child, due to a prophecy that the second would be extremely powerful. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Identify this Titaness representing wisdom, who was turned into a fly and swallowed by Zeus.

q2.quetsion_text: Nevertheless, this daughter of Metis sprang from Zeus’s forehead, fully-formed and fully armed. This virgin goddess advised many heroes and was identified with the Roman Minerva.

q3.quetsion_text: Athena won a competition against Poseidon to become the patron deity of Athens by offering the Athenians this botanical gift, which was judged superior to Poseidon’s creation of a saltwater spring.
q3.raw_answer: an olive tree [prompt on partial answer; accept Olea europaea, I guess]

lead_in: This character's mother Alberta, who never appears onstage, dies in childbirth. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this baby, the daughter of a washed-up baseball player who didn't manage to break the color line in the majors. She is raised by that man's wife Rose.

q2.quetsion_text: Raynell is the illegitimate daughter of Troy Maxson, who refuses to allow his son Cory to pursue a football scholarship in this 1983 play.

q3.quetsion_text: This African-American playwright included Fences alongside Radio Golf and The Piano Lesson in his ten-part Pittsburgh Cycle.

lead_in: An article in Midnight Pussycats about this character’s disappearance claims that she is covered in cement at the bottom of San Pedro Bay. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this star of a pornographic film in which she peels a banana, a locket-wearing actress who is kidnapped by a flying saucer and mated with another character in an alien zoo.

q2.quetsion_text: Wildhack has a child with Billy Pilgrim on the planet of these toilet plunger-shaped aliens. This race sees in four dimensions, meaning that they experience all moments simultaneously.

q3.quetsion_text: The Tralfamadorians appear in several novels by this author of Sirens of Titan and Slaughterhouse-Five.

lead_in: The first of these three treaties helped cause the fall of the Whig government in 1710, and Jonathan Swift published "Some Remarks on" it two years later. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these Anglo-Dutch treaties that were intended to allow the Dutch to build up and fortify its borders against a Bourbon neighbor.

q2.quetsion_text: Negotiations for the three Barrier Treaties occurred during and after this 1701 to 1714 war, which began after the death of Charles II and included the Battle of Malplaquet.

q3.quetsion_text: The first Barrier Treaty was negotiated by this man, who was nicknamed "Turnip" after he introduced to England the four-course rotation of wheat, turnips, barley, and clover. His grandson of the same name proposed the Revenue Act of 1767 while serving as Chancellor the Exchequer.
q3.raw_answer: Charles Townshend, 2nd Viscount Townshend [accept Turnip Townshend or Townshend Acts]

lead_in: This author wrote a comic novel that ends with Teodorico getting expelled from Aunt Titi's house after Titi discovers that the sought-after title object is really a lace nightdress from one of Teodorico's carnal exploits. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this Portuguese author of The Relic who was part of a group of radical positivists known as the Generation of 1870. He also wrote Cousin Bazilio and The Sin of Father Amaro.
q1.raw_answer: Jose Maria Eça de Queiroz [prompt on partial last name]

q2.quetsion_text: Eça de Queiroz's masterpiece is this 1888 novel in which the young aristocrat Carlos, with his friend Joao da Ega, observes the title family's financial and moral decline in 19th-century Lisbon.

q3.quetsion_text: Eça de Queiroz translated this British author's King Solomon's Mines into Portuguese.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Give this name for the strategic rivalry for supremacy in Central Asia between Britain and Russia during the late nineteenth century.

q2.quetsion_text: The Great Game resulted in sparring over influence in Iran and this other country, later invaded by the Soviet Union in 1979. This country was often referred to as the Kingdom of Kabul while dominated by the Durrani confederacy.

q3.quetsion_text: The creation of this line, named for a British diplomat, effectively created a buffer zone between Britain and Russia in Asia. This line forms the de facto border between Afghanistan and Pakistan.

lead_in: Answer the following about freezing point depression,

q1.quetsion_text: Freezing point depression is an example of one of these properties, which depend on the concentration of a dissolved solute rather than its actual nature. Osmotic pressure is another example.

q2.quetsion_text: To determine the freezing point depression of an ideal solution of calcium chloride, you multiply the freezing point depression constant by the molality and this integer, which would be the van't Hoff factor for calcium chloride.

q3.quetsion_text: Freezing point depression is no longer effective below this temperature, because the system separates into two distinct solid solutions of different concentrations. For salt water, this temperature is -21.2 degrees Celsius.

lead_in: This philosopher questioned whether it would be an obligation to take in and take care of a child who grew from a “people-seed” that floated through an open window. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this author of "A Defense of Abortion," a Columbia education moral philosopher and metaphysician.

q2.quetsion_text: A famous thought experiment in "A Defense of Abortion" is when the writer wakes up attached to a violin player via a dialysis machine, and an objection to that thought experiment draws on the distinction between these two acts to argue that the death resulting from detaching the violinist is less immoral than an abortion.

q3.quetsion_text: Thomson invokes this Biblical parable from the Gospel of Luke when talking about a woman who carries a fetus to term. In it, Jesus told of a man who was beaten and left for dead until a man came by and rescued him.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this wife of Ahasuerus and cousin of Mordecai. Her story is the basis for the Jewish holiday of Purim.

q2.quetsion_text: Esther and Mordecai were both members of the Hebrew tribe descended from this man. He and Joseph were the two sons of Rachel.

q3.quetsion_text: Ahasuerus married Esther after rejecting this first wife of his, who fell into disfavor after she refused to appear before the king at a feast.

lead_in: [missing]

q1.quetsion_text: Name this nightmarish 1830 piece which uses a series of pizzicato notes to portray a severed head bouncing into a basket in its fourth movement, "March to the Scaffold".
q1.raw_answer: Symphonie fantastique: Ã‰pisode de la vie d'un artiste...en cinq parties, Op. 14 [or Fantastic Symphony: An Episode in the Life of an Artist, in Five Parts]

q2.quetsion_text: Symphonie fantastique is by this French Romantic composer who called for four offstage brass bands in his Requiem.

q3.quetsion_text: Berlioz's Requiem also unusually calls for sixteen of these instruments, which are tuned using a pedal. This instrument and a clarinet open Jean Sibelius' first symphony.

lead_in: In one painting with this title, an open doorway looks out onto the sea, and in the other, a window looks out onto a forested region. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Give the common name of these paintings in which a canvas on an easel blends in with the landscape seen through the door or window behind them.
q1.raw_answer: The Human Condition [or La condition humaine]

q2.quetsion_text: Both versions of The Human Condition were painted by this Belgian bowler hat aficionado.

q3.quetsion_text: Magritte again painted a painting on an easel in front of an open window, this time contrasting the tower of a castle with the projective shape of a street, in this painting. Its name derives from its inspiration in geometry.
q3.raw_answer: Euclidean Walks [or Les promenades de Euclid; or Promenades of Euclid]

lead_in: Four of these elements are arranged anti-parallely in Greek key domains, and glycine and proline residues play a key role in these structures because they can assume unusual dihedral angles. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name these secondary-structure elements, found in protein domains called sandwiches and propellers. The two end strands of these structures can hydrogen bond to form cylinders called "barrels."

q2.quetsion_text: This fold consists of three beta strands alternating with two alpha helices. It is commonly found in proteins, such as NAD and FAD, that bind to nucleotides.

q3.quetsion_text: An alpha-beta barrel consisting of eight alpha helices alternating with eight parallel beta strands is named for triose phosphate isomerase, which catalyzes the interconversion of glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate and this molecule in glycolysis.

lead_in: This complex is home to the Great Enclosure. For 10 points each:

q1.quetsion_text: Name this site built by ancestors of the Shona people, whose soapstone bird sculptures were often stolen over the ages

q2.quetsion_text: This British overseer of Cape Colony and De Beers diamond magnate argued that black people couldn't have built Great Zimbabwe, though they did.

q3.quetsion_text: Rhodes envisioned a railroad from "Cape to [this city]", allowing British holdings to span the whole African continent. Anwar Sadat and Gamal Abdel Nasser were secular rulers here.
